description:
After two weeks, as our roster settles down, I'll make a slide deck where each student will have a single slide.  

Please follow the steps below 10 separate times (I'm asking for 10 videos total)
1. Pick one of the topics from the list below
2. Find and watch (end-to-end) a 3-10 minute (roughly) video that explains the topic.  You can use Youtube, Investopedia, Khan Academy, Linkedin Learning, or whatever else you feel is engaging and reputable.  Using a 1-5 star scale, rate them on 1) Informative (helpful and accurate) and 2) Presentation (easy to follow, fun, interesting)
3. Rate the videos across two factors: Informative (helpful and accurate) and 
Presentation (easy to follow, fun, interesting)

So at the end of the semester, you'll have watched 10 videos and each of those videos should have ratings (1-5 stars).

Hint: You may have to tweak your search to find relevant and interesting videos.  E.g. "Least harm ethics" instead of just "least harm"

"Do we have to go through every item on the list?"
- Nope.  You can just pick 10. 

You'll submit a link to your slide in Canvas, but please get started on it now.  Cramming introduces a severe learning risk.  Learn more about how [your brain needs time and sleep to learn](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0o2yyO0JAes)

**List of topics**
Utilitarianism
Least Harm
Respect for Autonomy
Beneficence
Justice
Deontology
Virtue ethics
Ethics of care
Egoism
Religion or divine command theory
Natural Law
Social contract theory
Rawls’s theory of justice
Moral relativism
John Stuart Mill beliefs

As a team over the next few weeks, start a company within the ethics domain.  I challenge you to make this more than just a business plan, but the beginnings of a revenue-generating company that has a chance of providing a useful service in the ethics domain.  Show substantive evidence of viability. 

There is no Canvas submission.  Please show your individual contributions using two annotated screenshots in a shared class Google Presentation. 

"Wait... so we have to build an actual business?"
- Yes.  But I won't fail you if your business fails to bring in revenue

- You can also show substantive evidence of viability (this is the first step to obtaining seed money and Series A funding). 

"Does the business have to be in the ethics domain?"
- Yes
- I'd suggest something that pressures other companies to be more transparent or honest about its dealings.  
- E.g. a service that pressures companies to be more environmentally friendly (maybe offers a sticker for those that qualify)
- E.g. a service that pressures other companies to help someone in need (maybe offering a badge to qualifying companies)
- E.g. a service that identifies sex trafficking, drug dealing, money laundering, scams, or other criminal activities 
- E.g. a Private Investigation service

"Could I help automate some sort of audit process?"
- Yes - this would an awesome service.  I'd highly recommend this function.

"How do audits work?"
- An audit is often one person (or machine) who digs into another company's operations and tries to find unethical and/or illegal things

"Who would define the audit criteria?"
- You.  Or I'm fine with you partnering with whoever.

"And if this turns out to make money or become my full time job, does Kingsford or UVU get any of the money?"
- No

Discuss

Your response to this discussion will have two parts to it: your initial post and your response to another student's post.

Initial Post

Your initial post should contain the following 3-2-1 items:

  • Answer three questions about yourself: Where you are from, What your major is, and What your expectations of this course are.
  • Identify two interesting concepts you learned/discovered in this module's reading
  • Pose one question related to the reading material

Peer Response

After your initial post, you will then see your peers' posts. Constructively and critically evaluate one other student's question and post your reply. Response content must be substantive and not just a reiteration of the post. Constructive criticism is welcome but be courteous and professional in your response.

Grading

This discussion is worth a total of 20 points.

  • 10 points for initial post. Please submit your initial post by Friday which allows your group members to respond to your post by Monday.
  • 5 points for your peer responses.
  • 5 points for your professional citizenship and etiquette.

See the grading rubric for more details on how you will be assessed by 1) clicking on the options icon and 2) selecting "Show Rubric."

There is no late submission after the "until" day. There is no late penalty if you complete both posts before or on the "until" date.

Discuss

Your response to this discussion will have two parts to it: your initial post and your response to another student's post.

Instructions

Read the following scenario and answer the question posed below.

Scenario

In the first four modules, we learn the basic concept of logical reasoning. We learned about propositions, predicates, tautology, contradiction, etc.. One of the things that we did not discuss is logical paradox.

A logical paradox is "an argument that derives or appears to derive an absurd conclusion by rigorous deduction from obviously true premises."  (Encyclopedia: Logical Paradoxes) One of the famous logical paradox was called "Achilles Paradox" which was presented by an ancient Greek philosopher Zeno of Elea. Achilles Paradox states that Achilles was asked to catch a slow-moving tortoise which had a head-start crawling away from Achilles. If Achilles wants to catch the tortoise, he needs to first run to where the tortoise is at the present time. Once he runs to where the tortoise was, the tortoise will be at a new location. Therefore, Zeno concluded that Achilles will never catch up to the tortoise.

Initial Post

We know the conclusion of the Achilles paradox contradicts our common sense. Why does Zeno's argument reach a conclusion that contradict the fact? Your initial post should be a few sentences long to reason whether Zeno's argument was correct. If you argue that it is correct then you need justify why the conclusion contradict the fact. If you argue that Zeno's argument was invalid then show where the mistakes are in his argument.

Peer Response

After you post you will then see your peers responses. Constructively and critically evaluate one other student's post and post your reply. Response content must be substantive and not just a reiteration of the post. Constructive criticism is welcome but be courteous and professional in your response.

Grading

This discussion is worth a total of 20 points.

  • 15 points for initial post. Please submit your initial post by Friday which allows your group members to respond to your post by Monday.
  • 5 points for your peer responses.

See the grading rubric for more details on how you will be assessed by 1) clicking on the options icon and 2) selecting "Show Rubric."

There is no late submission after the "until" day. There is no late penalty if you complete both posts before or on the "until" date.

Discuss: Multisets

Your response to this discussion will have two parts to it: your initial post and your response to another student's post.

Introduction

The topic of this chapter is sets. In a set, we don't list the multiple occurrences of an element. For example, {1, 1, 2, 3} is the same as {1, 2, 3}. In the upcoming chapters, we will present the concept of multisets. A multiset is like a set except it allows for multiple occurrences of the same element. In multisets, {1, 1, 2, 3} is different from {1, 2, 3}.

Example

Here is an example that illustrates the difference of using sets versus multisets. I went to the grocery store and bought two apples and three oranges. If I am only interested in the items that I purchased, I will use a set with two elements, {apple, orange}. However, if I am interested in the detailed list of everything that I bought, I will use a multiset with five elements, {apple, apple, orange, orange, orange}.

Initial Post

Create a multiset (like the example above) from something that you use in your everyday life. Your multiset must demonstrate the appropriate usage of sets and multisets to model/represent data. 

Peer Response

After you post you will then see your peers responses. Constructively and critically evaluate one other student's post and post your reply. Response content must be substantive and not just a reiteration of the post. Constructive criticism is welcome but be courteous and professional in your response.

Grading

This discussion is worth a total of 20 points.

  • 15 points for initial post. Please submit your initial response by Friday so your group members can respond to your post by Monday.
  • 5 points for your peer responses.

See the grading rubric for more details on how you will be assessed by 1) clicking on the options icon and 2) selecting "Show Rubric."

There is no late submission after the "until" day. There is no late penalty if you complete both posts before or on the "until" date.

Discuss: Transitive Closure

Introduction

In this module, we learned about relations. The concept of relations are very important in computer science and data science. It is the foundation of relational databases and some aspects of social network analysis. One of the concept we discussed in this chapter is transitive closure on a binary relation.

Example

Transitive closure is useful in social network analysis. For example, if the transitive closure of a social network is identified, it is easy to know if John can be reached by Mary in the network provided John and Mary are the members in the social network in considerations.

Instructions 

Construct and post at least one other transitive closure application that interests you or something that you encounter in your everyday life.

Peer Response

After you post you will then see your peers responses. Read through your peer responses to see what transitive closures they have created. Peer responses are optional in this assignment and are not graded, however constructive criticism is welcome but be courteous and professional in your response.

Grading

This discussion is worth a total of 15 points.

The penalty for late submission is 10%/day.

See the grading rubric for more details on how you will be assessed by 1) clicking on the options icon and 2) selecting "Show Rubric."

assignment_name: Module 10 - Discuss: Recursive vs. Iterative Algorithms
description:
Discuss: Recursive vs. Iterative Algorithms

Introduction

In this module, we focused our discussion on recursive algorithms. As you learn from your previous courses, most of these recursive algorithms can be implemented as an iterative algorithm. As an example, I listed below two different implementations of calculating factorial: one uses recursive algorithm and the other uses iterative algorithm. (These code segments do not have error checking in them.)

Recursive implementation of finding factorial

def FactRec(n):
    if n==0: return 1
    return (n*FactRec(n-1))

Iterative implementation of finding factorial

def FactIte(n):
    factorial = 1
    for i in range(1,n+1):
        factorial = factorial * i
    return factorial

Instructions

In this discussion assignment, please post a comparison of the advantage OR the disadvantage of using recursive algorithm and iterative algorithm.

How will you choose between advantage or disadvantage? The first person to comment will choose one or the other, the next person to comment will choose the opposite, then the next person will choose the opposite of the last comment. Nobody can choose the same advantages or disadvantages that someone else has already used. FOR EXAMPLE: Mike is the first person to comment on this discussion and posts the advantages, Saul is the next person to comment so he must post the disadvantages, Kate is the 3rd person to comment and she must post the advantages (the advantages cannot be the same advantages that Mike has already posted), Gus is the 4th person to comment and he must post the disadvantages (again it cannot be the same disadvantages that Saul already posted), and the rest of commenting will go so forth until everyone in your group has posted a new advantage or disadvantage. 

Grading

This discussion is worth a total of 15 points.

  • 15 points for initial post.

See the grading rubric for more details on how you will be assessed by 1) clicking on the options icon and 2) selecting "Show Rubric."

There is no late submission after the "until" day. There is no late penalty if you complete your post before or on the "until" date.

Discuss: Combinatorial Calculations

Your response to this discussion will have two parts to it: your initial post and your response to another student's post.

Introduction

In this module, we introduce the concept of combination using several examples. One of the examples is counting different hands of a standard deck of cards. We show how calculate the number of five-card hands that have a pair and a three-of-a-kind. There are other fields of study that rely on the combinatorial calculations.

Initial Post

Research what other fields of study of your interest that rely on combinatorial calculations. Then present another example that has not been mentioned in the textbook.

Peer Response

After you post you will then see your peers responses. Constructively and critically evaluate one other student's post and post your reply. Response content must be substantive and not just a reiteration of the post. Constructive criticism is welcome but be courteous and professional in your response.

assignment_name: Module 13 - Discuss: Applications of Directed & Undirected Graphs
description:
Discuss: Applications of Directed & Undirected Graphs

Your response to this discussion will have two parts to it: your initial post and your response to another student's post.

Instructions

In this course, we have discussed directed and undirected graphs. In directed graph, the edge connecting two vertexes has an arrow head indicating the direction of relation, meaning the relation is not reciprocal. On the other hand, the edges in an undirected graph have no arrow heads indicating the relations are reciprocal. 

Example

Here is an example of using a directed graph and an undirected graph to model two different relations in social media groups. A directed graph can be used to model the Twitter Follower relation. For example, John Mary means John follows Mary on Twitter. This "follow" relation is not reciprocal, i.e., "John follows Mary" does not imply "Mary also follow John". An undirected graph can be used to model the FaceBook friend relation. For example, John — Mary means John and Mary are friends with each other. The "friend" relation is mutual and goes both ways.

Initial Post

Please post an example of using a directed graph and an undirected graph to model a system.

Peer Response

After you post you will then see your peers responses. Constructively and critically evaluate one other student's post and post your reply. Response content must be substantive and not just a reiteration of the post. Constructive criticism is welcome but be courteous and professional in your response.

Grading

  • 15 points for initial post. Please submit your initial post by Friday so your group members can respond to your post by Monday.

This semester we'll be doing a group project.   You'll be assigned to a working group of 4-5 people who will meet together outside of class and prepare the submissions for each milestone.

Group Project Milestone 1:

For this milestone, you'll be turning in a Project Launch Details document that you'll prepare with your team.  The document will contain the following:

List of Team members

Proposed Meeting schedule (must meet at least once a week outside of class throughout the semester, but can be more as needed -- meetings can be in person or remote over Zoom or MS Teams.  Note that talking together for 5 minutes in the classroom before class starts is not a "meeting", but an organized sit-down meeting immediately before or after class time is fine.)

Schedule of Scrum Masters (each team member must be scrum master for a "sprint" at least once during the semester -- a "sprint" will be the time period in between project milestones, every 2-3 weeks)

Programming Language your team will use for project (note that anything other than C#, C++, Java, or Python will need instructor permission)

Source Control (what your team will use for central repository for code or other project files -- GitHub, Visual Studio Version Control, or something similar.  I would recommend using something that has version control, not just a cloud storage folder)

Project Management -- what your team will use for task management, to-do lists, and other project specific details (may be the same as the source control option).  

Also, note that all "official" meetings of your team should have a Meeting Report which outlines: who attended, agenda items you discussed, action items for each team member to work on before next meeting.   You'll be turning in all your meeting reports during each milestone in addition to the specific milestone requirements.  I'd encourage the assigned scrum master for each sprint to take the lead in preparing the meeting agenda ahead of each meeting to make your meetings more structured and productive, then just take notes during the meeting on your existing agenda docs and turn those in as your meeting reports.

For submission:  each team member should submit the group Project Launch Details document described above as their submission for this assignment (this is how I will know that each team member has been participating in the preparation with the team so far).   One chosen team representative will also submit the meeting report(s) for each team meeting before the milestone due date (this will be the scrum master in future milestones, but pick one representative for the meeting reports this milestone, no need for every team member to submit the meeting reports).

Grading: 35 points for Project Launch Details document, 5 points for one or more meeting reports from this milestone period

An important and influential educational client has hired your company to develop a software simulator called UVSim for computer science students to learn machine language and computer architecture. Students can execute their machine language programs on the simulator.

The UVSim is a simple virtual machine, but powerful. The UVSim can only interpret a machine language called BasicML.

The UVSim contains CPU, register, and main memory. An accumulator – a register into which information is put before the UVSim uses it in calculations or examines it in various ways. All the information in the UVSim is handled in terms of words. A word is a signed four-digit decimal number, such as +1234, -5678. The UVSim is equipped with a 100-word memory, and these words are referenced by their location numbers 00, 01, ..., 99. The BasicML program must be loaded into the main memory starting at location 00 before executing. Each instruction written in BasicML occupies one word of the UVSim memory (instruction are signed four-digit decimal number). We shall assume that the sign of a BasicML instruction is always plus, but the sign of a data word may be either plus or minus. Each location in the UVSim memory may contain an instruction, a data value used by a program or an unused area of memory. The first two digits of each BasicML instruction are the operation code specifying the operation to be performed.

BasicML vocabulary defined as follows:

I/O operation:
READ = 10 Read a word from the keyboard into a specific location in memory.
WRITE = 11 Write a word from a specific location in memory to screen.

Load/store operations:
LOAD = 20 Load a word from a specific location in memory into the accumulator.
STORE = 21 Store a word from the accumulator into a specific location in memory.

Arithmetic operation:
ADD = 30 Add a word from a specific location in memory to the word in the accumulator (leave the result in the accumulator)
SUBTRACT = 31 Subtract a word from a specific location in memory from the word in the accumulator (leave the result in the accumulator)
DIVIDE = 32 Divide the word in the accumulator by a word from a specific location in memory (leave the result in the accumulator).
MULTIPLY = 33 multiply a word from a specific location in memory to the word in the accumulator (leave the result in the accumulator).

Control operation:
BRANCH = 40 Branch to a specific location in memory
BRANCHNEG = 41 Branch to a specific location in memory if the accumulator is negative.
BRANCHZERO = 42 Branch to a specific location in memory if the accumulator is zero.
HALT = 43 Pause the program

The last two digits of a BasicML instruction are the operand – the address of the memory location containing the word to which the operation applies.

What you'll be submitting:

Design Document (20 pts) -- document that describes the high-level functionality of your application.  Your document will need at least 2 User Stories and 10-15 use cases outlining the functionality of your application.  (Ranges here are deliberate to avoid making your use cases too broad or too narrow.)

Working Prototype  (40 pts) -- prototype of your application that works from the command line -- it should ask for an input file and then process that file (using the console for any input/output specified by the file contents itself).  This is a prototype, so code it with an eye towards getting it working first, but also with an eye towards (as yet unknown) future expansion.  ALL team members must contribute to the code base -- you will need to submit a link to your source control base (or a screenshot from your source control that shows that all team members have checked in code for your project).

Unit Tests (30 pts) -- each use case should have two unit tests (so 20-30 total) to test the functionality of each use case (you can have more if you deem it suitable for that use case -- remember that unit tests in general need to test both the success condition(s) for each function as well as all possible failure conditions as well.).   The code for the unit tests should also be part of your source control code base.     You will also create a spreadsheet that lists the unit tests in row/column form.  Give each unit test a name, short description, the reference to the appropriate use case, inputs, expected outputs, and how you know whether the test succeeded or failed.

Other Documents (10 pts) -- Create a README.txt text file that describes how to use your application from the command line.  The grader should not need any information outside of your README to understand how to launch and use your application.  Make sure you note here if the programming language you used for the project requires some prerequisites to be installed ahead of time in order for your project to run. In addition to README, also submit your meeting reports from this sprint.

Test Files:

Test1.txt

Test2.txt

Your UVSim prototype was demonstrated and approved by your client for continuation as an "actual" project.  However, they want to make sure the application has a solid design behind it, as well as has a user-friendly GUI instead of the command line.

Your submissions for this milestone:

Modifications from previous milestone (10 pts): in your feedback to the previous milestone, I should have given you an indication if any of the user stories / use cases or code your team submitted needed additions or modifications.   Edit your document and/or source code to fulfill those requests and resubmit with the given changes for these points.  (If the feedback indicated that no changes were necessary, you'll have these points automatically)

GUI Design Document (10 pts): As part of your project revision, you'll need to discuss and design as a team how you want your user interface to work.  Create a "wireframe" diagram of your GUI that shows in basic form how it will look and how it will work.

Code Changes (35 pts): After you've designed your GUI, implement it in your code base.  Make sure it meets common-sense standards of "user-friendliness" (proper labelling of controls, proper workflow -- you'll want to discuss this as part of your functional requirements below).   Note that depending on how you constructed your code for the previous milestone, you may need to redo parts of your original code to support the GUI layer.   (This is common with most prototypes that show proof-of-concept but some/all of the code ends up getting 'thrown away' when design revisions are made.)  

Class Definition Document (15 pts): Describe all of the classes in your project, including interfaces, base classes, and abstract classes.   Make sure your class design is properly modular with loose coupling (i.e. no user interface code in the data model classes or "business logic" classes.  Proper class design should also make sure classes are divided appropriately without one class becoming too big or unwieldy.  (If you have a class that has more than five fields and/or ten functions it is probably a good candidate to subdivide into multiple classes).  In your document, each class should have additional documentation for the following: purpose of the class, purpose of each function, description of any input parameters for the function, description of return value (if any), pre- and post-conditions for the function.

Software Requirement Specification (SRS) Documents (20 pts): Submit the 7-8 SRS documents as defined by the process below. 

Other Documents (10 pts): Submit a revised README.txt describing how the grader can use your GUI to perform operations.  Also submit any meeting reports from this sprint.

Software Requirement Specification Document format:

1. Each team member (without consulting with other team members) will create their own SRS document containing 15 functional requirements and 3 non-functional requirements.

2. Submit these documents WITHOUT NAMES to the scrum master assigned to this sprint. 

3. The scrum master will divide the team into two groups and assign half of the documents to each team.

4. Each sub-team will discuss the documents they've been given and "merge" them into one document.  (The merged documents should still have at least 15 functional requirements and 3 non-functional requirements in the end, but can have more if you find that the submitted requirements are distinct and valuable enough apart from each other.  Don't just copy and paste one into another, though -- you'll need to discuss how to add/combine/rewrite the contents of both files to create the new one so it is internally consistent without repeats, redundancy, or contradiction between all the requirements.)

5. Each sub-team submits their merged document back to the scrum master.

6. As a team, meet and examine the resulting documents, and create one final SRS document based on your group's discussion and feelings about the results of the previous exercises.  (The resulting final document should have at least the same 15/3 content as before after any merging/rewrites, but can have more.  As before, make sure your final document is consistent after the merge with no repeats, redundancy or contradictions)

7.  Submit the final document as well as the 6-7 working documents created in the earlier steps.

For this milestone, submit the following:

Revisions To Previous Milestone (10 pts):  In the feedback for the previous milestone, I should have given you indications about revisions to your previous document or submissions.  Make those modifications and resubmit for these points.  (If my feedback says your submissions needed no changes, you will have these points automatically).

New Design Modifications (80 pts):  Your client likes the application so far, but has some new feature requests (read: new requirements): 

  • The current interface should be 'branded' with the appropriate color scheme, with the default being the UVU colors.   Furthermore, the color scheme should be configurable by the user without needing to recompile and reinstall the app.   Set up a system where the user can configure a color scheme (one primary color, and one 'off-color') and have the app (either instantly or upon restart) start using that custom color scheme.  (You can do this inside the app somewhere, or through a configuration text file containing the color info that is read on startup).   You can decide whether to use RGB or Hex values for the colors -- UVU uses a dark green that's RGB (76,114,29) / Hex# 4C721D with white (255,255,255 / #FFFFFF) as the off-color.  You can decide how and where to add the color to your interface, making sure that it is still readable and usable.  Text can still be black or dark gray.
  • Currently, if there's an issue with the file input (even a single byte) the process has to be recreated and redone.  The request now is that your application supports loading in the file first to the GUI in such a way that the command order can be inspected and modified before execution with the ability to add, modify, and delete commands through the GUI.   The client wants to be able to cut, copy, and paste as well as make individual manual changes to the code sequences. (NOTE that the max size of the data (100 entries: #00 - #99) cannot change, so don't allow add or paste operations that would exceed the max size.)
  • The client wants to be able to save and load files from any user-specified folder (not just a fixed default system folder).  

Note that for these functional changes you'll need to modify (and resubmit) not just the source code, but all of the associated design documents and elements that are affected by these changes:  unit tests, use cases, requirements, changes to GUI wireframe, class diagrams, and your README instructions for the grader.  All aspects of your project should be up to date with the current state of your working application.

Other Documents (10 pts): Submit your meeting reports for this sprint as well.

Your next meeting with the client goes well: "We love it...we just need some more features!"

  • The scope of each processed file is judged to be too small:  expand the application so it can handle 250 line files, instead of 100.  Note that this will require the support of three-digit line #'s instead of two (although you do not have to support more than 250 lines -- any command that references a line # greater than 249 will be invalid).  Note that to support this, the last digits to handle the address or value portion will need to be expanded to accept three digit values as well -- thus the final processing word for each line will now be 6 digits instead of 4 (and you will now handle 6 digit values for memory registers and math values).   The function codes for each operation will not change: simply append a zero to the beginning of each functional code (i.e. 010 instead of 10 will represent a READ command here) using this 6 digit format.
  • NOTE: With the above expansion, as a team you should decide how to support "old" files (4 digit word files): pick one of the following -- support both "old" and "new" files (you'll have to come up with a way to differentiate them at load or run time, but be able to edit/run them both in your app), or support a one-way "conversion" process feature where you can take a 4-digit file and convert it to six digit form (with leading zeroes) and save it to a "new" file format for execution.
  • The application should allow multiple files to be opened in the application at once (you can decide on the implementation -- GUI tabs, sub-windows, or other options, but the client should be able to have multiple files open simultaneously within your app instance, with the ability to edit and/or execute each of those files within the app with the same features as the previous milestone.)

As before, these functional changes will require revisions to the source code, unit tests, class diagrams, functional specifications, and README instructions.

Submit these new documents and code along with any meeting records from this period.

Grading will be the same as earlier milestones:

10 points:  Any feedback or requests from the previous milestone that you need to change

80 points: Functional changes to code and documents as outlined above

10 points: Meeting reports from this sprint.

Final submission time!

No new features this time around, so your source code and unit tests should already be in good shape!

Two major submissions to complete your final meeting with your client.

Client Presentation Video:

You'll be making a presentation to the client where you discuss and demo your application (assume this presentation will be to higher-level executives that have not been active in the development meetings before now, so have not seen your application before).   Rather than a live presentation to the class, your team will create a presentation video recorded by your team as if you were presenting to the client.  (Note that you can record individual sections and edit them together for the final submission video, you don't need to perform and record the entire thing "live" -- practice it and make sure you get an effective recording that puts your project and team in the best light for your current or future clients).

The content and organization of the presentation will be up to your team, but can contain some coherent combination of:

  • Project introduction / explanation (why does it exist, and what problem is it supposedly solving?)
  • Overview of the development process (you can introduce your team here and outline how the process went -- who worked on what, etc)
  • Application demo (make sure you hit all the features that were specifically requested by the client in the previous milestones)
  • Roadmap for future (see below).

All team members need to participate in the presentation in some fashion.  The final video should be 10-15 minutes in length (no shorter or longer) and can include Powerpoint slides as well as the project demo (or any other media elements you think would make an effective presentation).  If you decide to assign out sections of the video to different team members to record, then edit them together afterwards, make sure there aren't any contradictions or redundancies between sections -- act as if you were still making the presentation live by taking turns, and the script / flow of the presentation should make sense in that context.

Final Project Submission Document

Compile all of your previous documentation into one final document that you'll submit to the client:

  • User stories / use cases
  • Functional specifications
  • Class diagrams and GUI wireframes
  • Unit test descriptions
  • Application instructions (user manual), the contents of the README basically, but formatting in a more formal way (i.e. add some screenshots for the UI descriptions)

In addition, make sure your document has the following:

  • Cover Page
  • Table of Contents
  • Introduction / Executive Summary (a couple of paragraphs describing the purpose and content of your project, for executives who may not have followed the development process closely).
  • Future Road Map (brainstorm some possible directions you could take your application in the future -- new features, additional platform support, etc.)  You won't have to support these in code, but I'd like to see some thought put into what else you might do with your app in the future if you had follow-on projects over the next X months or years.   Make some new UI mockups as needed to demonstrate your ideas -- you should incorporate your road map into your video presentation above as well and some new design diagrams may be helpful there also. 

Make sure your document is formatted properly so it looks like one cohesive document, not a bunch of separate elements pasted together at the last minute.   Either PDF or Word format is allowed for the document. 

Submit both deliverables (along with any final meeting records) for your final project submission.  Congratulations for completing your project!
This homework has been CANCELLED, so you don't need to do anything!  (Canvas won't let me turn it off, so it will be here throughout the semester, but worth 0 to your grade)

Please complete your course evaluation which is very important. Please upload the snapshot of the submission confirmation to get your credit.  (This is worth 5 extra credit points, applied to your Homework score.)

This quiz is open-book, open-notes, but not open-neighbor -- do your own work and find the right answers.  You'll have 4 hours total, but only one attempt so make sure you are ready to devote the time needed to complete the exam.   The exam will cover any of the topics covered in the textbook and in class discussions.

Final exam is multiple-choice, open-book, open-notes -- 4 hour time frame.   Note that Canvas shuffles the answers so interpret any "All/None of the above" options as "All/None of the other answers".   Good luck!

description:
About-Me Web Page

In this project, you will create an “About Me” web page containing some basic info about you.

This assignment is meant to be a bit tedious.  There are a lot of little parts to it. In order to really learn HTML you have to spend time with it.  That means doing a lot of stupid tedious stuff.

Sorry.

Try and have fun with it.

A significant part of this assignment will be looking up the various HTML elements on the web.  As a web developer, you need to get used to Googling stuff.  Certain things you’ll need to know off the top of your head, but you’ll find yourself looking things up constantly.

A good place to start is w3schools:  http://w3schools.com.  Look for their HTML tutorial (If you can’t find it on their website, I bet Google can).

See a starter REPL here.  This starter REPL will be used for the first two projects.  This contains your code header/disclaimer which should be placed in all of your submissions.  You should not copy and paste anything but the disclaimer into your project.  It is important that you WRITE EVERY LINE OF CODE FROM SCRATCH for this project.

Assignment description

Your web page must have the following, in this order:

Header and Page Title (15 pts)

    1. In the <head> element, set the title, which appears on the browser’s title bar. The title should read: About <your-name>
    2. Put your name in a header, level 1.
    3. Put a recognizable picture of you using an <img> tag.
      1. Please use a paint program to resize and crop your image so that it is no larger than 500 by 500px (It does not have to be square).
      2. If the image looks squashed or stretched I’m going to take off points.
      3. The image should live in the same folder as your HTML page.

Personal Info (10 pts)

Your personal info

      1. Have a header (level 2) that says: “Personal Info:”
      2. Next, use an unordered list (bullet points) and give me the following pieces of info:
        1. Your major (spell it out. Don’t abbreviate).
        2. Your high school, and the year you graduated.
        3. What year are you in, currently, at UVU.
        4. Your favorite flavor of ice cream (mmmm, ice cream).
      3. Make use bold text for each label like in the example that I provided below.

Five Favorite Books (10 pts)

Enter your Five favorite books

    1. Have a level-2 header titled “My five favorite books”
    2. Choose five books that you like the best, and list them in the order of your preference.
    3. Each title should be italicized. Each author’s name should be in regular text.
    4. Add hyperlinks. For each of the five books you listed, make the author’s name a hyperlink to the author’s website. 

Haiku (10 pts)

 Compose a haiku or a limerick, or other short poem (3 or 4 lines).  Please keep your poem PG-rated (no potty humor, no sexually suggestive stuff).

    1. Have a level-2 header with a title of your poem
    2. Have a sentence or two explaining your inspiration for the poem.
    3. Put your poem after the header.
    4. Each line should use line-breaks, not paragraph breaks.

Brief Essay (15 pts)

      1. Make a level-2 header titled something like: “My personal interests”
      2. Give me three paragraphs, with three or more sentences each. In each paragraph talk about something you’re interested in.

Class Schedule (30 pts)

For the Class Schedule I want you to create a table that shows your weekly class schedule. This is easy to do using table elements, but it does require some attention to detail. 

      1. Make a level-2 header titled “class schedule”
      2. Create a table with 6 columns.
      3. Set the border size to 1, so I can see the borders for each cell. Set the cell spacing to 3, and set the cell padding to 3.
      4. The header row should have a blank cell, followed by cells for Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday. If you have a Saturday class (you poor soul), you can add a sixth column (or not, I don’t care, really).
      5. Going down the left side of the table, I want you to list out the hours of your week-day in 30-minute increments. You can start as early as you feel necessary.
      6. List the classes you have as cells. Use the row-span element to block out as many 30-minute cells as you need for each item.  If you have stuff that starts at an odd time, then guess.  I won’t care, as long as it doesn’t look all wonky.
      7. Fill up your schedule. Make stuff up if you have to.  I want to see at least four classes that run M-W-F or Tu-Th or every weekday.  In addition to classes, You can put your employment, your work-out time, your commute time, or anything else you like.
      8. Use the rowspan attribute, so if you have an hour-long class, the cell should take up two rows, without a line between them.

EXTRA ITEMS (5 Required, 10 pts max)

Do any five of the following things.  You will need to find this stuff out for yourself:

      1. (2 points) Can you set a repeating background image? The text should still be readable.  Pick something that doesn’t make my eyes bleed, or I won’t give you credit.
      2. (2 points) can you change the font used in the body of the document to something besides Times New Roman (or whatever your browser uses by default)?
      3. (2 points) can you make your photo right-aligned on the page, and make the page’s text flow around it?
      4. (2 points) on all hyperlinks, can you make it so that the underline only appears when you mouse-over the link?
      5. (2 points) find a way to indent your poem, or center it on the page.
      6. Weekly Schedule
        1. (2 points) text alignment. On your schedule, can you find a way to have all the text vertically aligned to the top and horizontally aligned to the left (including the headers).
        2. (2 points) on your weekly schedule, can you fill in in each block so that each thing is color-coded in its own color (English is yellow, calculus is light red, work is light blue, etc)?
        3. (2 points) equal column widths. On your schedule, can you find a way to have the column widths fixed so that they’re all the same size

When doing your weekly schedule, make sure your table doesn’t show any of the following errors or I will deduct points:

Errors from left to right:

  • Block of time that takes a whole hour, but uses two separate cells
  • Missing Cells
  • Missing Cells
  • Extra blank cells at end of row

 

Sample web-page

Here is a sample of what I’m talking about.  The fonts may vary.  Don’t worry about how your page looks.  All I really care about is can you get it to come out roughly like what I describe in this document (this example would be worth 92 points):

Tom Abbott

Personal Info

  • Major: Computer Science
  • High School: Kadena High, Okinawa, Japan. 1987
  • Current year at UVU: Sophomore
  • Favorite ice cream: Bear Claw

Five favorite fantasy novels

  1. Lord of the Rings, R. R. Tolkien
  2. Harry Potter, K. Rowling
  3. Chronicles of Narnia, S. Lewis
  4. A Wizard of Earthsea, Ursula K. LeGuin
  5. Son of the Black Sword, Larry Corriea

 

A Haiku I Wrote

Ode to my co-worker, whose desk is too close to mine:

The slurping man slurps

herba mate all day long

I crank my headphones

 

Personal interests

I like writing.  I started about 11 years ago, after I moved to Utah.  I’ve won a few minor awards, but right now I don’t have a lot of time.  I’ve completed one novel and three short stories.  Two of my short stories took Honorable Mention with the L. Ron Hubbard Writers of the Future contest.

I also like historical european martial arts (HEMA).  When I have time I study with a group of HEMA enthusiasts in Provo.  We study old manuscripts from the 1300s and 1400s and learn fighting techniques with two-handed longswords.

I also teach college as an adjunct professor for both BYU and UVU.  This was an unexpected opportunity, which fell into my lap.  It takes a lot of time and it is tough, but I get to work with a lot of people and make friends, and share the things that I’ve learned in my career.

 

Class schedule

 

Turning in your assignment

Please submit the following:

1. Zip File:  Put your .html file, your .css file, and all images and any other resources into a .zip file, and upload them to canvas.

2. Netlify URL:   

Please upload your site to Netlify and post your URL into a comment in your submission.  If you haven't done that before, see these instructions:

Hosting your own Web Site on Netlify

3. Your Self Grade

Review the rubric and give yourself a grade for each section.  Feel free to make additional comments clarifications

Add a comment on your site using the following format:

--SELF GRADE--
HEADER                      A / B / C / D / E
PERSONAL INFO        A / B / C / D / E
FAVE BOOKS              A / B / C / D / E
HAIKU                          A / B / C / D / E
ESSAY                         A / B / C / D / E

SCHEDULE                 A / B / C / D / E

--EXTRA ITEMS COMPLETED--Minimum of 5
REPEATING BKG IMG (2pts)            YES/NO
CHANGE FONT (2pts)                       YES/NO
RT ALIGN PHOTO (2pts)                   YES/NO

INDENT/CENTER HAIKU (2pts)        YES/NO

TABLE-TEXT ALIGN (2pts)                YES/NO

TABLE-COLOR CODE (2pts)             YES/NO

TABLE-EQUAL COL WIDTH (2pts)    YES/NO

ADDITIONAL COMMENTS

Cascading Style Sheets – ‘About Me’ CSS

In this project you’ll build upon the “About Me” web page.  You’ll create an external CSS document that your page links to, and you’ll use that CSS page to modify the look and feel of your document.  Featured in this spec are pictures and example from Tom Abbott, a former adjunct.

 

Required work (80 points total)

This portion is worth 80% of your grade. 

  1. Use an external .css file. All CSS should live in this file. 
  2. Your .css file must live its own folder. I suggest you name it ./styles, or ./css
  3. In your HTML, you may use the class attribute, only. You may not use the style attribute.

 

Body (15 points)

Font

Set a font for the body.  I’ll take off points if you use Times New Roman. 

  • The font should be readable, so don’t use fancy fonts. Jokerman looks good for headings and the like, but nobody wants to read a page full of the stuff.  Pick something that’s meant to be used for reading.  Suggestions are Segoe UI, Tahoma, Arial, etc.  You can use a serif font if you like, just pick something besides Times New Roman.
  • The font size should not be larger than 12 point.
  • Separate your paragraphs visually. You can do this by:
    • Using a first-line indent, like in books.
    • Add vertical spacing between paragraph (go read something on cnn.com for how this should look). You can do this by adding a margin-bottom or margin-top rules to the <p> element.  Your spacing should be about 75% - 100% the font size used for paragraphs.
  • Setting the margin property on the <body> element adjusts the margin around the edge of the window. By default every page has a margin of 15 pixels.

Set a background image

  • Go through the tutorial on CSS backgrounds at W3Schools: http://www.w3schools.com/css/css_background.asp.

Your Name (10 points)

Your name should appear at the top in a manner that it catches the eye. 

Here are some ideas:

  • Use a special font (see the “Bonus work” section, below).
  • Make the font extra-large (30pt)
  • Put an underline beneath it.
  • Have your name set in a header that uses some type of background header graphic or gradient. You can do this lots of ways. 
    • One way is to create a CSS class for <h1>, and set the background-image The background image will appear only within the rectangular space for the <h1>.
    • Instead of using an <h1>, create an image that has your name and whatever background you like. Put the <img> element at the top of your page.

Be creative!

 

Your portrait (20 points)

Here is an example of a good photo:

Notice the following:

  1. You can see the face clearly, and it looks lifelike.
  2. Not blurry.
  3. Not pixelated.
  4. No jpeg artifacts.
  5. Round things look round (not egg-shaped).
  6. Well-lit. Not too bright or dark.  Good contrast.  Not washed out.

Your portrait should not look pixelated, squashed, stretched, jpeggy, or generally messed up.  Find a basic paint program, and make friends with it.  Most of the problems I’ve seen are from trying to take a selfie from your phone (which is freaking huge) and then squashing it into a manageable size on your page. 

I will not give you an A if your photo looks like one of these:

 

Lots of jpeg compression artifacts. 

We’ve got good-quality cameras these days.  We don’t have to make do with photos that look like this.

 

Photo is stretchy. 

This is often caused by trying to fit a landscape photo into a square space.

 

 

 

 

Photo is squashed.

This is usually caused by trying to fit a portrait-sized photo into a square space.

 

Photo is pixelated.

This is usually caused by using a photo that is way too small and fitting it into a larger space.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Photo is too small.

This is a thumbnail photo.  It’s too small to make out any details.  It’s not good if you want to give your viewers an idea of what you look like.

 

Most often I see this when someone has cropped their picture out of a group photo.

 

Going overboard with the filters.

This looks fine for your facebook or your tinder profile. 

 

Here it just looks like there’s a bug in your page.  Pick a photo that uses natural color and lighting.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Photo is rotated.

Yeah, you can do better than this. 

 

Photo is badly cropped.

Your face should be fully in frame.

Incorporate your portrait into your text in a way that it accentuates uses the space on the page, instead of just looking like something you stuck there.

If you don’t know how to do this, you may try a combination of the following suggestions:

  • Center the photograph.
  • Use the float: right property to put the image on the right side of the page and have the text wrap around it. Remember that the browser will only wrap text that comes after the <img> tag.
  • Add a white (or colored) border around your picture. You can do this using the padding
  • Add a drop-shadow. W3Schools has a sample of how to do this.  Play around with it until you find a size and positioning that suites you.  http://www.w3schools.com/cssref/css3_pr_box-shadow.asp.

Your <img> element may use only the following attributes:

  • src (for obvious reasons)
  • class
  • alt
  • title

Do not use align, center, style, or any other attribute.  That’s the 90s way of doing things.  All the cool kids today use CSS.

 

Headings (10 points)

Headings should be called out visually, just like your name.

  • Use the margin property to set the space above or below each heading. If you don’t know what to do, make sure each heading has an upper margin of 75% of the heading’s font size, and a lower margin of 10%-33% of the heading’s font-size.  Do not use extra blank paragraphs or <br> elements.

 

Class schedule (25 points)

You have a lot of options here, but before you start, you really ought to head over to w3schools and look at their tutorial on CSS and tables: http://www.w3schools.com/css/css_table.asp.

In general, here is what I want to see:

  • Get rid of the border property on your <table> element. You don’t need this anymore.  If you want your table to have borders, use CSS.
  • Each of the items on your schedule should have its own background color. See the sample document for how to do this.  You can get this to work by defining a class for each item on your schedule.  In my example I used the background-color and border-color properties, and I picked a border color that was slightly darker than the background.  I also set the border-style to solid.
  • The column widths for each day of the week should be equal. You should be able to do this without adding line-breaks to the text in your <td> elements, or shortening the text.  There is a number of ways you can do this.  I got it to work by:
    • Make a CSS class for the <table> element, and set the following properties:
      • table-layout: fixed
      • width: (whatever you want. 600px-900px should be fine)
    • Make a CSS class for each <th> element, and set its width Start with 120px, and play with it till it looks good.

In addition, you can also try any combination of the following:

  • Make the header different from the rest of the table. Change the text alignment, the font colors, the background color, etc.  The default centered behavior you get with <th> almost never looks good.
  • Use the padding property to add cell padding so that the text isn’t crammed against the cell borders.
  • Get rid of cell spacing on the <table> element, by setting
    1. border-collapse: collapse;
    2. border-spacing: 0;
  • Use the border-bottom property and border-color property to draw lines across your table on each 30-minute mark. Pick a light color so that the lines are visible but not too strong.
  • Put a border around the outside of the table.
  • Tweak the horizontal or vertical alignment using the text-align and vertical-align
  • Think of something else. Be creative.
  • Add a background graphic for the entire table. You will have to play with this to get it to look right.  If this doesn’t look good, I won’t be impressed.

Just do something with your table so it looks better than this:

Extra Credit Work (20 points max)

You may do up to four of the following for up to 20 points of extra credit.  These topics are your responsibility to learn (remember, Google is your friend).

  1. (5 points) Embed your document in a centered <div> that floats over a fixed background, like so: http://forgefire.blogspot.com/. (this is easier than you think).
  2. (5 points) in your class schedule, do alternating striped colors for each row, or for each column (not both).
    1. Here’s an article on how to do that: https://www.w3.org/Style/Examples/007/evenodd.en.html.
    2. You should have a third color for the table header.
  3. (5 points) CSS3 Web Fonts. W3Schools has an in-depth article on this.
    1. You can use fancy fonts for your name at the top of the page, and for the section headings.
    2. If you do a special font for your body text, it must be a font that is easy to read. Please don’t make my eyes bleed.  No fancy script fonts, gothic-style fonts, etc.
  4. (10 points) If you click on your portrait, have a larger version appear in a modal <div> (like what Facebook or Twitter does). You’ll need JavaScript to do this, but if you search the web you can find lots of examples on how to do this.  Requirements:
    1. There should be a close-box in the upper left.
    2. Clicking the close box or clicking anywhere outside the image should make the modal <div> disappear.
    3. While the modal <div> is visible, the page in the background should appear darkened or blurred.
  5. (10 points) artistic merit. Wow me.  Think outside the box with the page’s layout, do something totally bold.
    1. Put each section in its own floating div. Have each div offset from the left margin or centered horizontally.
    2. Make use of side-bars
    3. Have a header that stays fixed on the page.
    4. It can’t just be one thing (that’s what we call a gimmick). Totally re-arrange your paradigm, but above all, make it attractive.

 

Turning in your assignment

Please submit the following:

1. Zip File:  Put your .html file, your .css file, and all images and any other resources into a .zip file, and upload them to canvas.

2. Netlify URL:   

Please upload your site to Netlify and post your URL into a comment in your submission.  If you haven't done that before, see these instructions:

Hosting your own Web Site on Netlify

3. Your Self Grade

Review the rubric and give yourself a grade for each section.  Feel free to make additional comments clarifications

Add a comment on your site using the following format:

--SELF GRADE--
BODY        A / B / C / D / E
NAME        A / B / C / D / E
PORTRAIT    A / B / C / D / E
HEADINGS    A / B / C / D / E
SCHEDULE    A / B / C / D / E

--EXTRA CREDIT COMPLETED--
FLOATING DIV (5pts)    YES/NO
STRIPED TABLE (5pts)   YES/NO
MODAL PORTRAIT (10pts) YES/NO
ARTISTIC MERIT (10pts) YES/NO (Add description of what you did)
ADDITIONAL COMMENTS

Example:

Here’s an example of what Professor Abbott did:

• DESIGN & PREP

    • Before you start coding spend a bit of time conceptualizing and designing your profile:

      • Choose an interesting topic of interest that will allow you to be creative
      • Remember and use the design principles you have learned this semester
      • Create a 'low definition prototype' of your web site
        • This can be made using
          • 3x5 or 5x7 postcards
          • Wireframe drawings on 8.5x11 sheets of paper
            • 'Wireframe' just means rough sketches.
          • Use Adobe XD to create an electronic wireframe or clickable prototype of your app.
          • drawing program of any sort
        • Your wireframes should convey the overall layout and interaction and flow of your site, including:
          • Wireframes showing home page layout
          • At least one wireframe indicating how your site may be responsive at a tablet level
          • Menu structure (links, buttons, tabs)
          • Structure of detail pages
          • How and where you will include pictures and videos
          • Annotations and clarifications where needed, for example, notate some of the css effects or animations you might create (draw borders, shadows etc.).your design should communicate

      • I've uploaded a few examples of a web site design (low def prototype) from a previous class.  Check them out for ideas!

        The are in our Files->Assignments->P3a-Responsive Web Site-Design->Low Def Prototype Examples folder

Submission

  • photo(s) of your paper or manual design, OR output from your design tool (image or pdf...)
  • If multiple images or pdfs, please attach individually so we can easily review them in speed grader.

Grading

  • Note:  Don't worry about making a full blown design, you will flesh out a lot of details as you build your site.  This is 'High Level'
    • I don't expect this exercise to take more than 1 - 2 hrs
    • If you have a good crack at it you will do well.  If you turn in a few scribbles that don't convey anything, you will get punished.
  • The included rubric is fairly simple and your grade will reflect the   degree to which you have conveyed the 'Overall layout, interaction and flow of your site'.

assignment_name: Project 3-Responsive Web Site-Topic of your Choice
description:
Project 3-Responsive Web Site-Topic of your Choice

This project will allow you to build a responsive web site using all of the skills you have learned thus far.

The theme of this web site is your choice.  Choose a theme or interest of yours that has plenty of content and that would allow you to utilize plenty of CSS skills.  You can let your imagination run wild.

  • WEB SITE ELEMENTS -  site should include the following elements:
    • Overall Layout  (Required)

      • Use CSS Grid and Flexbox for your overall layout, columns, rows, alignment etc.  It is a best practice to use CSS Grid for your overall layout, and Flexbox for layout within the site containers.

      • HTML 5 Semantic Tags for your entire layout: 

        • main, header, section, article, nav, aside, footer, figure, figcaption, detail

        • I recommend you start with just the main container tags for your application and then add content after they are placed and working as you desire.  Put a background and border on them so you can visualize your layout as you put your CSS Grid and Flexbox containers together.
    • Home Page  (Required)
      • Home page gives a nice one page display of your topic of interest
      • Should include:
        • At least four different areas on the page, e.g, 
          • header
          • Menu (aside)
          • Main Content
          • Footer
    • Header (Required)
      • Should have an image/logo and a title of some sort.
      • You could place your menu in the header if you so choose.
    • Menu (Required)
      • Create a menu and place it in a <nav> element in either the header, or an aside to left of main content
        • This could be a menu which uses  'pills' (buttons), or just plain <a> links.  
        • Menu can be vertical or horizontal
        • Menu has a minimum of three links to different 'sections' of your site, for example:
          • Home -  Link which shows your Home Page content
          • Contact - Link which shows your contact information
          • ???   - link to pages which might contain more detailed information and subsections of your site
          • Menu actions will hide/show the different sections each whose main content is in tab-panes', one at a time.
    • Section Content
      • Hiding/Showing Content (Required)
        • Implement implement each section of your site into separate <section> elements
          • Hide all of the elements except for the 'Home' page using the 'display:none' style
        • These are likely contained in <section> tags  One will be set to 'display:none' to start off with.   
        • You will use javascript to hide and show these sections as you click on the menu items or pills.
      • Images
        • Your page must contain images (required) 
          • At least one with a caption
            • You should enclose this in a 'Figure' html5 tag, which also includes a figcaption tag.  (required) (-2 if missing)
            • Extra Credit  (+2) Utilize a 'picture' tag with child 'source' tags which show different images based on media query.
      • Video (required) 
        • Embed videos of interest on  your topic
    • Overall Considerations
      • Responsiveness (Desktop/Tablet)
        • Your CSS Grid and  flexbox layout and css should make your profile look nice on both a large desktop as well as a tablet.
        • Use media queries to optimize layout at smaller/tablet size (approximately 768 pixels wide)
      • Styling
        • You should utilize your CSS skills to make your site LOOK NICE!   Use colors, gradients, background images, drop shadows,  images, icons etc. to enhance the look and feel of your site.
  • Rubric
    • See below rubric for details
    • Extra Credit Opportunities
      • Use animate.css, straight CSS, or javascript to create at least two pleasing animations (+2)
      • Use fontawesome icons in your implementation (+2)
      • Extra Credit  (+2) Utilize a 'picture' tag with child 'source' tags which show different images based on media query.

Deliverables:
.zip file with

  • root directory including your index.html
  • main.css file in the /css directory
  • main.js file in the /js directory
  • images you might use in /img directory
  • videos (DO NOT INCLUDE!)

Netlify Deploy

Deploy your web site on Netlify or GitHub pages (see this guide). 

    • Submit your URL as a comment on your submission.

assignment_name: Project 4-Responsive Web Site-CSS Theme and Refactor
description:
NOTE (11/4):  While you will turn this in a week earlier,  I will grade both this and Project 5 together over the Thanksgiving break.

This project consists of modifying your Project 3 page as follows:

Refactor CSS-Fix (20 pts)

  • Refactor and fix layout issues pointed out in your last submission.  
    • Fix alignment, Grid/Flexbox layout and another CSS issues pointed out by the grader, or any you noticed.
    • If you are using CSS Grid and Flexbox, allow them to do the 'work'.  Don't go setting floats, heights etc. that may interfere.
    • Make any improvements you wish to make to improve look and feel of site
  • Organize and document your CSS file
  • Make sure it is in a subfolder:
    • css/main.css
  • Enter a comment at the top of the main.css page indicating the changes that you addressed

CSS Theme (40pts)

  • Once your CSS styles are cleaned up and under control
  • Create a style sheet that overrides your main.css and gives your site a new 'theme'.
    • This theme should 'substantially' modify the look and feel of the page, not just change a few colors.
    • Ideas:
      • change your css grid layout, moving a menu from left to right
      • change css styles, colors, fonts, background image, gradients etc.
      • change animations to show a different effect or direction
      • create a 'Dark' or 'Light' theme
    • You override style sheet should only override the styles that you wish to modify.  DO NOT REPEAT tags that are not modified.
    • For basic understanding of CSS Overrides/Themes
      • See this REPL: ResponsiveBandWebPageWithTheme
  • Enter a comment at the top of the theme css file indicating the changes that you made

Apply/Toggle Theme (10pts)

  • You will not be applying the theme by default.  You will need to press a link or button to enable it
  • Create a button or link on your site  and attach a click event callback that will:
    • Insert a new 'link' element at the bottom of the head tag referring to your new theme stylesheet ('myThemeName.css')
    • This will override the styles in your main.css file, which should not be changed or removed!
    • How do you place a stylesheet into the  end of your head tag? (See this stackoverflow discussion)  
    • EXTRA CREDIT:   
      • Make the link or button a 'toggle' which will switch back and forth between original site and new theme.  +4 pts

Turning in your assignment

Make sure you document the changes you made at the top both the main.css and theme.css files.  Don't make us guess!!

Please submit the following:

1. Zip File:  Put your .html file, your .css file, and all images and any other resources into a .zip file, and upload them to canvas.

2. Netlify URL:   

Please upload your site to Netlify and post your URL into a comment in your submission. 

Hosting your own Web Site on Netlify

3. Your Self Grade

Review the rubric and give yourself a grade for each section.  Feel free to make additional comments clarifications

Add a comment on your site using the following format:

--SELF GRADE--
REFACTOR CSS-FIX       A / B / C / D / E
CSS THEME                     A / B / C / D / E
CSS THEME TOGGLE     A / B / C / D / E

EXTRA CRED(Toggle)      A / B / C / D / E

ADDITIONAL COMMENTS

assignment_name: Project 5-Personal Web Site-Visitor Form Validation-Refactor JS
description:
Project 5-Personal Web Site-Visitor Form Validation-Refactor JS

In this assignment, you will

  • Use CssGrid/FlexBox and javascript to create a 'Visitor' form in which to register site visitors. 
  • You will launch this form similar to your other windows, using a 'hidden' section and menu item called 'Log Visit'.   
  • You will validate the form entries before 'saving' (we will not save data in this version). 
  • You will hide the form and display a thank you message upon submission.
  • You will document and clean up file structure for your JS Code

Include the following in this iteration:

Refactor JS-Fix and Document (15 pts)

  • Refactor and fix any javascript issues pointed out in your last submission.  
    • If you did not have a single page in which you hide/show each section of content (e.g., you created multiple pages)
      • Please refactor  your code so that you are doing so.  contact me if you need more info on this.  
      • also, see Project 3 spec
  • Organize and document your JS Files
  • Make sure it is in a subfolder:
    • js/main.js
    • js/validation.js
    • js/page.js    /* perhaps put your page switching and theme code here in a  separate file */
  • Enter a comment at the top of the main.js  page indicating the changes that you addressed
  • Make sure you add a code header/disclaimer indicating that you wrote your own code.

Visitor Form Validation (70 pts)

  • TEMPLATE
    • I've provided a starting template here for a visitor form.  I've given you the full outline of the code and left you different pieces to implement.
      • Refer to the comments with 'TODO' to see what items you need to implement.
      • This template has been provided as an example you can look at and use for this project.  Resist the urge to just copy and paste this code.  I would like you to write every line of code yourself in your own project and understand what you are writing!
        Make the form I provided, which is ugly by design, look much better!
  • You may also refer to the following Repls for help.
    • Basic Form Validation-OnChange(Javascript)
    • Any other repls referred to in the form module.  
  • Other references that could be useful
    • Example Flexbox forms
  • Start by making a copy of your Personal Web Site.  You will be enhancing the site.
  • Create your Visitor Registration Form, which may include the following elements:
    • FlexBox Form Layout
      • Implement Form using flexbox styles for layout purposes (required). 
      • Make it look much better than my template!
    • Log Visit Button
      • Add a menu item or button to your web site page that opens the form in a hidden section just like I had you do in the last project
    • Visitor Form
      • Your form should contain the following elements
          • Personal Information Section
            • First, Last name  (req, validate using 'checkRequired' function)
            • Address
              • Address (req, validate using 'checkRequired' function)     
              • City (req, validate using 'checkRequired' function)
              • State (min/max two chars)  (req, validate using 'checkRequired' function)
                • Custom validation in JS required to check if value is in a list of states (included in template)
              • Zip  (req, custom validation using javascript regex, 'checkFormat' function in validation.js)
              • Cell Phone  (req, custom validation using javascript regex, 'checkFormat' function in validation.js)
              • Email Address (req, custom validation using javascript regex, 'checkFormat' function in validation.js)
          • How did you find my page?  (req, validate using 'checkRequired' function)
            • Checkbox Group - E.g., Internet, Friend, Google...
            • Custom Validation using javascript. At least one must be selected
          • Text Area for Comments   (optional)
          • Submit Button
            • Use a button with id="submitBtn" type='submit', this will cause 'submit' event to fire
    • Validation Library
      • Create a javascript file, e.g., js/validate.js...  This will serve as your validation library.
        • You can utilize the validation.js in the template, but type all of the code yourself, understanding it and testing it as you go
        • Include your javascript library in your html file
        • Place your main entry point in main.js (include main.js in your index.html, below the validation.js!): 
          • document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", function(event) {    
               initValidation("#myform");
});
        • Your "initValidation" function should:
          • Set up validation event callbacks
            • onSubmit - Capture submit event and validate the whole form.
              • Make sure you prevent the default event as well as event bubbling
              • You can check whether a form is 'valid' you may use the DOM function
                • form.checkValidity()   //returns false if any input is invalid
            • onChange - for a given element, as the person exits the field,  validate the element and display a custom message.
        • Field Validation
          • Your form tag should have a 'novalidate' attribute so that the default submit validation will not occur.
          • All Validation will be done using Javascript for this project.  I've stubbed out the following functions in the JS to accomplish this.  See the 'TODO' markers in the template to know what to do
            • validateForm()
              • Runs all of the tests (already stubbed out for you)
            • checkRequired(fieldId, RequiredMessage)
              • Checks if field has a value, or checkbox group has a checked element
              • used for all required fields (first, last, address,etc)
            • checkFormat(fieldId, BadFormatMessage, regex)
              • Check the 'value' of an input against a regex
              • Regex expressions are found at top of validation.js
              • for the 'phoneRegex'-go to regexer.com or reg101.com and find a suitable phone number regex and use that
              • See this regex text repl for examples
            • validateState(fieldId, InvalidMessage)
              • check if the value of the field is in the 'stateAbbreviations' array at the top of validation.js in the template.
            • setElementValidity(id, valid, message)
              • Uses setCustomValidity to set the ':valid' and ':invalid' properties on an input.
                • These properties can be used in CSS to show red or green borders, error messages etc.
              • inserts message in the error div just below the input 
                • <li >
                     <label for="email">Email</label>
                     <input type="text" id="email" name="email" class='was-validated' placeholder="Enter your email here">
                     <div class="errorMsg"></div>
                  </li>
            • Using CSS rules, you can style inputs based on the pseudo classes as follows
              • Remember you must add the 'was-validated' class to an input for the errors to show (see above, this class is added using javascript): 
                  • /*only show error information when 'was-validated' class is added to the input*/
                    input.was-validated:invalid {
                      color: red;
                      border: 1px solid red;
                    }

                    input.was-validated:invalid ~ div {
                      display: block;
                    }
                    /* hide all error divs 
                    ~ is the general sibling selector and selects 'div' siblings of the input*/
                    input:valid ~ div {
                      display: none;
                    }

                    input:invalid ~ div {
                      display: none;
                    }
      • General Rules
        • Fields should be validated 'onChange' (tab out or exit of input after field has changed). 
        • An error message should be displayed below the input if input has error.
        • If field is Valid we should indicate with red or green colored border
        • When submit button is clicked,  validation is performed on the whole form.
          • If form is valid, hide the form and display a thank you message.
          • If form is invalid,
            • mark the fields as invalid (css), and show the error message below the field. (just like you do onChange)
    • Overall Considerations
      • Responsiveness (Desktop/Tablet)
        • Your grid/flexbox layout and css should make your profile and new form look nice on both a large desktop as well as a tablet size
        • Extra Credit:  make your form mobile responsive (+3)
      • Styling
        • You should utilize your CSS skills to make your form LOOK NICE!   Use colors, gradients, background images, drop shadows,  images, icons etc. to enhance the look and feel of your form.
        • You should modify your 'Theme' from Project 4 to apply theme to your form
    • Rubric
      • See included rubric for grading criteria.

  • Make sure you document the changes you made at the top both the main.css and theme.css files.  Don't make us guess!!
