The test is held in class.

Identify the class of each of the following IP addresses (A/B/C), and specify the number of bytes allocated for the network and host parts of these addresses:

  • 128.36.199.3 
  • 21.12.240.17 
  • 183.194.76.253 
  • 192.12.69.248 
  • 89.3.0.1 
  • 200.3.6.2

B.  Give an explanation for why IP does reassembly at the destination host rather than within routers. (4 points)

 

C. Suppose that a TCP message containing 2048 bytes of application data and a 20 byte TCP header is passed down to IP for delivery across two networks (from the source host to a router to the destination host).  The message, as it is passed down from TCP to IP, would look like this:

                 (Original TCP Message)

 

The first network crossed has an MTU (frame payload maximum) of 4096 bytes; the second network has a 1024 byte MTU.  Each network’s MTU determines the maximum sized IP packet that can be transmitted, including the IP header (but not including the frame header).  

 

Give the sizes and offsets for the sequence of IP packet fragments delivered up to the IP layer at the destination host.  Give the offset as an actual byte count (not the mod 8 value).  Assume that all IP headers are 20 bytes, and be careful when calculating the offset value (the Offset field in the IP header).  You may find it helpful to draw a picture of each fragment to visualize it.  You may also wish to refer to the Lecture 2 slide titled “Rules for Sizing Fragments”.  (6 points)

55.  Suppose a router has built the forwarding table shown below. The router can deliver packets directly to the final destination over interfaces 0 and 1, or it can forward packets to routers R2, R3, or R4. Describe what the router does with a packet addressed to each of the following destinations:

  1. 128.96.39.10
  2. 128.96.40.12
  3. 128.96.40.151
  4. 192.4.153.17
  5. 192.4.153.90

 

Table 4.14  Routing table for Exercise 21:

 

D.  Assume that an Internet Service Provider has assigned the IPv4 network address 162.247.0.0 to a business.

  1. What is the default subnet mask for this address?
  2. What is the shortest subnet mask (fewest 1-bits) that would be appropriate if the business needed to use 9 subnets?  Show this mask in both dotted decimal and “slash” notation.
  3. What is the maximum number of hosts that could be used on each of those 9 subnets?

E. For the network shown in the figure below, build the combined distance-vector tables like those in Tables 3.10 (slide 5-10) and 3.13    in the text…

(a) before the distance-vector algorithm runs.  (Initially, each router knows only the distances to its immediate neighbors.)

(b) after node E communicates its distance-vector (routing table)  information to B.  (Assume that no distance-vector information has been communicated between any other nodes at this point.)

(c) after all nodes have received all available distance-vector information about all other nodes (convergence has occurred).

For the Ch3 HW 48 problem, please complete the following steps

  1. Using the tree method.  Show the tree at the end of each step. 
  2. Using the table method.  Create a table that shows (for each node):
    1. The total distance from node D
    2. The next node (via)

The main difference between the methods

  • the first method shows all possible known nodes as dashed-possibilities and picks the shortest one (making the selection a solid line)
  • the second method always picks the next node by selecting the next destination node with the next shortest total distance from the source node to next destination node, but ignores nodes that aren't the next shortest total distance

Like we discussed at the end of class, if two nodes have the same next shortest total distance from source node, just pick one.  Both methods will generate the same optimal outcome (shortest total distances from a source node to all other nodes) regardless of which of the equal total distance nodes that you pick next.

  1. For the network given in Figure 3.53, show how Dijkstra's shortest-path algorithm builds the routing table for node D. Create a routing database (table) similar to Table 3.14 on page 258. (You may find it more useful to number the steps as listed in the algorithm on page 257.) Illustrate the progression of the algorithm using Radia Perlman’s technique as illustrated on slides 7-8 through 7-14.  Draw one tree for each pass through the algorithm.  After each iteration, also create the resulting routing table (similar to the routing table on slide 7-14).  The tree for the first pass is shown below.  The tables and trees may be drawn by hand and scanned or photographed for submission to Canvas.  (10 points)

 

Please also use the greedy algorithm (at the end of the first pass is shown below):

a b c d e f
Cost (Distance) 0 2
Next Hop (Via) D E

1. Give the big-endian and little-endian representation for the decimal integers shown below. Show the results in binary form with the lowest memory address on the left, and assume a 32-bit field in all cases. (See slide 14-17).

 

    1. 101
    2. 10,120
    3. 16,909,060

 

A.  Determine the memory byte order for the following architectures: Motorola MC68000, Sun SPARC, Intel Pentium, AIM PowerPC, AMD Athlon II, Intel Itanium and ARMv8. Hint: there is a third alternative to big-endian and little-endian not mentioned in the lecture.

Give the ASN.1 transfer syntax encoding for the following data types and values.  Show integer data values in hex (not binary) format and show characters as text characters.  Assume that the integer value is stored in a 4-byte field.  Use Figures 7.7 and 7.8 on p. 590 and the relevant Lecture 15 slides as a guide. (10 points)

  1. a) The integer 10,120
  2. b) The ASCII text string “Text”
  3. c) A SEQUENCE containing the data items in (a) and (b), as follows:

 

     Part-c ::=

         SEQUENCE {

             myint INTEGER ::= 10120,

             mytext IA5String ::= "Text"

         }

C. Encode the following sequence of decimal integer byte values using Base64 encoding:
248, 22, 172, 123, 174, 62. Show the resulting 6-bit integer values and corresponding
text characters from the Base64 lookup table. Tables are available at http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2045.txt (page 25) or
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Base64#Examples. (Hint: if you get it right, it will be obvious.)

D.  Given the following data sample, calculate the entropy (n) of the circumscribed-x symbol.  If a fixed-length 8-bit-per-symbol encoding scheme is used for the uncompressed data, what is the efficiency of the original 8-bit code for the circumscribed-x symbol?  (Here, we'll define the "efficiency" to be the ratio of the bit length of the most efficient representation (the entropy) to the bit length of the symbol in its uncompressed form.  This is the inverse of the compression ratio.) (5 points)   

E.  Consider a photo image to be transmitted over a 56Kbps link. (Assume 1K = 1000). JPEG can compress a typical photo image at a ratio of approximately 30:1.  JPEG compression is typically done well before transmission, but for this question, we’ll assume that we are trying to determine whether it is worth compressing the image immediately before transmission, as part of the overall transmission process. 

Using the formula presented on page 599 of the text (Bc > ( r/(r - 1) ) x Bn) and a 30:1 compression ratio, determine the "break even" point for the “bandwidth” of the compression process Bc (in bps), at which compression becomes worthwhile.  (5 points)

Points
10

F. Using the Huffman-related slides from lecture 18 as a guide, construct a Huffman Tree for the following weighted symbol set.  Show the Huffman Tree and the corresponding table of codes for each symbol.  (Before constructing the tree, sort the symbols by weight.)  (5 points)

G. 

 Using the slide titled “Two Simple Run Length Encoding Algorithms” as a model, RLE encode each of the following symbol streams using both Variants 1 and 2.  Show the resulting data stream and the compression ratio in each case.  Express the data stream in characters and decimal integer count values (not in bits).  Assume that the <esc> and the integer counts require one byte each.  Aside from the question of compression ratios, what advantage does Variant 1 have over Variant 2?  (5 points)a)

        a) AAAAAABBBBBBCCCCCCDDDDDD 

        b) AAAABBBBBCCCDDDD

        c) AAABBBCCCDDD

Use LZW to compress the string allallysally.  Show the completed code table and output stream.  (10 points)

  Beginning of the code table:  Beginning of the output stream:

   #1 = a     #1 (a)

   #2 = l     #2 (l)

   #3 = y     #2 (l)

   #4 = s       ...

     ...

Assume that a DCT output matrix contains the AC coefficient 49, and that the corresponding value in the quantization table is 8.  (10 points)

a)What is it’s the quantized value of that AC coefficient?

  1. b) What is its value after being decompressed?
  2. c) Use the formula (original value ¸ decompressed value) - 1 to express the resulting error (loss).
J. The frequency of I frames in the MPEG stream defines the granularity (meaning accuracy or level of detail) of any fast-forward or reverse functions. Explain why.

B.  Using slides titled “The RSA Algorithm” as a model, apply the RSA algorithm using the following values: p = 3, q = 17, e = 3 and m = 13.  Select an appropriate value for d and determine the corresponding cipher text value c.  Decrypt the cipher text message to verify that the value for c is correct.  Show your work.  (10 points)

The test covers slides (lectures) 1-9.

Note: You are allowed to use one page note sheet. You can use online scientific calculator.

This test covers slides 10 - 20 inclusive (the rest of chapter 5 and everything in chapter 7 up to and including LZW compression).  The test covers programming projects 1-3.  You need to understand what the functions are (like recv, sendto, connect, etc.); However, you don't have to memorize either function parameters or parameter data types.  The test covers homework assignments Chapter 7 home work problems #9 and A-H inclusive.  The test covers quizzes 3-4.

Please use the student lecture notes!!!  Read through the lecture notes, make a mental model of what the lecture notes cover, then look at that facet's slide(s) and compare the slides to your mental model.  Also, be sure that you understand the exact steps for the homework and can do them repeatedly without looking at the notes or slides! 

Finally, when something doesn't match, you need to review the lecture notes again, ask a classmate, ask the TA, or ask the professor.  We will start by asking you how you think it works, so that we clarify inconsistencies and don't waste your time reteaching material you already mastered. 

Please read all possible answers carefully before selecting the best choice and double check your answers.  There are 34 questions, weighted at 6 points each, for a total of 204 possible points.

Books and notes are not allowed.  Scratch paper and all types of calculators are permitted.  A translation dictionary is allowed for international students. Also, you can use a 1-page note sheet that contains essential formulas or concepts that you can not remember.  

Good Luck.

This is an open book and open note exam. This exam is worth 204 possible points toward your final grade.  There are 24 multiple-choice questions, weighted at 6 points each (144 possible points).  Three short essay questions are worth 20 points each (60 possible points).

 All types of calculators are permitted.  You may use blank scratch paper.  A translation dictionary is allowed for international students.

This form may be submitted at or before the final exam.  You may take this quiz/survey as many times as you want, but only the latest submission will be used.  The resulting adjustment will not be posted to Canvas until after all other scores have been posted, including your final exam.

Take a look at your homework, lab exercise and programming assignments scores in Canvas (this voucher cannot be applied to quizzes or tests).  Each homework assignment is worth 1.1% of your final grade.  Each lab exercise is worth 2.5%.  Each programming assignment is worth 3.3%.  This voucher will allow you to receive full credit for one chosen homework assignment or one lab exercise (1 – 3 only) or one programming assignment.

Note: For getting full points using the Gimme-a-break voucher, an updated/corrected version submission for the chosen assignment is NOT mandatory.  However, you are encouraged to submit an updated version.

You may find this article helpful:

PearlOverview.pdf 

For this assignment you are being asked to write a short 1-page report explaining the basic notation of causal graphs and how they represent the data generating process.

You may find this article helpful

PearlOverview-1.pdf 

For this assignment you are being asked to write a short, 1-page report about 1. identification in statistics in general, 2. identification in economics regarding causal inference, and 3. what Pearl means by identification (see Definition 2 of the linked-to paper).

You may find the following article helpful:

PearlOverview-2.pdf .

For this assignment you are being asked to write a short, 1-page report on admissible sets (the back door criterion), see Definition 3 of the linked-to-paper.
Complete the following questions. Note that you only have one attempt to complete this quiz. There is a time limit of 30 minutes.

This assignment deals with mutually supporting strands of evidence.  

Read the following article written by Paul Rosenbaum.

RosenbaumMutuallySupportingStrandsOfEvidence-1.pdf 

Then proceed to upload a one page report that describes a real world context where causal inference was successful and widely accepted by society. Try to emphasize some of the points that Rosenbaum makes in his article.

Regards,

Brian

This homework involves natural experiments and randomization inference.

Start by reading Chapters 1 and 2 of this book by Rosenbaum:

NaturalExperimentsAndRandomizationInference-1.pdf 

For your homework you may do any one of the following:

1. Find a natural experiment of your own and write about it. You may describe what you read somewhere in the media, but if you do try to track down the original scientific article(s) that any media reports are based on. Submit a one page report.

2. Simulate randomization inference within R. You may use the examples provided by Rosenbaum in Chapter 2. Try to connect this with AB testing if you can.

3. Study this paper, written by your instructor and others, https://arxiv.org/abs/2103.05692 . Comment on whether you think randomization inference can be generalized to the observational study setting or not. Submit a one page summary of what you learned.

Regards,

Brian

This assignment deals with quasi-experimental devices. The specific device we will study carefully is that of a second control group. The broader context is that of covariate selection.

Start by carefully reading this paper: SamSecondControlGroups.pdf .

To complete this assignment you may do any one of the following options.

1. Conduct simulations by making data generating processes to see if it is or is not reasonable to be cautious about adjusting for some types of pre-treatment covariates. You may include M bias in your analysis if you'd like. See https://arxiv.org/abs/1408.0324 .

2. Write a report about "matching" in statistics. You can find some relevant reading in Part 2 of that book by Rosenbaum:

Matching.pdf 

3. Do some research and describe an additional quasi-experimental device (besides second control groups) that you find compelling. A one page report should suffice.

Regards,

Brian

Rosenbaum says that sensitivity analysis may warrant causal inference, but what is a sensitivity analysis? Perhaps a good place to start is the following paper by Ding and VanderWeele. Here is a link:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4820664/ .

However, this assignment is more about bridging gaps between causal graphs and the causal inferential frameworks of Rubin and Rosenbaum. Note that Rosenbaum's framework for sensitivity analysis can be found in Section 3.4 of his book. See RoseBook.pdf . 

The following may greatly interest you. It is a paper by VanderWeele that combines the covariate selection issue with causal graphs. Here is a link: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3166439/ .

Finally, we arrive at the main topic of study this week; incorporation of time into the analysis. Here is a paper from the 1980s that introduced some important ideas. RobinsOriginalPaper.pdf . Note that Robins was VanderWeele's PhD advisor at Harvard.

This is a challenging week with much to study, so make sure you attend class, ask questions, and plan head. You are being asked to write a one page report about how time information can be incorporated into analyses for causal inference. 

Regards,

Brian

PS Here are two additional links that may help: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Granger_causality , https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proportional_hazards_model .

PPS In case this is helpful: https://github.com/kathoffman/causal-inference-visual-guides/blob/master/visual-guides/G-Computation.pdf . See also https://scholar.harvard.edu/sites/scholar.harvard.edu/files/shephard/files/cause20170718.pdf .

This assignment deals with interaction. We will study this paper by VanderWeele:

VanderWeeleInteractionPaper.pdf

You are being asked to write a short 1-page report on why it is important to consider interaction for the purpose of causal inference.

Regards,

Brian

This homework assignment deals with the concepts of mediation and mechanism in causal inference. Please carefully read the following article by VanderWeele:

VanderWeeleMediationAndMechanism.pdf .

Write a one-page report that compares and contrasts the concepts of mediation and mechanism. Be sure to include numerous concrete examples to demonstrate that you understand. These examples should be your own (i.e. thought of on your own, not looked up somewhere online).

Regards,

Brian
Please complete the following. You must work alone.

Here you are being asked to do one of the following three options for your final project.

1. As with Dagitty (see http://www.dagitty.net ) you are being asked to implement the back door criterion of Pearl (see PearlOverview-3.pdf ). You must on your computer construct an algorithm that takes a causal graph (a directed, acyclic graph, implemented as say an adjacency matrix), with labels for the treatment/exposure and the outcome/response along with covariates, and then the algorithm will output a list of minimal sufficient sets of covariates for unbiased adjustment. See the minimum sufficient adjustment sets in Dagitty (found in the upper right corner) for concrete insight. 

2. Conduct statistical simulations to assess the seriousness of this M bias concern. Ding and Miratrix have this paper https://arxiv.org/abs/1408.0324 . Pearl responded with this comment: PearlComment.pdf . Who is right, and why? Conduct simulations to find out.

3. (Difficult) Theoretically develop principles to guide selection of interventions on a causal graph using the graph, details contained within the data, and other details (e.g. random assignment of a variable or low cost of an intervention) as required.

For credit you must present evidence to your instructor that you completed one of the three tasks described above sometime before the due date.

Regards,

One of the things an assembler has to do is take assembly language instructions (like ADD, AND, and JMP) and convert those into binary opcodes. Each assembly instruction has a corresponding 4-bit binary opcode. For example, the binary opcode for ADD is 0001, for AND it's 0101, and for JMP it's 1100.

Write an LC-3 assembly language program that does the following:

  1. Output a message to the screen that prompts the user to type in an LC-3 assembly language instruction (like ADD). The user ends their input by pressing Enter/Return.
  2. If the instruction typed by the user is a legal LC-3 assembly language instruction, your program displays the corresponding 4-bit opcode. For example, if the user types "ADD", the program would print out "0001".
  3. If the instruction typed by the user is not a legal LC-3 assembly language instruction (for example,  "ADDD"), your program displays an appropriate error message.
  4. After displaying the output, your program loops back to the top, reinitializes anything that needs to be reinitialized, and goes again.
  5. Your program will exit when the user types the string "QUIT" and presses Enter/Return.

Note: Your program must treat input as case insensitive, meaning that the user can type their input in any combination of upper and lower case. For example, "ADD", "add",  and "AdD" would all be legal instructions.

Note: As the user types an instruction, your program should echo each typed character to the monitor so they can see what they're typing.

Note: You can process characters as the user enters them or you can store them away and process them after the user hits the Return or Enter key. If you process characters as they are entered, you still have to wait until after the user hits Return/Enter before you give an error response, even if you already know it's not a valid instruction.

Note: The algorithm you use for processing the text has to use a state machine. If the user types an 'A', you move to the A State. In the A State you check to see if the next character is either 'N' or 'D'. Anything else would be an error. If the next characer is an 'N' you move to the AN State. In the AN State you check the next character. If it's a 'D' you move to the AND State, otherwise it's an error. In the AND State, the next character has to be the CR or LF character, otherwise it's an error. Etc., etc. Rinse and repeat for all valid instructions.

Note: For the BR instruction, you only need to handle "BR", not the  variants  ("BRn", "BRz", "BRp", "BRnz", "BRzp", "BRnp", "BRnzp").

Note: Write your program in a text editor (not a word processor!) and save the file as you go.  Every time you need to assemble and load the file into the Simulator you can just drag the file onto the assembler. The reason you shouldn't use a word processor (like Word) is that word processors put a bunch of non-ASCII junk into a document file. Plus they do things like smart quotes, which look like regular quotes but have a different underlying value, so the assembler doesn't interpret it correctly.

Submit your code as a .asm file (a .asm file is just a text file with the extension ".asm").

Overview

For this assignment, you will explore the internal operations of the xv6 operating system and record your findings in Canvas. You will create the source code for a new userspace program named assn1 and add it to the xv6 build system. You will use the debugger to see the kernel source code in operation. You will also examine variables in a running system. Changes you make to files will be added, committed, and pushed via git to your upstream repository for grading.

Notes on the Assignment Specifications

This is a long assignment and reads a lot like a tutorial. You should expect to do a lot of reading. If something has gone wrong and your results do not match the assignment, go back and try again. You will occasionally encounter call-outs like this:

Important concepts can be found in these call-outs. You really want to understand what is intended by these call-outs. If you do not understand the concept, you will want to ask questions on MSTeams.

Objectives

The objectives for this assignment are:

  • Successfully build and run the xv6 operating system within the provided Docker container which includes:
    • Installing Docker. Frankly this will likely be the hardest part of the assignment
    • Launching the jjolly/xv6 Docker container image
    • Building and running xv6 with the make qemu and make qemu-gdb commands
    • Exiting the qemu emulator with Ctrl-a, x
  • Demonstrate your ability to write a basic C program by adding a userspace program to the xv6 source code:
    • Create a working xv6 userspace program in the source code file user/assn1.c.
    • Write a program in C
    • Add the new program to the list of userspace programs in the Makefile
  • Understand how to debug xv6, set breakpoints, and examine system state using GDB commands which includes:
    • Starting and stopping the operating system within the debugger
    • Stepping over and into instructions using the GDB s and n commands
    • Setting and disabling breakpoints with the GDB b and d commands
    • Printing and examining data within the xv6 OS with the GDB p and x commands

Part A: Setup of Docker

For all assignments this semester you will be using the xv6 docker container that I have created. You can find the container in Docker Hub and the Dockerfile used to create the image in GitHub. In order to use this container you need a working installation of Docker. This task will depend on the system you are running on:

Linux

Nearly all Linux distributions have a package for Docker. For Ubuntu this package name is docker.io. Fedora has instruction for installing the docker-ce package. Installing on openSUSE can be done via YaST or installing the docker package. Other distributions have instructions that can be found via a Google search. Ultimately you should be able to perform the following from the command line:

$ docker version

Client: Docker Engine - Community
 Cloud integration: v1.0.22
 Version:           20.10.11

...

Server: Docker Engine - Community
 Engine:
  Version:          20.10.11
  API version:      1.41 (minimum version 1.12)

...

and

$ docker run --rm hello-world

...

Hello from Docker!
This message shows that your installation appears to be working correctly.

...

Windows

I would recommend installing Windows Subsystem for Linux 2 along with Docker Desktop. You can find help in the installation video found in the module videos page.

You can also install a virtual machine manager such as Oracle VirtualBox or VMWare Workstation. This will allow you to install a distribution of Linux. You may then follow any of the Linux installation instructions as mentioned above. Details can also be found in the module videos page.

MacOS

You may install the official Docker Desktop and run docker commands from the terminal.

Running xv6 in Docker

Once you have determined that Docker runs for you, starting the xv6 Docker container on Linux should be a one-command task.

$ docker run --tty --interactive --name xv6 --hostname xv6 --volume $HOME:$HOME jjolly/xv6

The options for this command are:

  • --tty: You wish to see the console output of Docker. You can shorten this to -t
  • --interactive: You wish to interact (provide input) to the Docker console. You can shorten this to -i
  • --name xv6: Instead of some randomly-generated name, you may wish your container to have a specific name, such as xv6
  • --hostname xv6: You may wish to assign the internal hostname of the container to xv6
  • --volume $HOME:$HOME: This maps your home directory to an equivalent directory in your container. If your user ID is "student" you will find files shared on both the host and in the container in the directory /home/student.
  • jjolly/xv6: The Docker image you wish to start running. You can find the image on Docker Hub.

For Windows you may start the Docker container from Powershell with the following command. Note the change in the --volume option:

$ docker run --tty --interactive --name xv6 --hostname xv6 --volume ${HOME}:/home/userid jjolly/xv6

This command will start a Bash shell inside of the TMux screen manager within the container. You are now ready to experience the xv6 OS. To see it run, type this command:

$ make qemu

This will build the OS kernel and userspace programs from source. It will then create a disk image with all the necessary binaries. It will then boot this disk image using the qemu emulator. After several lines of compiler output you should see the xv6 kernel boot like this:

xv6 kernel is booting

hart 1 starting
hart 2 starting
init: starting sh
$

The xv6 operating system is now running using the qemu emulator.

You are now running the xv6 command line running in the qemu emulator, and not the Linux command line. Do not expect all Linux commands to work until you have stopped the qemu emulator.

You can now see the names of several xv6 commands if you type ls (list files):

$ ls
.              1 1 1024
..             1 1 1024
README         2 2 2226
cat            2 3 23880
echo           2 4 22712
forktest       2 5 13072
grep           2 6 27240
init           2 7 23816
kill           2 8 22680
ln             2 9 22640
ls             2 10 26112
mkdir          2 11 22784
rm             2 12 22776
sh             2 13 41648
stressfs       2 14 23784
usertests      2 15 156000
grind          2 16 37952
wc             2 17 25024
zombie         2 18 22176
console        3 19 0

Except for the directory files . and .., as well as the device file console, these are all userspace program you can run. We will look at many of them during this semester.

To stop the qemu emulator, you need to use the qemu exit command Ctrl-a, x. This has the effect of "turning off" the machine that is running the xv6 operating system. When you stop the qemu emulator, you have caused the xv6 command line to stop running.

When you use the command to stop the qemu emulator, you are returned to the Linux command line.

The qemu emulator has many commands that all start with Ctrl-a that are documented here.

Install an Editor

Your xv6 OS container does not have an editor installed. This is done to keep the size of the Docker image small and reduce download times. Before installing anything into the xv6 container, always run apt update first. Here are three common editors you can install:

  • Nano: A fairly simple editor that is friendly to people new to console editors. It is fairly small - less than 1MB installed. It can be installed with:
    • apt install nano
  • Vim: A much more feature-rich editor, but the user interface is extremely minimalistic. This can be very confusing to newcomers and should be used cautiously. This is the editor your instructor uses because of the minimalism. It's a little larger installed at 37MB. It can be installed with:
    • apt install vim
  • Emacs: An entire environment of functionality that has been described as, "A good operating system with a passible editor." It even has the Lisp programming language built-in. A basic console installation* takes 148MB. It can be installed with:
    • apt install emacs-nox
  • The typical Emacs installation includes the x11 GUI and quickly approaches 350MB. You are welcome to install whatever you want, but you likely won't use the GUI component in this Docker container.
At this point you should have a console editor installed. If you do not know which editor to install, then you want to install the Nano editor. The Nano editor is the most friendly.

Part B: Creating a userspace Program for xv6

The xv6 operating system source code is divided up into two main categories: The kernel code and the userspace code. Userspace programs are used to interact with the kernel and perform useful functions. The ls command used in the earlier demonstration is an example of a userspace program. The source code for the ls program can be found in user/ls.c.

In order for the xv6 build system to recognize the userspace source code, each userspace program must be added to the Makefile. A variable in the Makefile called UPROGS lists the names of all the userspace programs that will be built and included in the file system. The list looks something like this:

UPROGS=\
  $U/_cat\
  $U/_echo\
  $U/_forktest\
  $U/_grep\
  $U/_init\
  $U/_kill\
  $U/_ln\
  $U/_ls\
  $U/_mkdir\
  $U/_rm\
  $U/_sh\
  $U/_stressfs\
  $U/_usertests\
  $U/_grind\
  $U/_wc\
  $U/_zombie\

The name of your userspace program must match the name of the source in the user directory. For this part of the assignment you will create a userspace program named assn1. You will do this by creating a file named assn1.c in the user directory, then adding $U/_assn1\ to the Makefile UPROGS variable.

The minimum source code for an xv6 userspace program is as follows:

#include "kernel/types.h"
#include "user/user.h"

int
main(int argc, char *argv[])
{
  exit(0);
}

This looks like a typical C program with two major differences:

  1. You must include the two header files kernel/types.h and user/user.h
    • You may include other header files, but these two must always be included
    • There is no stdio.h in xv6. Everything you can use can be found in user/user.h. Open the file in an editor to become familiar with what you can work with.
      For all the assignments, you will only ever need kernel/types.h and user/user.h - Adding other includes will likely cause you compile errors and heartache.
  2. You must call exit(0) at the end of your program
    • Traditionally when a C program terminates the exit(0) function is called automatically after your program calls return. This is not true for xv6. Every userspace program must be terminated by manually calling the exit(0) function.
    • This is an often-overlook source for bugs in xv6 userspace programs. It can be easy to overlook an exit point in main if there are multiple return statements.
      Do not use return from the main function of your user-space programs. Always use exit(0)

Userspace Program Specification

You userspace program must show your ability to write a working C program. Your assn1 userspace program will calculate the nth value of the Fibonacci Sequence.

The Fibonacci Sequence is fairly simple to understand and implement. The first two values in the sequence are given, specifically v0 = 0 and v1 = 1. All other values in the sequence are calculated from the previous two based on the function vn = vn-1 + vn-2. This gives us the first five values of the Fibonacci Sequence as:

  • v0 = 0
  • v1 = 1
  • v2 = v1 + v0 = 1 + 0 = 1
  • v3 = v2 + v1 = 1 + 1 = 2
  • v4 = v3 + v2 = 2 + 1 = 3

To determine which value to calculate and print, you must read the number from the options passed on the command line. If nothing is on the command line, then return v0. Your output should appear like this:

$ assn1
assn1: by John Jolly
Fibonacci number 0 is 0
$ assn1 4
assn1: by John Jolly
Fibonacci number 4 is 3
$ assn1 25
assn1: by John Jolly
Fibonacci number 25 is 75025

Your program must print out the header line with the name of the program and your name. Your program must output the result formatted as shown above, with both the sequence number as well as the sequence value.

Use must use the parameters of main, usually called argc and argv. If you do not understand how to use those parameters, then do a Google search on "tutorial argc and argv".

Once you have created, built, and run your program you will add your changes (two files) to your repository and commit them to a git branch named assn1.

All assignments will be submitted via your private Bitbucket repository. If you are unfamiliar how to do this, please refer to the lecture videos available in the module.

Part C: Debugging the xv6 operating system

A small description of the environment you will be debugging in is in order. The xv6 operating system is designed to run on the RISC-V (pronounced "risk-five") architecture. This is much like Intel or Arm but is considered more open in the sense of open source. All the RISC-V architecture manuals are freely available and we will reference them a few times during the course. They are not light reading but contain much valuable information.

Running xv6 in the GDB debugger

To debug the xv6 operating system you will need to run xv6 in one console window using the make qemu-gdb command and the debugger in a second console window using the gdb-multiarch command. In order to accommodate this two-console requirement the TMux console manager is used. TMux uses the Ctrl-b key to begin commands. Here is a short list of useful TMux commands:

  • Ctrl-b, c: Create a new console window. Each window is sequentially numbered when it is created
  • Ctrl-b, #: Where # is a digit 0-9. This allows you to switch directly to a specific console
  • Ctrl-b, p and Ctrl-b, n: Allows you to switch from the current console to the previous or next console
  • Ctrl-b, d: Detach from TMux and return to the starting console. This will cause Docker to terminate the container. Probably not what you want to do
    • If you did detach from TMux, you can restart the container by typing docker start -ai xv6
    • To avoid this problem detach from the Docker container with the Ctrl-p, Ctrl-q key sequence. This detaches your console from the container tty and allows the container to run in the background.
    • You can reattach to the container by typing docker attach xv6.

 

Become comfortable with TMux, as the xv6 Docker image is built on it, but it is also a common tool in the industry when working with the console

In order to debug xv6, you need to type this command:

$ make qemu-gdb

This will cause xv6 to be run in qemu running as a GDB server. You will see a message such as this:

*** Now run 'gdb' in another window.
qemu-system-riscv64 -machine virt ...
This command only starts the qemu emulator, it does not start running the xv6 OS. To actually start xv6 you need to have the debugger continue execution.

You can now create a new console by typing Ctrl-b, c. In the new console type:

$ gdb-multiarch

This will start the GDB debugger for our xv6 OS. For now allow GDB to continue by typing cont. To switch from the debugger screen back to the xv6 OS type Ctrl-b, p to switch to the previous console. To switch from the xv6 OS back to the debugger screen type Ctrl-b, n to switch to the next console.

You now have two "windows." One with the qemu emulator and a second with the debugger which is controlling the emulator in the first window.

When you exit qemu using Ctrl-a, x you will cause the debugger to lose it's connection. You can exit the debugger with the quit command.

GDB Commands: Examine and Print

The next GDB command is the "examine" command, which is just the letter x. You use "examine" when you want to see what is stored in memory at a variable or address. One of the nice things about "examine" is the formatting option. To format the output of "examine", you follow the x with a slash and a format specifier. There are several format specifiers you can use:

  • x: Output in hexadecimal, or base 16
  • d: Output in decimal, or base 10
  • t: Output in binary, or base 2
  • f: Output a IEEE-754 floating point number
  • c: Output ASCII character, or escaped unicode character
  • s: Output a NULL-terminated string
  • a: Address output, including offset from nearest symbol

The "examine" command is similar to another command, "print", or just the letter p. Commonly "examine" is used to view memory or registers, whereas "print" is used to view variables. Also, "print" allows for evaluating expressions. For example, the "print" command can do the following:

(gdb) p (10 + 30 / 6) / 5
$1 = 3

Another nice thing about the "print" command is that a temporary numeric variable is created to store each output. So, for this example, if you wish to reuse the result of this expression, you just need to use the variable $1.

Use "examine" to view memory directly. Use "print" to show variables and evaluate expressions.

When the debugger is first started for xv6, the first instruction to be executed is actually in the system BIOS and not in the xv6 code. There's only a few instructions in the BIOS that need to run. We can look at those instructions by typing the command x/5i $pc:

0x0000000000001000 in ?? ()
(gdb) x/5i $pc
=> 0x1000:      auipc   t0,0x0
   0x1004:      addi    a2,t0,40
   0x1008:      csrr    a0,mhartid
   0x100c:      ld      a1,32(t0)
   0x1010:      ld      t0,24(t0)
(gdb)

The first line above is output by the debugger to let us know where we are debugging in the system. I shows the current address stored in the Program Counter (PC), in this case the address is 0x0000000000001000, or 0x1000. The command I gave has four parts:

  • x: This is the Memory Examine command. It is frequently used to analyze memory in various formats. Those formats follow the forward-slash after the command
  • 5: This is the count of items we wish to examine. In this case, we want to examine five instructions
  • i: This is the format of the output. We want to see the machine instructions at this address, so we use i
  • $pc: This is the address we wish to examine. For our purposes we want to see the instructions starting where the program counter currently references. All registers are accessed using the dollar-sign ($).

We could have found the same results if we had typed the address directly, like this:

(gdb) x/5i 0x1000
=> 0x1000:      auipc   t0,0x0
   0x1004:      addi    a2,t0,40
   0x1008:      csrr    a0,mhartid
   0x100c:      ld      a1,32(t0)
   0x1010:      ld      t0,24(t0)

What you are looking at are the assembly instructions that are first executed when the emulator starts. This is the human readable format of the machine instructions. You can see the actual machine instructions using the x/5x $pc command:

(gdb) x/5x 0x1000
0x1000: 0x00000297      0x02828613      0xf1402573      0x0202b583
0x1010: 0x0182b283

Now to move onto parts of the code that are more readable. There are actually five stages to the startup of the xv6 operating system:

  1. BIOS: This is at address 0x1000 and is not actually part of the xv6 operating system. This is where your debugger will always start. You will usually move on quickly from this stage with the cont continue command.
  2. _entry: This is the assembly language entry point of the xv6 operating system and the source code can be found in the kernel/entry.S file. This part of the code sets up the kernel stack for each CPU. It is short and we will not concern ourselves with this code for this assignment.
  3. start: This is where the C source starts for xv6. The source code can be found in kernel/start.c. This code performs several configuration steps for the CPU in preparation for running as an operating system kernel.
  4. main: This is where the kernel initializes the data structures used internally by the xv6 operating system. The source code can be found in kernel/main.c. Things like the console, the storage device, main memory, and many other kernel structures will be initialized here.
  5. scheduler: This is the part of the kernel that manages processes. The source code can be found in kernel/proc.c. Technically the scheduler function loops forever on each CPU and never exits, always choosing another process. We will discuss this part of the kernel in depth shortly.

GDB Commands: Setting, Viewing, and Deleting Breakpoints

For now you will skip over the _entry and the start parts of the operating system. Let's investigate where the operating system really starts to initialize itself. Do this by setting a breakpoint on main and continuing the debugger:

(gdb) b main
Breakpoint 1 at 0x80000e80: file kernel/main.c, line 13.
(gdb) c
Continuing.
[Switching to Thread 1.2]

Thread 2 hit Breakpoint 1, main () at kernel/main.c:13
13        if(cpuid() == 0){
(gdb)

You have hit the breakpoint and are now at the top of the main function of the kernel. Breakpoints allow the debugger to execute until a specific point in the code has been reached. We can allow the operating system to initialize and stop just as the first process is about to be scheduled by setting a function breakpoint on the function named scheduler:

(gdb) b scheduler
Breakpoint 2 at 0x80001ea2: file kernel/proc.c, line 446.
(gdb) c
Continuing.
[Switching to Thread 1.1]

Thread 1 hit Breakpoint 1, main () at kernel/main.c:13
13        if(cpuid() == 0){
(gdb)

What's this? Wasn't the debugger suppose to halt at the next breakpoint? The debugger has stopped at the breakpoint for main again. This is because the xv6 operating system defaults to being emulated on a 3 CPU system, and the debugger has hit a breakpoint on another CPU. For now, we don't need the breakpoint on main, so let's delete the breakpoint.

(gdb) info breakpoints 
Num     Type           Disp Enb Address            What
1       breakpoint     keep y   0x0000000080000e80 in main at kernel/main.c:13
        breakpoint already hit 2 times
2       breakpoint     keep y   0x0000000080001ea2 in scheduler at kernel/proc.c:446
(gdb) d 1
(gdb) info breakpoints 
Num     Type           Disp Enb Address            What
2       breakpoint     keep y   0x0000000080001ea2 in scheduler at kernel/proc.c:446
(gdb)

The first info breakpoints command shows two breakpoints are set. Breakpoint #1 is set for the main function in kernel/main.c at line 13. Breakpoint #2 is set for the scheduler function in kernel/proc.c at line 446. Since the first breakpoint is not needed, the "delete" command, or d - along with the breakpoint number 1 - removes the breakpoint. This is shown by listing the breakpoints with the info breakpoints command. Note that the breakpoint number did not change for our scheduler breakpoint - it is still breakpoint #2. All breakpoints that are set will have a unique numeric identifier.

Learning how and where to set breakpoints will be a valuable skill.

Now we can allow the system to continue until one of the CPUs reach the scheduler breakpoint. Listing the code will show the first lines of the scheduler function.

(gdb) c
Continuing.

Thread 1 hit Breakpoint 2, scheduler () at kernel/proc.c:446
446     {
(gdb) l
441     //  - swtch to start running that process.
442     //  - eventually that process transfers control
443     //    via swtch back to the scheduler.
444     void
445     scheduler(void)
446     {
447       struct proc *p;
448       struct cpu *c = mycpu();
449       
450       c->proc = 0;
(gdb)

GDB Commands: Stepping Over and Into Function Calls

In order to use the debugger to step from one line to the next within the debugger, the "next" command, or n should be used. Try to step over the next several lines:

(gdb) n
448       struct cpu *c = mycpu();
(gdb) n
450       c->proc = 0;
(gdb) n
453         intr_on();
(gdb) n
[Switching to Thread 1.2]

Thread 2 hit Breakpoint 2, scheduler () at kernel/proc.c:446
446     {
(gdb)

Suddenly in this example the debugger switch from line 453 in thread number 1 to our breakpoint at line 446 for thread number 2. This can happen in multithreaded programs such as our emulated multi-cpu system. It may take you a few times stepping through the code with the "next" command, but you will experience this eventually. This (very annoying) thread switching can be limited by changing the scheduler-locking setting in the debugger There are several values that can be used, we'll start with step which prevents thread switching so long as we are stepping line-by-line:

(gdb) set scheduler-locking step
The default configuration for xv6 emulates three CPUs. Debugging commands may switch between the three CPUs unexpectedly unless you use the set scheduler-locking step command.

Now the debugger should allow us to single-step through the code and not randomly switch to another thread when we least expect it. Step through the lines of code until it stops at line 456 (once you type a command, the enter key alone will repeat that command). Type the "next" command followed by the enter key alone four times:

(gdb) set scheduler-locking step
(gdb) n
448       struct cpu *c = mycpu();
(gdb) 
450       c->proc = 0;
(gdb) 
453         intr_on();
(gdb) 
455         for(p = proc; p < &proc[NPROC]; p++) {
(gdb) 
456           acquire(&p->lock);
(gdb)

Examining In-memory Structures

An important skill when debugging is to view the contents of data structures while debugging. Notice that on line 455 above the for loop is initializing the p variable with the value of the proc variable. This is actually a memory address pointer that really has no direct meaning to the debugger:

(gdb) p p
$2 = (struct proc *) 0x80010f80 <proc>
(gdb) 

The debugger tells us several things about the pointer: the type of the pointer is struct proc *, the memory address, and the closest symbol to the address (in this case, the variable named proc). But the actual content of the structure is not shown. To do that, the pointer needs to be dereferenced:

(gdb) p *p
$3 = {lock = {locked = 1, name = 0x800081f8 "proc", cpu = 0x80010b80 <cpus>}, state = RUNNABLE, chan = 0x0, killed = 0, xstate = 0, pid = 1, parent = 0x0, kstack = 274877894656, sz = 4096, pagetable = 0x87f73000, trapframe = 0x87f74000, context = {ra = 2147490276, sp = 274877898752, s0 = 0, s1 = 0, s2 = 0, s3 = 0, s4 = 0, s5 = 0, s6 = 0, s7 = 0, s8 = 0, s9 = 0, s10 = 0, s11 = 0}, ofile = { 0x0 <repeats 16 times>}, cwd = 0x8001f090 <itable+24>, name = "initcode\000\000\000\000\000\000\000"}
(gdb)

Using the dereference operator (the asterisk) we are allowed to view the data within the structure. Unfortunately this is very difficult to read. By changing another GDB setting, we can allow GDB to cleanly format the output of the structure. The following command will make the setting change for you:

(gdb) set print pretty on

Now try and print the dereferenced p variable again:

(gdb) p *p
$4 = {
  lock = {
    locked = 1,
    name = 0x800081f8 "proc",
    cpu = 0x80010b80 <cpus>
  },
  state = RUNNABLE,
  chan = 0x0,
  killed = 0,
  xstate = 0,
  pid = 1,
  parent = 0x0,
  kstack = 274877894656,
  sz = 4096,
  pagetable = 0x87f73000,
  trapframe = 0x87f74000,
  context = {
    ra = 2147490276,
    sp = 274877898752,
    s0 = 0,
    s1 = 0,
    s2 = 0,
    s3 = 0,
    s4 = 0,
    s5 = 0,
    s6 = 0,
    s7 = 0,
    s8 = 0,
    s9 = 0,
    s10 = 0,
    s11 = 0
  },
  ofile = {0x0 <repeats 16 times>},
  cwd = 0x8001f090 <itable+24>,
  name = "initcode\000\000\000\000\000\000\000"
}

This is the process structure for the initcode process. Some important members to this structure are:

  • state: This is the current state of the process. Right now the process is in the state RUNNABLE. There are other states that a process can be in, which we will discuss in the next few weeks
  • pid: This is a unique numerical identifier for the process. Every process has a unique process ID.
  • parent: This is a pointer to the process structure of the parent process. More will be discussed regarding the process parent/child relationship
  • sz: This is the number of bytes of memory used by the process
  • pagetable: A structure that defines how memory is organized for the process. Much will be said about page tables later in the semester
  • context: These are the registers that were set for the process when the process was paused. Since we're running in the operating system kernel, the registers of the process need to be stored here until the kernel has finished running and switches back to the process.
  • ofile: The open file table. This will be discussed in a later part of the class
  • name: The character string name of the process. Usually the name of the program that was executed.
Examining data structures such as this process structure, is a common task when debugging. You should get use to printing structures in GDB.

Let's practice debugging the kernel after starting a program. Delete the scheduler breakpoint and continue the operating system (you should know how to do this now). This will allow the xv6 operating system to come up fully. You can now switch away from the gdb window to the xv6 window using the TMux Ctrl-b, p command.

For this assignment, you will answer questions about a process when a system call is made. Specifically, you will set a breakpoint that will halt the debugger in the fork() system call. To set this breakpoint, switch to the console with the debugger. Because the xv6 operating system is running, you initially will not see the debugger prompt. To halt xv6 and get to a debugger prompt, you need to interrupt the debugger using the Ctrl-c command. You should see the following when you press Ctrl-c:

^C
Thread 2 received signal SIGINT, Interrupt.
acquire (lk=lk@entry=0x80016278 <proc+21240>) at kernel/spinlock.c:25
25        if(holding(lk))
(gdb)

Where the debugger stops when interrupted with Ctrl-c will vary, but you will be presented the gdb prompt. Note that xv6 will no longer interact with you as it is halted waiting for the debugger to resume.

Get use to the fact that either you can use xv6 or you can use the debugger, but both will not be usable at the same time. If xv6 is not responding, you likely need to continue in the debugger. If the debugger is not responding, you likely need to halt the debugger with Ctrl-c.

At the debugger prompt, set a breakpoint for the fork() function (should show as a breakpoint on line 281 in kernel/proc.c) and continue. Now switch back to xv6 - you'll find it's responsive again. Type the command ls and enter. No directory listing will be shown immediately if you set the breakpoint correctly. This is expected. Switch back to the debugger screen and you should see:

[Switching to Thread 1.1]

Thread 1 hit Breakpoint 3, fork () at kernel/proc.c:281
281     {
(gdb)

We can see several things. We are looking at the code being executed on the first CPU (in RISC-V parlance, it's called a Hart, but we'll continue to use the generic term CPU). This is known because the debugger informed us that it has switched to thread 1.1, or the first thread which represent the first CPU. You may get a different thread, and this is fine. You also will see that the debugger has halted at line 281 in kernel/proc.c, precisely where we need it to be halted.

List the source code at this point and see what the first few lines of fork looks like:

(gdb) l
276
277     // Create a new process, copying the parent.
278     // Sets up child kernel stack to return as if from fork() system call.
279     int
280     fork(void)
281     {
282       int i, pid;
283       struct proc *np;
284       struct proc *p = myproc();
285
(gdb)

Notice on line 284 the myproc() function is called and the return value is assigned to the struct proc * variable p.

In order to execute line 284 the "next" command needs to be used, but there's a problem that you can't see yet. Remember that this is a multiple CPU system, and each CPU is running as a thread in the qemu emulator - except when we step through the program. Take a look at the scheduler-locking setting:

(gdb) show scheduler-locking 
Mode for locking scheduler during execution is "step".
(gdb)

This setting prevents all other threads from executing when using the "next" or "step" commands. In most cases this is not a problem, but in order to see the process structure, the myproc() function call needs to be made. There is something important to understand about the myproc() function, so let's debug into that function. Use the "next" command one time to advance the debugger to line 284, then use the "step" command to step into the myproc() function:

(gdb) n
284       struct proc *p = myproc();
(gdb) s
myproc () at kernel/proc.c:85
85        push_off();
(gdb)

Take a look at the source code for the myproc() function by using the "list" command:

(gdb) l
80
81      // Return the current struct proc *, or zero if none.
82      struct proc*
83      myproc(void)
84      {
85        push_off();
86        struct cpu *c = mycpu();
87        struct proc *p = c->proc;
88        pop_off();
89        return p;
(gdb)

The push_off() and pop_off() functions are important here. Those function are responsible for locking out other CPUs while this CPU does it's work. The problem is the push_off() function will block, or not return, if another CPU has also called push_off(), and will not return until the other CPU has called pop_off(). The detail of this will be covered when we discuss Concurency in a few weeks. If this function blocks waiting for another thread, but the scheduler-locking setting prevents threads from running, then the debugger will appear to lock up.

For now, disable the scheduler-locking. We do not expect that any other CPUs will be calling the fork() system call while we're debugging, so we don't need to worry about unexpectedly changing to another thread. Advance the debugger past line 87 (where struct proc *p is being set):

(gdb) set scheduler-locking off
(gdb) n
86        struct cpu *c = mycpu();
(gdb) n
87        struct proc *p = c->proc;
(gdb) n
88        pop_off();
(gdb)

After this line has been executed, you should be able to inspect the process structure for the process that made the system call to fork(). Please answer the following questions about the process:

Q1: What is the debugger command you used to display the content of the process structure?

Q2: What is the process state? (hint: It should be all in upper case)

Q3: What is the process ID?

Q4: What is the process size?

Q5: What is the process name?

Q6: How many open files does this process have (hint: the number of elements in the array ofile that are not zero)

You can also display the process structure for the parent process. Using the "print" command, display the structure of p->parent and answer the following questions:

Q7: What is the parent process state?

Q8: What is the parent process id?

Q9: What is the parent process name? (hint: don't worry about anything starting at "\000" and after. It's usually garbage anyway)

You should type the answers to these questions as your submission to Canvas.

Overview

In this assignment you will add a new system call to the xv6 operating system and write a user-mode test program. This new system call will retrieve the process id of the parent of the current process. The test program will verify that the parent process ID retrieved for a process matches the actual parent process id.

Goals

By the end of this assignment you will demonstrate:

  • How to create a userspace test harness program
  • How to create a new system call in xv6
  • How to properly lock internal kernel data structures
  • How to navigate the process structure in xv6
  • How to use git to add a remote repository and fetch a branch from the remote
  • How to use git to create a tar archive and submit that file to Canvas

Before You Start

You will need to create a new assn2 Git branch for your assignment. Before you can do that, you need to verify that everything is clean in your current branch. Check the status of your current branch with:

$ git status
On branch assn1
Your branch is up to date with 'origin/riscv'.

If anything has been changed or uncommitted please stage and commit them now. If you do not want to keep the changes, then restore those files using the instructions provided by the output of git status. You do not need to worry about untracked files as they should not conflict with your new branch.

Now make sure you have created a new Git branch for your project. You can do this the step-by-step method of:

$ git checkout riscv
Switched to branch 'riscv'
$ git branch assn2
$ git checkout assn2
Switched to branch 'assn2'

Or do the same thing in one step (don't try both as you will get errors about the new branch already existing):

$ git checkout -b assn2 origin/riscv

Now that you have a new branch, you can start editing your code.

Creating the Test Program (Test Harness)

You are responsible for creating a user space program that tests your new system call. In fact, you should create it first and make sure it fails where you expect it to fail. Creating the test before creating the feature is call Test Driven Development. It will help you with a target that will build and run successfully when you have completed the new feature.

For this assignment, you will create a test program that will call your getppid system call. In order for this test to work, we need to know two things:

  1. The process ID of the parent, and
  2. The parent process ID of the child.

Since any program we write does not have specific knowledge of the parent process, the test program needs to be both the parent and the child. Fortunately this can be done with the fork() system call. Using fork() will allow the test program to be both the parent and the child.

Of course, since your program will be calling fork(), you must also call wait(int *) to make sure the child is properly cleaned up. Every process that terminates must call the exit(int) API. In addition to releasing all the process memory, it allows the process to provide a return code. This integer can signify success (usually 0) or failure (usually 1 or -1) or any value that makes sense.

But if the process memory is released where should the return code be stored? In xv6 the return code is stored in the xstate member of the process structure. The process is then set to a ZOMBIE state, as the process is dead but not completely gone (the process structure is still in use).

To make the process structure available again, another process must call the wait(int *) API. The integer pointer parameter allows the wait(int *) API to store the content of xstate in the process structure into a variable usable to the caller. Once the ZOMBIE process state has been copied to an integer variable, the process structure can be set to UNUSED, officially freeing the structure for any new process. The wait(int *) call can be made by the parent in the following way:

int ret = 0;
wait(&ret);
printf("The child return code is %d\n", ret);

If the parent process does not properly call wait(int *) to clean up after it's children, then another process must be responsible. Any time a parent process terminates without waiting on it's children, those children are reassigned to the granddaddy of all processes, the init process (process #1). The init process constantly waits for abandoned children processes to come along. These abandon children are known as orphan processes. This abandonment can happen while the child is still running or when it has terminated. In either case, init will wait for the child to terminate and clean up after it.

There are times when a process waiting for a child does not care about the return value of the terminating child. This is the case for the init process (see user/init.c line 42). In this case the universal symbol for "I don't care" is sent, the number 0 (known as NULL in other systems). When wait(int *) is about to copy xstate from the zombie process structure, and finds the pointer set to zero (See kernel/proc.c line 411) then it doesn't perform the copy.

Now that you know what is necessary for creating and cleaning up child processes, you can create your getppid test program. The test program should do the following in the main() function:

  1. Get the current process id with getpid() and store it in a local variable
  2. Call fork()
  3. If this is the parent:
    1. Wait for the child with wait(int *)
  4. If this is the child:
    1. Get the parent process id with getppid() (you will be creating this system call)
    2. Compare it with the previously-obtained process id
    3. If they match, report success
    4. If they don't match, report failure

Write your code in the source code file user/assn2.c and update the UPROGS variable in the Makefile. If you've done everything correctly your program will fail to build because you are missing the getppid() system call. If it is failing to build, you've done it right! Stage your files and commit them locally. Now is a good time to push your changes to Bitbucket.

Creating a System Call

As was demonstrated in class, there are a few files that need to be modified to add a system call. You will be adding a system call getppid(). Notice the extra 'p' in the call. This is somewhat similar to the getpid() system call, so let's use that as a reference. Start by cleaning up the source directory and searching for all the occurrences of getpid:

root@xv6:/xv6-riscv# make clean
rm -f *.tex *.dvi *.idx *.aux *.log *.ind *.ilg \
*/*.o */*.d */*.asm */*.sym \
user/initcode user/initcode.out kernel/kernel fs.img \
mkfs/mkfs .gdbinit \
        user/usys.S \
user/_cat user/_echo user/_forktest user/_grep user/_init user/_kill user/_ln user/_ls user/_mkdir user/_rm user/_sh user/_stressfs user/_usertests user/_grind user/_wc user/_zombie
root@xv6:/xv6-riscv# grep -rn getpid kernel
kernel/syscall.h:12:#define SYS_getpid 11
kernel/sysproc.c:19:sys_getpid(void)
kernel/syscall.c:93:extern uint64 sys_getpid(void);
kernel/syscall.c:118:[SYS_getpid]  sys_getpid,
root@xv6:/xv6-riscv# grep -rn getpid user
user/user.h:21:int getpid(void);
user/usys.pl:35:entry("getpid");
user/usertests.c:803:        getpid();
user/usertests.c:908:  int master_pid = getpid();
user/grind.c:150:        kill(getpid());

First run make clean. This will restore the source directory to it's original state. Then search using the grep utility for all instances of getpid. Here are the files we need to focus on:

  • kernel/syscall.h : Every system call has a unique numeric identifier. The identifier for getpid is 11. We will need to choose an identifier for our new getppid system call and add it to this file. The number that is chosen should be unique from all the other numbers. Just choose the next integer value sequentially. Note that it is prefixed with SYS_. Do not forget to do this. (one line added to kernel/syscall.h)
  • kernel/syscall.c : There are two additions that must be made to this file:
    • This is where we add the function declaration for our new sys_getppid(void) function. Just like the other functions your declaration should take a void parameter and return a uint64. It should be declared extern just like the other function declarations. The easiest way to finish this is to copy the getpid() declaration and paste it, adding the extra 'p' to the function name. (one line added to kernel/syscall.c)
    • We need to associate the function to our system call id number chosen in the previous step. This is done in the declaration of the syscalls variable. Each system call needs an entry that has the system call ID defined in kernel/syscall.h associated with the system call function. It will likely look like this: [SYS_getppid] sys_getppid, Add that to the syscalls array. (one line added to kernel/syscall.c)
  • user/user.h : You need to add a function declaration for the userspace programs to call. This declaration will be different than the declaration in the kernel code in that it will not be prefixed with sys_ and could have parameters (although not in our case). Just copy the function declaration for getpid() and paste it, including an extra "p" in the function name. (one line added to user/user.h)
  • user/usys.pl : This script is a code generation script. It creates stub functions for every system call that will be linked to the userspace programs. When a userspace program makes a system call, the stub function generated by this script will be called. In order for a stub to be created, though, and "entry" needs to be made in this script. Just copy the getpid entry and add the letter "p". (one line added to user/usys.pl)

Now we need to actually write the system call. Let's add it to the same source file as sys_getpid(void) is found - kernel/sysproc.c. Here is what the current "Get Process ID" system call function looks like:

uint64
sys_getpid(void)
{
  return myproc()->pid;
}

Let's start by writing a stub system call. Just copy this function, but have it return 0 for now. This should allow us to successfully compile, but if we run the test program in xv6, it will fail:

xv6 kernel is booting

hart 1 starting
hart 2 starting
init: starting sh
$ assn2
assn2: getppid by John Jolly
FAILURE! Process IDs do not match! 3 != 0

But it compiles and runs! Call that an initial success. Make sure your assn2 test program output matches what you see above when the system call only returns a zero.

Getting the Parent Process ID

The getpid system call shown above is fairly simple. It just calls the myproc() function and references the pid member of the function return. So what does the myproc() function look like. This can be found in the kernel/proc.c source code:

// Return the current struct proc *, or zero if none.
struct proc*
myproc(void) {
  push_off();
  struct cpu *c = mycpu();
  struct proc *p = c->proc;
  pop_off();
  return p;
}

This function first disables interrupts to this CPU. This is a good idea since a device (like the timer) might interrupt this CPU between getting the cpu structure and getting the process structure. Imagine how awkward it would be for this process to wake up on another CPU and get the process structure from the first CPU.

When finished, this function returns a pointer to the process structure. The definition for the process structure can be found in kernel/proc.h:

// Per-process state
struct proc {
  struct spinlock lock;

  // p->lock must be held when using these:
  enum procstate state;        // Process state
  void *chan;                  // If non-zero, sleeping on chan
  int killed;                  // If non-zero, have been killed
  int xstate;                  // Exit status to be returned to parent's wait
  int pid;                     // Process ID

  // wait_lock must be held when using this:
  struct proc *parent;         // Parent process

  // these are private to the process, so p->lock need not be held.
  uint64 kstack;               // Virtual address of kernel stack
  uint64 sz;                   // Size of process memory (bytes)
  pagetable_t pagetable;       // User page table
  struct trapframe *trapframe; // data page for trampoline.S
  struct context context;      // swtch() here to run process
  struct file *ofile[NOFILE];  // Open files
  struct inode *cwd;           // Current directory
  char name[16];               // Process name (debugging)
};

Whew! There's a lot going on here. For now focus on the pid member which holds the unique process ID for that process. Also notice the parent member. It's a process structure as well. That means it's as simple as returning myproc()->parent->pid, right? Not quite.

Take a look at comment right above the parent member. It mentions that a wait_lock must be held to use the parent. There's a problem we must account for. Consider the following.

Just after the myproc() function successfully returns the process structure for the process running on the current cpu, and the parent member is retrieved, something happens to the parent process. Perhaps while running concurrently on another CPU the parent process decides to exit. That causes the process structure for the parent to be cleared. Suddenly we have an invalid pid value.

Concurrency issues like this can be prevented by using locks. Locks prevent any other concurrent process from accessing the lock. If our current process is holding the wait_lock, then no other process may acquire the lock - even if the process is running on concurrently on another process. We need to acquire that wait_lock before reading the parent process structure.

Let's search for wait_lock in the code using the grep command:

root@xv6:/xv6-riscv# grep -r wait_lock
kernel/proc.c:struct spinlock wait_lock;
kernel/proc.c:  initlock(&wait_lock, "wait_lock");
kernel/proc.c:  acquire(&wait_lock);
kernel/proc.c:  release(&wait_lock);
kernel/proc.c:// Caller must hold wait_lock.
kernel/proc.c:  acquire(&wait_lock);
kernel/proc.c:  release(&wait_lock);
kernel/proc.c:  acquire(&wait_lock);
kernel/proc.c:            release(&wait_lock);
kernel/proc.c:          release(&wait_lock);
kernel/proc.c:      release(&wait_lock);
kernel/proc.c:    sleep(p, &wait_lock);  //DOC: wait-sleep
kernel/proc.h:  // wait_lock must be held when using this:

Hmm, only one file has access to the wait_lock - kernel/proc.c. The lock is not used in any other source file. In fact it is only accessible from kernel/proc.c. We can't use the wait_lock from the kernel/sysproc.c file where we're creating our getppid system call. This means we need to create an accessor function in kernel/proc.c.

Writing Kernel Data Accessors

In order to get the parent process ID we must create a function that will do the following:

  • Get the current process structure by calling myproc(). Save the pointer to a local variable.
  • Acquire the wait_lock
  • Save the parent process id in a local variable
  • Release the wait_lock
  • Return the parent process id (it's in the local variable, remember?)

A great example of how to lock, use, and unlock can be found in the fork() function in kernel/proc.c. Here's the relevant piece of code:

  acquire(&wait_lock);
  np->parent = p;
  release(&wait_lock);

In this example, a value is being written to parent. We want to read from parent, so make sure you switch this around.

Now, with your new function in kernel/proc.c that returns the parent process id, we need to add our function declaration to the correct header file, but which one? Well, we know myproc() is usable outside of kernel/proc.c. It needs to be declared somewhere, let's look for it:

root@xv6:/xv6-riscv# grep -r myproc kernel/*.h
kernel/defs.h:struct proc*    myproc();

Ahh, kernel/defs.h is the place. Add a line in this file that declares your getppid() function. It should be returning an integer.

We're in the home stretch! Now we can have our system call in kernel/sysproc.c return something other than zero. Just catch the return from the call to the function you created in kernel/proc.c and return it from your system call.

Grading

This is a 25 point assignment. Here is the point breakdown:
