Objective

You will implement the lottery scheduler as described in OS:TEP Chapter 9 - Proportional Share Scheduling. You will also create two system calls, one that returns the runtime of a process, and one that allows a process to assign the number of shares to the current process. But first you will write a user-space test program to verify your scheduler.

Overview

In class we have gone over the xv6 process scheduler. As you recall the original scheduler loops through the processes looking for a RUNNABLE process, sets it to RUNNING and then performs a context switch to the process. This is a fairly basic scheduler and is much like the Round Robin scheduler since it schedules each process in order, but can be preempted by the CPU timer. The only difference is the Round Robin scheduler orders jobs by their arrival time, where the xv6 scheduler order is dictated by the position of the process structure within the process structure array - only slightly less fair.

The changes you will make to xv6 will implement the Lottery Scheduler that is found in Chapter 9 of OS:TEP. You will add a variable to the process structure that contains the number of shares assigned to the process. Initially this variable will be set to the same shares as the parent process. The init process will be set to a default number of shares.

The assignment should follow these steps:

  1. Create a new branch named assn3 from the riscv branch
  2. Add an integer runtime variable to the process structure and a system call to retrieve the runtime value
  3. Create the source code for a user space program that will test your scheduler and name it user/assn3.c
  4. Create the stub for the shares system call
  5. Add the shares variable to the process structure, and initialize it in the proper initialization function
  6. In the appropriate function copy the shares from the parent process to the child process when the fork call is made
  7. Write a random number generator
  8. Write a loop to count the total number of shares on RUNNABLE jobs
  9. Choose a random ticket within the range of the total number of tickets
  10. Have the scheduler only choose a job if the random ticket is within the ticket range for the process
  11. Finish the shares system call

Create your new assn3 branch

Before you write any code, you need to create the assn3 branch in your local repository based off the riscv upstream branch. Create your new branch and check it out with this command:

root@xv6:/xv6-riscv# git checkout -b assn3 origin/riscv
Branch 'assn3' set up to track remote branch 'riscv' from 'origin'.
Switched to a new branch 'assn3'

The output of this command should reassure you that your are now working in a branch named assn3 and that it is "tracking" remote branch riscv from the origin remote. You are now ready to write some code.

Creating a Process Runtime System Call

In order to test our scheduler, we need a user space program that creates several processes with different shares assigned, and after killing the processes measures the number of times each process was scheduled and compare those times. This means we need to add code that increments a counter each time a process is scheduled. To add this feature, we need to do the following:

  • Add an integer variable to the process structure named runtime. This is one line of code in the kernel/proc.h file
  • Initialize our new runtime variable to 0 in the allocproc function. This is one line of code in the kernel/proc.c file
  • Increment our new runtime variable in the scheduler function. This is one line of code in the kernel/proc.c file

You also need to create a system call that allows the parent process to read the runtime variable of another process. This system call should take one parameter, an integer, that will be the ID of the process where we need to get the runtime value.

  • Create a new system call named int getrt(int) that returns the value of runtime. Refer to your assignment 2 for how to create a system call. This will modify the following files:
    • user/user.h - one line of code
    • user/usys.pl - one line of code
    • kernel/syscall.h - one line of code
    • kernel/syscall.c - two lines of code
    • kernel/proc.c - Add this function fifteen lines of code:
      • int
        getprocruntime(int pid) {
          struct proc *p;
          int runtime = -1;

          for(p = proc; p < &proc[NPROC] && runtime < 0; p++) {
            acquire(&p->lock);
            if(pid == p->pid) {
              runtime = p->runtime;
            }
            release(&p->lock);
          }

          return runtime;
        }
    • kernel/defs.h - one line of code that should look like this: 
      • int             getprocruntime(int);
    • kernel/sysproc.c - No more than six lines of code that should look like this: 
      • uint64
        sys_getrt(void)
        {
          int pid;
          argint(0, &pid);
          return getprocruntime(pid);
        }

This addition will keep track of how many time a process has been scheduled. This is generally when the timer interrupt is triggered, but can also occur when a process makes a system call. For our purposes the test program will be written to trigger the timer interrupt.

I suggest writing a test program for this new getrt(int) system call that has output like this:

xv6 kernel is booting

hart 2 starting
hart 1 starting
init: starting sh
$ testgetrt
testgetrt by John Jolly
Process 3 sleeping for 100 ticks
Start ticks == 7
End ticks == 107
Process 3 tick difference == 100
$ testgetrt 50
testgetrt by John Jolly
Process 4 sleeping for 50 ticks
Start ticks == 1
End ticks == 51
Process 4 tick difference == 50
$ testgetrt 250
testgetrt by John Jolly
Process 5 sleeping for 250 ticks
Start ticks == 1
End ticks == 251
Process 5 tick difference == 250

The "ticks" value in xv6 is the number of times a process has been scheduled. This happens every one-tenth of a second. In order to have the process not do work for a certain number of ticks, you will need to use the sleep(int) API. The integer parameter is the number of ticks your process will wait before being scheduled again and doing more work.

Please note this is not the test program you need to write for testing the scheduler, and this test program is not required for your assignment. You're just adding a new feature we need to write the required test program for the new scheduler, and you should test the new process runtime feature.

This is a good time to stage and commit your new process runtime system call.

Create the User Space Test Program for the New Scheduler

First make sure you have a simple user space program created in user/assn3.c that just prints the assignment title and your name. This is just a stub program that you will fill in shortly. Follow the instructions from previous assignments. Don't forget to update Makefile. Your output in xv6 should look like this (with the name changed, obviously):

xv6 kernel is booting

hart 1 starting
hart 2 starting
init: starting sh
$ assn3
assn3 by John Jolly
$

If that runs successfully, stage your changes and commit them to your Git repository.

In order to test the scheduler, we want to make CPU-bound processes each with a different share value assigned. This will force the timer interrupt to trigger and the scheduler to run. The easiest way to create a CPU-bound process is to loop infinitely with the simple loop for(;;);. If several child processes are created that set their share value with the shares system call and loop forever, then the parent can call the kill system call to terminate those children. Once all the child processes have been killed, the parent can call the getrt system call on the children to find how many times the processes were scheduled. Then the parent can clean up the killed children using the wait system call.

Here are the tasks the test program should accomplish:

  • Create three child processes and store in variables the three process IDs returned by fork
    • Each child process should call the shares system call that will set the child process shares
      • The number of shares should be 10 for the first child, 20 for the second, and 30 for the third
      • You will create this system call for your new scheduler later in this assignment
    • After setting the process shares, loop forever in your child process
      • You do not need to call exit from the child, as the loop will not allow anything to be executed in the child process
  • Once the parent process creates the three child processes, the parent should call the sleep system call for 300 ticks (30 seconds)
  • After the call to sleep returns, call the kill system call using the process IDs returned by fork for each of the three children
  • For each of the child processes, call the getrt system call using the process IDs returned by fork. Display the value returned by getrt
  • For each of the child processes, call the wait system call to clean up the process structures. Pass 0 as the parameter as we do not care about the process exit status

At first, your test program will not compile as you have not created the shares system call. This is to be expected. Stage and commit your changes and let's fix the compile problem.

Test Driven Development is all about testing the feature you want, before you write the feature. Your test program will fail at first. Don't panic, you're not done yet.

Create the Stub for the shares System Call

This will be similar to the getppid assignment where you modify the following files:

  • kernel/syscall.c - The declaration for the kernel system call function. Two lines added
  • kernel/syscall.h - The system call number. Name it SYS_shares. One line added
  • kernel/sysproc.c - Your system function definition. Name it sys_shares. You will add to this function later, but for now it should be no more than three to five lines added
  • user/user.h - The system call declaration in userspace. Name it shares to return int and take an int parameter. One line added
  • user/usys.pl - The system call definition in userspace. Add an entry(...). One line added

This call will take an integer as a parameter and return an integer for status (0 for success, -1 for error). For now just return -1. Since the system call is not complete, it would be an error to use it. The test program will react appropriately for an error.

When you're done add the files for staging and commit your changes:

root@xv6:/xv6-riscv# git add kernel/user.h kernel/usys.pl kernel/syscall.h kernel/syscall.c kernel/sysproc.c
root@xv6:/xv6-riscv# git commit -m 'Create shares system call'

Now the test program can be run. For this to be an effective test, you need to limit the CPUs of the system to one instead of the usual three. You can do this by running the xv6 operating system with the following addition:

$ make CPUS=1 qemu

Your test program should now build successfully and you should get the following output:

xv6 kernel is booting

init: starting sh
$ assn3
assn3 by John Jolly
Allowing child processes to run for 300 ticks (30 seconds)
Share value for process 6 failed to set
Share value for process 4 failed to set
Share value for process 5 failed to set
Process 4 with 10 shares ran for 1 ticks
Process 5 with 20 shares ran for 1 ticks
Process 6 with 30 shares ran for 1 ticks

First, notice that you do not see hart 1 starting or hart 2 starting. Adding CPUS=1 to make qemu causes the emulator to launch with only one emulated CPU. This can also be used in make qemu-gdb if you wish to debug a single-processor system.

Second, you should see the output of your test program assn3 with the runtime ticks of your three child processes. Note that the children only ran for one tick. This is because they should exit immediately after reporting the error. Also note the errors are out-of-order, with process 6 reporting first. This is because our scheduler is nondeterministic. This means you can't predict in what order processes will be scheduled. Don't be worried about the values right now. In fact, they will change dramatically once the scheduler has been changed.

If you have things working well at this point, stage and commit your changes. Don't forget to push your changes to your student branch for the sake of a backup.

Add shares Variable to the Process Structure and Initialize

Now we need to modify the process structure. Let's take a look at the structure. Edit the kernel/proc.h file and go to the bottom of the file where struct proc is declared:

 84 // Per-process state
 85 struct proc {
 86   struct spinlock lock;
 87
 88   // p->lock must be held when using these:
 89   enum procstate state;        // Process state
 90   void *chan;                  // If non-zero, sleeping on chan
 91   int killed;                  // If non-zero, have been killed
 92   int xstate;                  // Exit status to be returned to parent's wait
 93   int pid;                     // Process ID
 94   int runtime;                 // Number of ticks elapsed since start of process
 95
 96   // wait_lock must be held when using this:
 97   struct proc *parent;         // Parent process
 98
 99   // these are private to the process, so p->lock need not be held.
100   uint64 kstack;               // Virtual address of kernel stack
101   uint64 sz;                   // Size of process memory (bytes)
102   pagetable_t pagetable;       // User page table
103   struct trapframe *trapframe; // data page for trampoline.S
104   struct context context;      // swtch() here to run process
105   struct file *ofile[NOFILE];  // Open files
106   struct inode *cwd;           // Current directory
107   char name[16];               // Process name (debugging)
108 };

There are three sections to this structure.

  1. The top has variables that may be accessed by other processes (lines 89-94). Any process that accesses one of these variables should hold the lock on this structure.
  2. The middle section has the pointer to the parent structure (line 97). This must be locked globally, unlike the first section. In the first section there may be only two processes that need to lock the structure, but the middle section could have any process trying to modify the parent structure.
  3. Finally the third section has variables that no other process will be accessing except the owning process (lines 100-107).

Our shares variable will be accessed by other processes when they are gathering the total number of shares. This is only a contention between the scheduling process and the owning process, so the shares variable should be assigned to the first section. Just add this line to the structure after the int runtime; line (line 94):

  int shares;                 // Share count. Added for assignment 3

This should only be one line of code.

It is critical that this variable be initialized properly. There are two places where it should be initialized:

  • The first process that is created
  • When a child process is forked

Within the source file kernel/proc.c you will find a function named userinit:

231 // Set up first user process.
232 void
233 userinit(void)
234 {
235   struct proc *p;
236
237   p = allocproc();
238   initproc = p;
239
240   // allocate one user page and copy initcode's instructions
241   // and data into it.
242   uvmfirst(p->pagetable, initcode, sizeof(initcode));
243   p->sz = PGSIZE;
244
245   // prepare for the very first "return" from kernel to user.
246   p->trapframe->epc = 0;      // user program counter
247   p->trapframe->sp = PGSIZE;  // user stack pointer
248
249   safestrcpy(p->name, "initcode", sizeof(p->name));
250   p->cwd = namei("/");
251
252   p->state = RUNNABLE;
253
254   release(&p->lock);
255 }

This function sets up and starts the first process, init. Several variables of the process structure are initialized here. Once everything is initialized, the process lock is released. You need to initialize the process shares value in this function.

You will want to set a default value for shares between the allocproc() and the release(&p->lock). I would suggest setting the shares value just before the line p->state = RUNNABLE. Set shares to 1000000. Such a high shares value will ensure that init, sh, and the parent assn3 process will run with little to no interruption when needed. One line of code added.

Even with two lines of change, you should stage and commit your code.

Copy the Parent shares Value to the Child shares

The second place to initialize the shares value is also in kernel/proc.c within the fork() function:

277 // Create a new process, copying the parent.
278 // Sets up child kernel stack to return as if from fork() system call.
279 int
280 fork(void)
281 {
282   int i, pid;
283   struct proc *np;
284   struct proc *p = myproc();
285
286   // Allocate process.
287   if((np = allocproc()) == 0){
288     return -1;
289   }
290
291   // Copy user memory from parent to child.
292   if(uvmcopy(p->pagetable, np->pagetable, p->sz) < 0){
293     freeproc(np);
294     release(&np->lock);
295     return -1;
296   }
297   np->sz = p->sz;
298
299   // copy saved user registers.
300   *(np->trapframe) = *(p->trapframe);
301
302   // Cause fork to return 0 in the child.
303   np->trapframe->a0 = 0;
304
305   // increment reference counts on open file descriptors.
306   for(i = 0; i < NOFILE; i++)
307     if(p->ofile[i])
308       np->ofile[i] = filedup(p->ofile[i]);
309   np->cwd = idup(p->cwd);
310
311   safestrcpy(np->name, p->name, sizeof(p->name));
312
313   pid = np->pid;
314
315   release(&np->lock);
316
317   acquire(&wait_lock);
318   np->parent = p;
319   release(&wait_lock);
320
321   acquire(&np->lock);
322   np->state = RUNNABLE;
323   release(&np->lock);
324
325   return pid;
326 }

The two variables that are important in this function are the p and np variables. The p variable is set to the return of myproc(), the process that is calling fork in the first place (line 284). The np variable is set to the process structure allocated for the new process by allocproc() and already has a lock acquired for the structure (line 287). Right after allocating the process structure the user memory is copied from the current process to the new process (line 292). If an error happens, then everything is reversed and an error is returned (lines 293-295). This is the only place an error can happen, so after this point is a safe place to put the shares value copy. Something simple is all that is necessary - like the line that copies the process size (line 297). Just copy the shares value from the p structure to the np structure. A great place to add this line would be just after the np->sz = p->sz line (line 297). Add one line of code.

Stage and commit your change. You'll be glad you did.

Create a Random Number Generator

The xv6 operating system does not come with a random number generator, and there is no library like the standard library to pull from. We need to write our own random number generator. I would suggest writing your new RNG in the kernel/proc.c file, right before the scheduler function. 

An easy-to-implement RNG is the xorshift generator. The algorithm is shown in C on the Wikipedia page and can be used in your code. There are several versions of this algorithm, but you should be fine with the xorshift32 function.

Please notice that the state structure is really just the last random number generated. This is extra complexity that is not necessary. Instead of using the state structure, just make the input parameter for the function the type uint32. In fact, if you name the variable x you can just eliminate all lines of code that use the structure.

If you change the input parameter of the RNG to uint32, you can make the state a local variable to the scheduler function initialized to any value you like. My favorite is:

  uint32 seed = 0xdeadbeef;

Create this variable at the top of the scheduler function, just after struct cpu *c is initialized is a good place. Then just call your function like this:

    seed = xorshift32(seed);

You will need a new random number each time the scheduler iterates over it's infinite loop. Place your call just inside this loop at the top of the loop body. Stage and commit your changes (sounding like a broken record, aren't I?).

Interlude - Compiler Optimizer Defeats Debugger

If you've added this code you should be able to compile and run xv6. If you try to debug your RNG function you will run into a problem:

0x0000000000001000 in ?? ()
(gdb) b xorshift32 
Breakpoint 1 at 0x80001ec8: file kernel/proc.c, line 433.
(gdb) c
Continuing.

The debugger will never reach your breakpoint. This is due to the fact that the Makefile is using a compile option that compiles your xv6 kernel with optimizations. One of those optimizations is unused function call elimination. In our case, we're not using the seed variable in our scheduler, and there are no side-effects. The compiler doesn't see side-effect in the use of the seed variable, so it trims all that unnecessary code. If we wish to debug our code, we need to stop this optimization. There are two ways to do it.

First, we can try causing a side-effect. The xorshift32 algorithm explicitly states that the random number seed (the value we're passing into xorshift32) should never be zero. This implies the output should also never be zero. Luckily the compiler doesn't know this. So add this line after getting a random number:

    if(seed == 0) printf("seed: %p\n", (uint64)seed);

We know the print will never be hit, because the seed variable will never be zero. But the compiler doesn't know that and sees a potential side-effect. So it will not optimize out the call to xorshift32. You should now be able to set a breakpoint on xorshift32:

0x0000000000001000 in ?? ()
(gdb) b xorshift32 
Breakpoint 1 at 0x80001ec8: file kernel/proc.c, line 433.
(gdb) c
Continuing.

Breakpoint 1, xorshift32 (x=x@entry=3735928559) at kernel/proc.c:433
435     {
(gdb) p/x x
$1 = 0xdeadbeef
(gdb) c
Continuing.

Breakpoint 1, xorshift32 (x=x@entry=1199382711) at kernel/proc.c:433
433     {
(gdb) p/x x
$4 = 0x477d20b7

Notice the seed value is now 0x477d20b7. The random number generator seems to be working.

The second method for disabling compiler optimizations is to edit the Makefile. In the Makefile you will see a line like this:

CFLAGS = -Wall -Werror -O -fno-omit-frame-pointer -ggdb

The -O switch is what is causing our debugging problems. Change the line so that optimizations are disabled by changing the switch to -O0:

CFLAGS = -Wall -Werror -O0 -fno-omit-frame-pointer -ggdb

You will want to clean your project and rebuild everything:

root@xv6:/xv6-riscv# make clean
rm -f *.tex *.dvi *.idx *.aux *.log *.ind *.ilg \
*/*.o */*.d */*.asm */*.sym \
user/initcode user/initcode.out kernel/kernel fs.img \
mkfs/mkfs .gdbinit \
        user/usys.S \
user/_cat user/_echo user/_forktest user/_grep user/_init user/_kill user/_ln user/_ls user/_mkdir user/_rm user/_sh user/_stressfs user/_usertests user/_grind user/_wc user/_zombie 
root@xv6:/xv6-riscv# make qemu-gdb

...

*** Now run 'gdb' in another window.
qemu-system-riscv64 -machine virt -bios none -kernel kernel/kernel -m 128M -smp 3 -nographic -drive file=fs.img,if=none,format=raw,id=x0 -device virtio-blk-device,drive=x0,bus=virtio-mmio-bus.0 -S -gdb tcp::25000

Now you can run gdb-multiarch, set the breakpoint on xorshift32, and continue. The breakpoint should be reached very quickly.

This change was for debugging purposes and doesn't need to be committed to your source code. This is the one time during this assignment you will be told to not bother with committing, so don't get use to it.

Write Shares-Counting Loop

The first part of the scheduler should be to count the number of shares in all the running programs. Here is the current scheduler with the random number generator code:

445 scheduler(void)
446 {
447   struct proc *p;
448   struct cpu *c = mycpu();
449   uint32 seed = 0xdeadbeef; // Initializing your random number seed
450 
451   c->proc = 0;
452   for(;;){
453     // Avoid deadlock by ensuring that devices can interrupt.
454     intr_on();
455
456     seed = xorshift32(seed); // Generating a new random number
457     uint32 rnd_num = seed; // Not necessary, but helps clarify where to find the random number
458 
459     /***** YOU MUST ADD THE RUNNABLE PROCESS COUNT LOOP HERE *****/
460     for(p = proc; p < &proc[NPROC]; p++) {
461       acquire(&p->lock);
462       if(p->state == RUNNABLE) {
463         // Switch to chosen process.  It is the process's job
464         // to release its lock and then reacquire it
465         // before jumping back to us.
466         p->state = RUNNING;
467         p->runtime++; // You should have added this line earlier in the assignment
468         c->proc = p;
469         swtch(&c->context, &p->context);
470 
471         // Process is done running for now.
472         // It should have changed its p->state before coming back.
473         c->proc = 0;
474       }
475       release(&p->lock);
476     }
477   }
478 }

At the point indicate in the code above add a counter variable and a loop that loops through every process (similar to the loop just below the comment). Make sure you are acquiring and releasing the lock just like the loop below the comment. You only want to include the share counts for processes that are RUNNABLE. Ignore everything else for now. Again, the loop below the comment shows how to test for a RUNNABLE process. When the loop is done, it should have a variable with the total number of shares of all runnable processes.

Stage and commit your first changes to the scheduler.

Write Scheduler Loop

This is just a matter of reusing the current scheduler loop. The current implementation is a simple "grab the next runnable and go" scheduler, going through every process before starting on the next process. This is a form of the Round Robin scheduler and is fairly common and relatively easy to implement.

Our scheduler is going to check if a runnable process has the random ticket that was selected. How to check for this will be an exercise for the student, but there is a video that provides an explanation. But there is one critical difference in the scheduler beyond the comparison. As mentioned above, the current scheduler operates in a round robin order. Every process gets a chance to run. The difference with our scheduler is once a process has been chosen and allowed to run, it will eventually return to this scheduler. When it returns, our scheduler starts over at the first process and selects a new ticket. We cannot allow the loop to move onto the next process in the list and test if the process has a ticket.

The solution for this is simple. We break out of the loop after the scheduled process returns. Just put a break instruction and another release after the c->proc = 0 like this:

        // Process is done running for now.
        // It should have changed its p->state before coming back.
        c->proc = 0;
        release(&p->lock);
        break;
      }      
      release(&p->lock);

This will cause the inner loop to stop looping, and allow the outer (infinite) loop to choose a new lottery ticket and schedule a new process.

What is described works but is not efficient. See if you can make a more efficient lottery scheduler.

Once you have made these changes and verified that the xv6 operating system still functions, stage and commit your changes to the scheduler.

Finish the shares System Call

To complete the assignment, finish the shares system call. I would suggest using the sys_exit system call as an example how to retrieve the integer parameter. You will likely be editing your system call function in the kernel/sysproc.c source code file.

Note that the sys_exit system call has an odd function call at the start:

 10 sys_exit(void)
 11 {
 12   int n;
 13   argint(0, &n);
 14   exit(n);
 15   return 0;  // not reached
 16 }

Any time this system call is running, it is running in the protected, or kernel mode. The operating system kernel sees memory addresses very differently than processes see memory addresses. In order to get the integer value from the user mode memory into the kernel mode memory the argint function needs to be called.

The argint function takes two parameters. First the index of the parameter. If it was the first parameter passed to the system call, then index 0 is used. If it was the second parameter, index 1, etc. Second is the address of a variable in which to store the value retrieved from user mode memory. This variable should be a function local variable or a global variable accessible in kernel mode memory. In the case of the sys_exit system call this is just a local variable. You will do something similar to get the share value send to the system call.

The sys_exit system call makes a call to another function, and you can do the same. It's not necessary, though. You can easily get the current process structure (myproc), acquire the lock, set the value, and release the lock. All in this system call function.

And remember to return 0 on success. If the argint function fails (it's return is less than zero) then return -1 to indicate an error.

Stage and commit your changes. Last time you are warned, I promise.

Processes 1 and 2 are the init program and the shell respectively. Process 3 is the main process for the lottery test. Processes 4, 5, and 6 are all children processes of the main process and all have different shares settings. If you run one iteration of the test, it will wait long enough for the child processes to be schedule enough for roughly five-times their share value. You can see in this example process 4 has 10 shares and was scheduled 48 times. Process 5 had 20 shares and was scheduled 96 times. Process 6 had 30 shares and was scheduled 158 times.

Objective:

In this assignment, you will do the following:

  • Create a new git branch called assn4 that is branched from the riscv branch.
  • Create a definition for the struct meminfo structure in a header file named kernel/meminfo.h which you will use to communicate between the kernel and the user-space program.
  • Write a user-space program in user/assn4.c that will call your new system call with a structure that will be written to by the kernel. The user space program will then print the memory statistics to the console. Add the user-space test program to the Makefile
  • Write a system call that will gather statistics about system memory and return those statistics to the user-space program in a structure provided by the user-space program.

Create Your assn4 Branch

git checkout -b assn4 origin/riscv

Warning: The next assignment will assume you know how to do this.

Layout of RISC-V Physical Memory

There is information hidden within the kernel protected mode that may be useful to our user space processes. Some of that information deals with how memory is organized within the kernel. For the xv6 operating system, memory is usually organized like this (as explained in kernel/memlayout.h):

  • Address 0x00001000: The boot ROM:
    • Provided by and run by QEMU when the system starts. Usually just jumps to the start of the kernel
  • Address 0x02000000: Core Local Interruptor (CLINT):
    • Each CPU has one and manages the timer interrupt (how long to wait and where to jump)
  • Address 0x0C000000: Platform-Level Interrupt Controller (PLIC):
    • Peripheral interrupts (keyboard, storage, etc.) will come through here on it's way to the interrupt handler
  • Address 0x10000000: Universal Asynchronous Receiver/Transmitter (UART):
    • Serial communications registers used for keyboard input and console output
  • Address 0x10001000: virtio disk:
    • Registers used to communicate to the virtualized storage provided by QEMU. This is emulated hardware
  • Address 0x80000000: Start of kernel execution
    • This is where the boot ROM (at 0x1000) jumps to in order to begin execution of the kernel

Layout of xv6 Kernel in Physical Memory

Everything after address 0x80000000 is free for the kernel to manage. The kernel breaks up memory into specific usable ranges that you will need to find the sizes of:

  • Size of kernel instructions (text section size)
  • Size of kernel data (Read-Only Data, Global Initialized, and Global Uninitialized data)
  • Size of memory that can be allocated for processes
  • Size of memory currently allocated for all processes

Addresses From User Mode Cannot Be Directly Use In Kernel Mode

There is an important distinction between the address space used by kernel-mode instruction and the address space used by user-mode instructions. To operate properly, operating system kernel instructions need to be able to address all of physical memory. This can be done by turning off the Memory Management Unit (MMU) or by creating kernel-mode page tables. Disabling the MMU also disables per-page memory protections such as the read, write, and execute bits. This is generally considered a bad idea and should be avoided. Therefore the operating system will usually have kernel-mode page tables that are a near-identical match to how the physical memory address space is laid out.

Contrast the kernel-mode memory layout to that of user-mode process memory address spaces. The virtual memory addresses used within a user-space process do not have to match how physical memory is configured. Since there is not a one-to-one match for user-space addresses to kernel-space addresses, any pointer coming to the kernel from user-space via a system call cannot be immediately used by kernel-mode instructions. Some form of address translation needs to happen within the kernel code to get the correct physical address.

For your system call, you will write a system call function that will receive a pointer from the user-space process. To the kernel this value is just a very large integer (uint64) and cannot be used as a pointer until translated. In this assignment you will use two kernel functions that help handle pointers from a user-space program:

  • getaddr(int, uint64 *): This function will read the user-space pointer value from user-space memory and store the value into a 64-bit unsigned integer variable. This is just a number to the kernel. Don't try to use it as a pointer!
  • copyout(pagetable_t, uint64, char *, uint64): This function will write data from kernel memory into the virtual address space of the user process. The first two parameters are used to translate the user-space address into a physical address, and the second two parameters are the pointer and length of the data to copy from kernel memory into user-space virtual memory

Add struct meminfo to a kernel header

There are system calls where the kernel needs to write data into the memory of a user-space process. A good example of this is the stat system call. This system call allows the kernel to write information about a file into user-space memory. The memory that is being written is defined by a data structure struct stat. You can see this structure in the file kernel/stat.h.

For the system call you will write, a structure data type must be defined that will hold the data that will be shared with the user-space process. The system call function will allocate memory in the kernel stack (local variable) for the structure, write values to that structure, then copy the entire structure memory from kernel memory into the process virtual memory.

Create a new file named kernel/meminfo.h and add the following structure definition to this file:

struct meminfo {
  uint32 kerneltextsize;
  uint32 kerneldatasize;
  uint32 totalallocsize;
  uint32 totalprocsize;
  uint32 freememory;
  uint32 currentprocsize;
};

You will include this header in both your user-space test program as well as in the kernel system call function.

Create the User-Space Test Program

You need to create a new test program in user/assn4.c that includes the following headers:

  • kernel/types.h   // Must be included before the meminfo.h header
  • kernel/meminfo.h // Contains the structure definition your test program will use
  • user/user.h      // Contains the system call declaration to get memory information

Create the basic main function that prints the program name and your name. Add it to the Makefile and make sure it builds and runs in xv6.

Now add the code that defines an instance of the struct meminfo and make sure it compiles. You will use this structure as a parameter to your new system call. Add the lines of code that will print the structure values. Build it and run it. You should see something like this:

$ assn4
assn4 by John Jolly
                 Section Size
------------------------ ----
Kernel Text Segment Size 0
Kernel Data Segment Size 0
 Kernel Allocatable Size 0
Process Allocated Memory 0
             Free Memory 0
    Current Process Size 0

Don't worry if you're getting different values for your output right now. You haven't written the code to modify the structure. In fact, your test program will not be writing anything to this structure. That's the purpose of the system call you will write.

Now add the call to your system call. You want to send the structure in as a reference. If you declared your meminfo structure variable as minfo, your call should look like this:

int err = getminfo(&minfo);

Make sure you check the err variable for a negative value. That will indicate that something went wrong.

Creating the System Call Function

Your getminfo system call signature should look like this:

struct meminfo;
int getminfo(struct meminfo *);

Remember that the actual system call function in the kernel will look different from this. This function declaration identifies the parameters that the system call is expecting. The actual system call handler function in the xv6 kernel will not have any parameters, so you will need to get the address of the user-space struct meminfo structure by using the argaddr(int, uint64 *) function. It takes two parameters:

  • The index of the argument to retrieve
    • There's only one argument, so there's only one possibility. Remember we're working with zero-based indexes)
  • A pointer to a uint64 which will contain the address.

The sys_wait function in kernel/sysproc.c is a great example of how to make this work.

To get the memory information into the user-space process, your system call function needs to have a corresponding structure allocated in kernel memory. You can do this by declaring a local variable of type struct meminfo just like you did in your test program. Assign the appropriate values into this local structure, then use the copyout function to copy the values in the local structure to the structure in user-space pointed to by the address received by the argaddr function. The copyout signature looks something like this:

int                                                   
copyout(pagetable_t pagetable, uint64 dstva, char *src, uint64 len);

You will get the pagetable from the process structure pagetable variable (the myproc() function will help here). The dstva is the uint64 value you retrieved from user-space using the argaddr function. The src is the address to the local meminfo structure variable you just populated with data. The len parameter is the size of the meminfo structure (you can find the size of any datatype by using the sizeof operation).

In short, this function copies len bytes of data from src to the virtual address dstva that can be found in kernel memory by walking the process pagetable.

Calculating Memory Statistics

You can fill in the structure by calculating the memory statistics by observing:

  • What is the difference between KERNBASE found in kernel/memlayout.h and etext that is generated at compile time by the code in kernel/kernel.ld
    • This will be the size of the text (code) segment of our kernel 
    • The etext variable will not be accessible to your system call function until you declare extern char etext[];
    • You can also write a function in the kernel/vm.c that performs the calculation for you. This is because etext is declared extern within that file.
  • What is the difference between etext and end as generated within kernel/kernel.ld
    • This will be the size of the read-only and global variables of our kernel
    • You have the same problem with end as you did with etext. Declare it extern in the same source as your system call function
    • As with etext, you can write a function in kernel/vm.c that performs this calculation for you.
  • What is the difference between end and the maximum kernel memory as specified by PHYSTOP
    • This will be the kernel allocatable size
    • The PHYSTOP macro is defined in kernel/memlayout.h, which should be included in the system call source
  • What is the sum of sizes (the sz variable) for every process structure that is not UNUSED
    • You can access the array of processes one of two ways:
      • Create a function in kernel/proc.c that loops through the process array, summing the sz variables of all processes that are not UNUSED
      • Declare proc extern to the system call source and create your summing loop in the system call function
    • The size variable in the process structure needs the process structure lock to be acquired before being read. This is documented in the process structure definition in kernel/proc.h
    • How do you loop through all the processes? How do you check if a process structure is UNUSED?
  • You now have the total memory, the space taken by the kernel, and the space taken by the processes. What is left is the free space.
  • What is the current process size
    • Obtained from the current process structure.\
      • What function do you call to get the current process structure?

Tasks:

Here is a list of things you will need to accomplish for this assignment:

  • Create the getminfo system call
    • This system call will take one parameter: a pointer to a struct meminfo structure
  • Calculate the kernel text segment and data segment sizes
  • Calculate the total allocatable memory available to the xv6 operating system kernel
  • Calculate the total memory used by all active processes
  • Calculate the total free memory of the system
  • Calculate the current process size
  • Populate a local struct meminfo structure variable with the values found above
  • Copy the entire local struct meminfo structure variable from kernel memory into the user-space struct meminfo structure variable
  • Return success from the system call if there were no problems. Return -1 otherwise

Hints:

  • You will be access data all over the kernel: from kernel/vm.c to kernel/memlayout.h and more. There are many ways to get this information, and I will leave it up to you, the student, to figure out how to get that information.
    • The most reliable way is to create "getter" functions in the various source modules and call those functions from your system call to get the values. Remember to add any new functions declarations to kernel/defs.h so they are "visible" to other source modules.
    • Declaring variables as extern in the system call handler source file is another way
  • When looping through the processes, acquire and release the process structure lock when accessing any data members.
  • You will need to use type casting to convert data types. Specifically:
    • The etext and end values are pointers and need to be cast to uint64 before any math can be done
    • The reference to the struct meminfo structure will need to be cast to a character pointer in the copyout function

Objective:

In this assignment you will create a new system call in the xv6 OS. This system call will provide a page of shared memory to a process as identified by a numeric identifier. By the end of this assignment you should be able to:

  • Allocate and initialize a fixed number of memory pages to be used by user processes
  • Assign a page allocated by the kernel to the page table of a user process
  • Copy a user process page table without copying any assigned shared memory page
  • Free the page table of a user process without freeing any assigned shared memory pages

Details:

Getting set up

1. Create an assn5 branch based from origin/riscv

You should be comfortable doing this now.

2. Create shmem system call

The signature of the system call is char *shmem(int). Also write an empty system call function that returns an error value of 0.

3. Create user/assn5.c test program

Specifically, this:

#include"kernel/types.h"
#include"user/user.h"

#define NULL (void *)0
#define MAXCOUNT (1000000)

#define ID_P (0)
#define ID_1 (1)
#define ID_2 (2)

#define STATE_WAIT (0)
#define STATE_INIT (1)
#define STATE_FINI (2)

#define SHARED_GLOBAL (1)
#define SHARED_THREAD (2)

int main(int argc, char * argv[]) {
  printf("assn5 shared memory by John Jolly\n");
  int *s1 = (int *)shmem(SHARED_GLOBAL);
  if(s1 == NULL) {
    printf("Error getting shared memory 1\n");
    exit(1);
  }
  // These state variables communicate information between processes
  // Only the owning process may write to it's variable, all other
  // process can only read
  s1[ID_P] = STATE_WAIT;
  s1[ID_1] = STATE_WAIT;
  s1[ID_2] = STATE_WAIT;
  int pid1 = fork();
  if(pid1 == 0) {
    int *s2 = (int *)shmem(SHARED_THREAD);
    if(s2 == NULL) {
      printf("Error getting shared memory 2 in child 1\n");
      exit(1);
    }
    // The first child is responsible for initializing the memory shared
    // between children.
    *s2 = 0;
    // When initialization is done, the first child "signals" the second.
    s1[ID_1] = STATE_INIT;
    // Now wait for the parent to start the "race"
    while(s1[ID_P] == STATE_WAIT);
    // This does not fail properly if the compiler is using the -O switch.
    // To cause this to fail spectacularly, set the switch to -O0.
    for(int i = 0; i < MAXCOUNT; i++) (*s2)++;
    // Set the first child status to "complete"
    s1[ID_1] = STATE_FINI;
    exit(0);
  }
  int pid2 = fork();
  if(pid2 == 0) {
    int *s2 = (int *)shmem(SHARED_THREAD);
    if(s2 == NULL) {
      printf("Error getting shared memory 2 in child 2\n");
      exit(1);
    }
    // The second child waits for both the parent's signal to start as
    // well as the first child's signal that shared memory is initialized.
    while(s1[ID_P] == STATE_WAIT);
    // Make sure the Makefile has the optimize switch set to -O0
    for(int i = 0; i < MAXCOUNT; i++) (*s2)--;
    // Set the second child status to "complete"
    s1[ID_2] = STATE_FINI;
    exit(0);
  }
  // Wait for the first child to complete initialization
  while(s1[ID_1] != STATE_INIT);
  // Tell the children to start the race
  s1[ID_P] = STATE_INIT;
  // Wait for the children to complete
  while(s1[ID_1] != STATE_FINI || s1[ID_2] != STATE_FINI);
  // O
  int *s2 = (int *)shmem(SHARED_THREAD);
  if(s2 == NULL) {
    printf("Error getting shared memory 2\n");
    exit(1);
  }
  // The result should be zero if everything was synchronized
  printf("The results are: %d\n", *s2);
  exit(0);
}

If you are attempting to copy-and-paste this code into VIM, you will want to follow these steps:

  1. In VIM, type the command :set paste
    • This will cause the Insert mode to accept the paste verbatim and not perform any fancy formatting
  2. Enter the Insert mode
    • You should see the prompt read -- INSERT (paste) --
  3. Copy and paste the code into VIM
  4. Exit Insert mode
  5. Type the command :set nopaste
    • Any new inserts will use the usual formatting helps provided by VIM

5. Turn off optimizations in the Makefile

Compiler optimization will cause problems with this assignment. You need to turn off optimizations by changing the -O (capital O) switch on line 59 to -O0 (Capital O, zero). The line should look like this when you're done:

CFLAGS = -Wall -Werror -O0 -fno-omit-frame-pointer -ggdb -gdwarf-2

4. Add _assn5 to UPROGS in the Makefile

You should be able to build and run the test program. When you run the assn5 program you should expect it to fail

Adding the shared memory functionality

The design requirements for shared memory are:

  • System should provide four or more individual pages of memory in total
    • Pages should be identified using an integer between 0 and one less than the total pages
    • For example, if four pages are provided, then they should be identified using 0, 1, 2, and 3
  • Shared memory pages should persist after a process terminates
  • Shared memory pages should persist in the virtual address space of both parent and child processes after calling fork

Hints on implementation

  • System should pre-allocate shared memory pages during kernel startup (Mr. Jolly's Implementation: 6 lines)
    • This can be done using a function created in kernel/vm.c specifically for this purpose
    • All it should do is call kalloc for each share page and assign the address to an array
  • When the system call is made, the identified shared page should be added to the process page table (Mr. Jolly's Implementation: 14 lines)
    • Create a new function in kernel/proc.c that finds the process page table, sends it to the shared memory allocator, and updates any struct proc variables
      • You may be tempted to perform page mapping functionality here. Try to avoid that temptation. The kernel/proc.c file is intended for process related activity, not for page table manipulation.
    • Create a new function in kernel/vm.c that assigns the identified page to the process table
      • Avoid adding process-related functionality here. This file does not "know" about the process structure, and shouldn't. 
      • You will use the mappages(pagetable, virtual_addr, num_pages, physical_addr, permissions) api to assign a physical page frame address to a process page table.
        • pagetable - You should use the pagetable of the process that can be accessed by the function in kernel/proc.c
        • virtual_addr - Again, the process should know which virtual address is available. This can either be a static address near the highest address in memory, or simply where the current end of heap memory is for the process
        • num_pages - Just assign one page at a time to the process
        • physical_addr - The physical address should have been allocated during the kernel startup
        • permissions - Set this to PTE_U | PTE_R | PTE_W
    • The system call should return the virtual address of the first byte of the page
      • This should be the virtual address determined by your system call
      • The function calls should be system call function → process shared memory allocator → virtual memory shared page mapper
  • When a process terminates, any shared pages should not be freed with the kfree api (Mr. Jolly's Implementation: 4 lines)
    • Specifically, don't let the call to kfree in kernel/vm.c at line 188 happen when the physical page frame address in pa matches the physical page frame address of one of the shared pages
    • Should be a simple loop to check your share page frame array
  • When a process forks, and shared pages should not be copied with the memmove api (Mr. Jolly's implementation: 8 lines)
    • Specifically, don't let the call to memmove in kernel/vm.c at line 322 happen when the physical page frame address in pa matches the physical page frame address of one of the shared pages
    • The preceding call to kalloc should also not happen when a shared page is found
    • The following call to mappages should still happen though
      • Be careful of the error condition for mappages. It performs a kfree on the physical page frame on error, which is a really bad idea for shared pages
