Points Description
5 points Assignment pushed to Bitbucket repository and based off origin/riscv
5 points Code compiles without error
5 points Test program user/assn5 added and matches what is given here
5 points System call char *shmem(int) is implemented 
5 points  System call char *shmem(int) returns pointer to shared memory
5 points Shared memory not freed when process terminates
5 points Shared memory not copied during call to fork
5 points The assn5 test program runs successfully (random results produced)

Submit 

Objective:

In this assignment you will provide system calls that will help fix the race condition from Assignment 5. You will need to add three system calls to initialize, lock, and unlock a mutex. The system calls will guarantee mutual exclusion after the call to lock for a specific mutex.

Details:

Starting Your Assignment 6 Branch

You will need to start this assignment using the changes to made for Assignment 5. The command for this is:

git checkout -b assn6 student/assn5

This command will checkout, from the assn5 branch, a new assn6 branch. You may now make changes, stage, commit, and push those changes as you have done with previous assignments

Writing Your Test Program

You will create a new test program at user/assn6.c

Your test program will do the following:

  • Obtain a shared memory page and initialize an integer in that page to zero.
    • Allocate a shared page using the shmem system call created in Assignment 5. It doesn't matter which page you allocate, but remain consistent.
  • Launch two child processes using the fork system call:
    • One child will increment the shared memory integer one million times
    • The other child will decrement the shared memory integer one million times
    • Be aware that the unary increment and decrement operators take precedence before the pointer dereference operator. This means *nval++ is an error. If you want to use the pointer dereferece operator, surround it with parantheses like (*nval)++ and you shouldn't have any problems.
    • You can also do nval[0]++ as the index operator takes precedence before the unary increment/decrement operators
  • The parent will wait for each child to complete
  • The parent will display the value of the integer in shared memory

Remember to add your user program in the appropriate place within the Makefile and run it. You should expect a similar output to this:

xv6 kernel is booting

hart 1 starting
hart 2 starting
init: starting sh
$ assn6
assn6 Share Memory Test Program by John Jolly
Total after loops: 167058
$ assn6
assn6 Share Memory Test Program by John Jolly
Total after loops: -67521

Note your output will almost certainly not match the output above, but that's the point. You have written code that has a race condition. You will create a new system call that will provide a mutex to lock the critical section of your new code.

If you are seeing output remotely close to what is shown in the example above, stage and commit your changes in your local git repository.

Fixing Your Broken Test Program

Your test program has critical sections that need to be protected with locks. Specifically, you have two threads - one that increments and one that decrements. Is is that increment and decrement code that is the critical section, so a simple mutex should solve our problem.

Part 1: Adding The Stub Mutex System Calls API (~30 lines of code)

  • In this section you will:
    • Create three system calls: mutex init, mutex lock, and mutex unlock

In order to provide mutual exclusion, you will create three system call APIs that will have the following functionality:

  • Mutex Initialization - This system call will allocate an internal data structure that will keep track of the lock state.
    • It will take no parameters and return a handle to the internal data structure.
    • I'm leaving the naming of the system call to you. While there is no required name for this system call (I'm hoping you'll come up with something original), you are welcome to use the overly-large initialize_mutex_handle. Please try to be more terse that your instructor.
  • Mutex Lock - This system call will lock the mutex specified.
    • The system call takes one parameter - the preallocated handle obtained from a call to the mutex initializer.
    • The lock system call should return 0 on success and -1 if there's an error condition.
    • The system call will only return if the lock is successfully acquired or there's an error. Otherwise it will block until the lock is released by another process.
    • Again, use a name that makes sense, or burden yourself with the unnecessarily long lock_mutual_exculsion_handle.
  • Mutex Unlock - This system call will unlock the mutex specified
    • The system call takes one parameter - the preallocated handle from the mutex initializer.
    • The unlock system call should return 0 on success and -1 if there's an error condition.
    • This system call should return immediately - no blocking.
    • Your system call name should make sense, but probably not as long as unlock_mutual_exclusion_handle.

You will start by creating stub system call functions. Remember the steps to create a system call (you'll need to follow these steps three times for each of the three system calls described above):

  • Edit user/user.h - Add function declarations for your system calls. (1 line of code per syscall)
  • Edit user/usys.pl - Add an entry line with the name of each of your system calls. (1 line of code per system call)
  • Edit kernel/syscall.h - Add a #define that gives each of your system calls a number. (1 line of code per system call)
  • Edit kernel/syscall.c - Associate your system call number to the system call function within the syscalls array (2 lines of code per system call)
  • Edit kernel/sysproc.c - Add your system call function definitions here. (5 lines of code per system call)

Once those five steps are followed, you should have a buildable system call. Try running xv6 and see if everything builds successfully. Take care to resolve any build errors now, starting with the first error. When you fix the first error, try your build again. Repeat until you've fixed all the build problems.

You are welcome to run your assn6 test program but don't expect any different result. You haven't modified assn6 to use your system calls yet. That's the next step.

Part 2: Modify user/assn6.c (5 lines of code)

  • In this section you will
    • Call the mutex initialize system call and store the handle
    • Call lock and unlock around each critical section using the handle previously obtained

Now you need to modify the user/assn6.c source code to use your new mutex system calls. First you should call your mutex initializer before the forks and assign the result to an integer variable like this int mutex = get_an_initialized_mutex_handle();. I hope your system call name is not that obnoxious. You want to make this call before the fork.

When the handle is acquired before the fork (I did mention this, I hope), then the mutex handle will exist in both the parent and the child processes after the fork. This will make it useful for locking and unlocking in different processes later. If the mutex allocation is performed after the fork, then the parent and child processes will have different mutexes and a lock on one mutex will not affect the other mutex.

Now we need to lock the mutex before our critical section and unlock the mutex after our critical section. Something simple like lock_the_mutex_handle(mutex); before both of the increment and decrement operations. Then call unlock_the_mutex_handle(mutex); after the increment and decrement. If your system call names are as long as I am demonstrating here, then you haven't been paying attention to my snarky comments.

Where you place the lock and unlock calls is important. You should only surround the critical sections of your code. Do not protect anything that is not part of your critical section. You will lose points if you lock anything that is not part of the critical section of your code!

Please note that the API as describe above have error values being returned from lock and unlock. While it's not necessary to check this in this code (we're not deviating from the normal here), you would be wise to check for error returns and handle them accordingly (such as exiting the program). Validating return values is a good habit to form as a programmer.

Part 3: Adding a spinlock for our mutex (3 lines of code)

  • In this section you will
    • Define a spinlock variable
    • Initialize the spinlock on kernel startup
    • Declare the spinlock extern in the same file as your system call functions

In order for our locks to work properly, we will be using the built-in spinlock functionality of the kernel. This functionality is exposed through the acquire and release calls available inside the kernel. The release call is very simple, but the acquire function is where the real work happens. If you look at the acquire code in kernel/spinlock.c you'll see:

 19 // Acquire the lock.
 20 // Loops (spins) until the lock is acquired.
 21 void
 22 acquire(struct spinlock *lk)
 23 {
 24   push_off(); // disable interrupts to avoid deadlock.
 25   if(holding(lk))
 26     panic("acquire");
 27
 28   // On RISC-V, sync_lock_test_and_set turns into an atomic swap:
 29   //   a5 = 1
 30   //   s1 = &lk->locked
 31   //   amoswap.w.aq a5, a5, (s1)
 32   while(__sync_lock_test_and_set(&lk->locked, 1) != 0)
 33     ;
 34
 35   // Tell the C compiler and the processor to not move loads or stores
 36   // past this point, to ensure that the critical section's memory
 37   // references happen strictly after the lock is acquired.
 38   // On RISC-V, this emits a fence instruction.
 39   __sync_synchronize();
 40
 41   // Record info about lock acquisition for holding() and debugging.
 42   lk->cpu = mycpu();
 43 }

Notice at line 32 that the hardware atomic test-and-set intrinsic operation is used. This is useful for us as we do not need to duplicate effort to use hardware atomic operations.

The mutex system call code you write must use a spinlock to protect a new critical section you will create. To use the acquire and release functions, we need to declare a spinlock variable. Our spinlock need to be initialized when the kernel starts up. There are several places for this, but not in kernel/sysproc.c where our system call functions are located. I recommend adding the spinlock variable and initialization in the kernel/proc.c source file. There are several examples how to declare a spinlock such as pid_lock on line 16 and wait_lock on line 27:

 16 struct spinlock pid_lock;
 17
 18 extern void forkret(void);
 19 static void freeproc(struct proc *p);
 20
 21 extern char trampoline[]; // trampoline.S
 22
 23 // helps ensure that wakeups of wait()ing
 24 // parents are not lost. helps obey the
 25 // memory model when using p->parent.
 26 // must be acquired before any p->lock.
 27 struct spinlock wait_lock;

I suggest adding your spinlock after line 27 but before the process initialization function procinit found starting a line 45. Give a name that is shorter than mutex_data_spinlock.

You will need to initialized the spinlock when the kernel is starting up. The main function for our kernel (located oddly enough in kernel/main.c) calls several initialization functions for various parts of our kernel. We could always create our own initialization function, or we could piggy-back on one that already exists. For this assignment we'll choose the procinit function found in the kernel/proc.c kernel source file. In the procinit function:

 45 // initialize the proc table at boot time.
 46 void
 47 procinit(void)
 48 {
 49   struct proc *p;
 50
 51   initlock(&pid_lock, "nextpid");
 52   initlock(&wait_lock, "wait_lock");
 53   for(p = proc; p < &proc[NPROC]; p++) {
 54       initlock(&p->lock, "proc");
 55       p->kstack = KSTACK((int) (p - proc));
 56   }
 57 }

Notice how nextpid on line 51 and wait_lock on line 52 are initialized. Initialize your shorter-than-mutex_data_spinlock variable similar to the other lock initialization. The second parameter is just a readable name for the spinlock and can easily just be the same as the variable name, similar to line 52. Remember to pass a reference to your spinlock as the first parameter, otherwise you will get a compile error.

One last change for our new spinlock is to make the variable visible to our system call functions in kernel/sysproc.c. If your spinlock is named mutex_data_spinlock (I hope not), you need to add this line to the top (but somewhere after #include "spinlock.c") of kernel/sysproc.c:

extern struct spinlock mutex_data_spinlock;

Part 4: Adding the Mutex Data Structure (~4 lines of code)

  • In this section you will:
    • Define an array for the states of your mutexes
    • Initialize your mutex state array

The spinlock is intended to lock a data structure that will contain our mutex lock state. To best decide what data type to use for our mutex, we need to know what is being stored. A mutex lock can be represented by it's state. There are only three states our lock can be in:

  • Unallocated - This state means the mutex has not been allocated by a call to your initialize mutex system call
  • Unlocked - This state means the mutex is allocated, but the lock system call has not been called
  • Locked - This state means the mutex is allocated and the locked is held by a process

We can represent each state as a simple integer value: Zero (0) for uninitialized, one (1) for unlocked, and two (2) for locked. This can easily fit in the unsigned character type. Multiple mutexes can be stored within a character array. When defining an array of a specific size, it's wise to define the size of the array with a macro - similar to the NPROC macro. The assn6 test program only opens one mutex, but more would be wise.

In the kernel/proc.h header file, add this line to define our mutex count to 32:

#define NMUTEX 32

Now we can create our mutex data structure - which really is an array of characters with a size of NMUTEX. Put this into the kernel/proc.c source code file:

unsigned char mutex_count_array[NMUTEX];

and add a loop to the procinit function that sets each array element to zero. Do not miss this step as uninitialized data is always bad.

In order for our system call functions to be able to use this character array, we need to declare it in kernel/sysproc.c just like what was done for the spinlock. Add this line before your system call functions:

extern unsigned char mutex_count_array[];

Notice the lack of an actual size for the array. We already defined the size in kernel/proc.c. All that needs to be known here is that this is an array of unsigned char type. Now your system call functions can directly access the mutex_count_array. Again, without this line you will get a compile error.

Part 5: Understanding how to Use the xv6 Spinlock Like a Condition Variable (No Code Writing Necessary)

Now for the tricky part. How do we use our spinlock? In our three system call function, we need to use the spinlock like this:

  • Mutex Init - The spinlock should be acquired before checking for an unallocated mutex and remain allocated until the mutex is set to unlocked. This way we don't have a race condition where multiple processes are trying to allocate a mutex.
  • Mutex Lock - This will be tricky. The spinlock should be acquired and the mutex state should be tested for a locked state. If the mutex is locked, the process needs to be stopped until some other process unlocks the mutex - but how do we cause this interprocess communication?
  • Mutex Unlock - The spinlock should be acquired before setting the mutex state to unlocked. Somehow after the mutex is set to unlocked this process needs to signal any processes blocked waiting that they can check the mutex again. Again, what can we use to do this?

There is communication between the Lock and Unlock system call functions that needs to be implemented. Fortunately for us, the xv6 operating system has this "condition-variable-like" functionality.

Consider how a parent process will wait for a child to exit by using the wait function. This function does not return until a child process has terminated. This sounds just like the functionality we need - some way to stop one process while waiting for another process to complete a task. In our case it's the lock system call waiting for the unlock system call to unlock the mutex. Let's look at the wait function in kernel/proc.c:

381 // Wait for a child process to exit and return its pid.
382 // Return -1 if this process has no children.
383 int
384 wait(uint64 addr)
385 {
386   struct proc *np;
387   int havekids, pid;
388   struct proc *p = myproc();
389
390   acquire(&wait_lock);
391
392   for(;;){
393     // Scan through table looking for exited children.
394     havekids = 0;
395     for(np = proc; np < &proc[NPROC]; np++){
396       if(np->parent == p){
397         // make sure the child isn't still in exit() or swtch().
398         acquire(&np->lock);
399
400         havekids = 1;
401         if(np->state == ZOMBIE){
402           // Found one.
403           pid = np->pid;
404           if(addr != 0 && copyout(p->pagetable, addr, (char *)&np->xstate,
405                                   sizeof(np->xstate)) < 0) {
406             release(&np->lock);
407             release(&wait_lock);
408             return -1;
409           }
410           freeproc(np);
411           release(&np->lock);
412           release(&wait_lock);
413           return pid;
414         }
415         release(&np->lock);
416       }
417     }
418
419     // No point waiting if we don't have any children.
420     if(!havekids || p->killed){
421       release(&wait_lock);
422       return -1;
423     }
424
425     // Wait for a child to exit.
426     sleep(p, &wait_lock);  //DOC: wait-sleep
427   }
428 }

Don't panic. There's not a lot going on here. Here is the step-by-step analysis:

  • The wait_lock is acquired on line 390
  • An infinite spinloop is started. This loop will keep going as long as this process has at least one child, or has not been killed by another process (see lines 420-423)
  • Loop through all the processes (line 395) looking for a process that has the current process as a parent (line 396).
  • When a child process is found, acquire the child process lock (line 398) to check if it's a ZOMBIE process (line 401)
    • Remember, a process in the ZOMBIE state has terminated via the exit function and is waiting for the parent to clean up after it
  • If a dead child is found, copy the exit state of the child into the integer variable reference (lines 404-405) used as a parameter for the wait system call made by the user-space program.
    • Computer science is great. Where else can we talk about a "dead child" without feeling existential remorse?
  • Free the child process process (line 410) and return the process ID of the child to the caller of wait (line 413)
  • If there are no children to this current process, or it has been killed by another process, exit the function (including the infinite loop) with an error value (lines 425-428))
  • If none of the above cause wait to return, then sleep - here's the spinlock tool we can use in the mutex code!

This specific call to sleep on line 426 takes two parameters: the pointer to the current process structure and a reference to the wait_lock. Let's take a look at the function signature for sleep found in the kernel/defs.h header file:

 99 void            sleep(void*, struct spinlock*);

The second parameter makes sense, but what is the deal with the first parameter? It is type void *. This means that an address pointer to any data structure is allowed here. It can be a pointer to literally anything, an integer, a pointer to a float, a pointer to a struct proc (like how sleep is called in wait), anything. This pointer to "anything" is actually used as a unique reference value for the function that will cause sleep to "wake up" and return to the caller. Let's take a look at the function that causes the wait function to wake up - the exit function in the kernel/proc.c source file:

336 // Exit the current process.  Does not return.
337 // An exited process remains in the zombie state
338 // until its parent calls wait().
339 void
340 exit(int status)
341 {
342   struct proc *p = myproc();
343
344   if(p == initproc)
345     panic("init exiting");
346
347   // Close all open files.
348   for(int fd = 0; fd < NOFILE; fd++){
349     if(p->ofile[fd]){
350       struct file *f = p->ofile[fd];
351       fileclose(f);
352       p->ofile[fd] = 0;
353     }
354   }
355
356   begin_op();
357   iput(p->cwd);
358   end_op();
359   p->cwd = 0;
360
361   acquire(&wait_lock);
362
363   // Give any children to init.
364   reparent(p);
365
366   // Parent might be sleeping in wait().
367   wakeup(p->parent);
368
369   acquire(&p->lock);
370
371   p->xstate = status;
372   p->state = ZOMBIE;
373
374   release(&wait_lock);
375
376   // Jump into the scheduler, never to return.
377   sched();
378   panic("zombie exit");
379 }

Let's walk through this function:

  • First, make sure it's not the init process that's exiting (lines 344-345). If init exits, then our operating system no longer can operate.
  • Close all the open files for the process (lines 347-354).
  • Decrement the reference count to the current working directory (lines 356-359). More will be discussed about this in later modules.
  • Acquire the wait_lock (line 361). This is spinlock is held until the release on line 374
  • If this process has any children, reassign those children to the init process on line 364 (this is why init can never exit)
  • Call wakeup using the pointer to the parent process structure - this is what we're looking for!
  • Save the exit status (line 371), set the process to the ZOMBIE state (line 372), release wait_lock (line 374), and "schedule" the process (line 377)
    • This really doesn't cause the process to be scheduled to run on a CPU. Remember that only RUNNABLE processes are allow to be scheduled, and this process is no longer anything except a ZOMBIE process.

Notice the parameter that is used for the wakeup call - the pointer to the parent process structure. This is the same pointer that is used by the wait function to go to sleep. This is critically important for you to understand the relationship between sleep and wakeup. Every process that calls sleep stores the "reference" value in the first parameter so it may be looked up when another process calls wakeup. When a process is found to contain that "reference" value (xv6 calls it a "channel"), that process is allowed to be rescheduled. You can see this in the sleep and wakeup function in kernel/proc.c:

526 // Atomically release lock and sleep on chan.
527 // Reacquires lock when awakened.
528 void
529 sleep(void *chan, struct spinlock *lk)
530 {
531   struct proc *p = myproc();
532
533   // Must acquire p->lock in order to
534   // change p->state and then call sched.
535   // Once we hold p->lock, we can be
536   // guaranteed that we won't miss any wakeup
537   // (wakeup locks p->lock),
538   // so it's okay to release lk.
539
540   acquire(&p->lock);  //DOC: sleeplock1
541   release(lk);
542
543   // Go to sleep.
544   p->chan = chan;
545   p->state = SLEEPING;
546
547   sched();
548
549   // Tidy up.
550   p->chan = 0;
551
552   // Reacquire original lock.
553   release(&p->lock);
554   acquire(lk);
555 }
556
557 // Wake up all processes sleeping on chan.
558 // Must be called without any p->lock.
559 void
560 wakeup(void *chan)
561 {
562   struct proc *p;
563
564   for(p = proc; p < &proc[NPROC]; p++) {
565     if(p != myproc()){
566       acquire(&p->lock);
567       if(p->state == SLEEPING && p->chan == chan) {
568         p->state = RUNNABLE;
569       }
570       release(&p->lock);
571     }
572   }
573 }

Notice that sleep releases the spinlock (line 541) before it sets the process to the SLEEPING state and "schedules" it. When another process sets the sleeping process back to RUNNABLE by calling wakeup (line 568), the process will return to re-acquire it's lock (line 554) before returning from sleep. This way, the spinlock can be acquired before calling sleep and we can expect the spinlock to still be locked when sleep returns.

Part 6: Using sleep and wakeup in the Mutex Code (~15-20 lines of code)

  • In this section you will:
    • Write the code to lock a mutex
    • Write the code to unlock a mutex

Assume that the mutex state array is named mutex_state_array and the spinlock for the state array is named mutex_state_array_lock (I'm hoping my use of long variable names has encouraged you to shorten yours). The following needs to happen in the mutex lock code:

  • Get the integer ID of the mutex passed in as a parameter to the system call (using argint)
  • Acquire the mutex spinlock by calling acquire(&mutex_state_array_lock);
  • Loop as long as the indexed mutex is set to a locked state. This will be checking if mutex_state_array[index] == MUTEX_IS_LOCKED
  • Inside the loop, sleep using a reference to the specific element in the mutex_state_array and the spinlock that has been acquired. It will looks something like this: sleep(&mutex_state_array[index], &mutex_state_array_lock);
  • Outside the loop set the mutex state to locked
  • Release the mutex spinlock by calling release(&mutex_state_array_lock);
  • Return from the system call with a success code

One thing missing here is validating the index value passed into the system call. This validation should happen after the index is retrieved with the argint call but before the mutex spinlock is acquired. You should check that the integer is within the bounds of the mutex state array, or between 0 and NMUTEX.

Always validate the parameters coming into a system call. When writing kernel code never trust parameters coming from user space. Ever. Seriously.

Now consider the code for the unlock system call:

  • Get the integer ID of the mutex passed in as a parameter to the system call (again, using argint. Don't forget to validate the index)
  • Acquire the mutex spinlock (same as the lock)
  • Set the mutex state to unlocked
  • Release the mutex spinlock (same as the lock)
  • Call wakeup with the same reference used when the call to sleep was made. It's the first parameter of sleep.

You might wonder if it's appropriate to release the spinlock before calling wakeup. This is actually so the freshly-awakened process does not suddenly have to wait for the spinlock just when it was getting started. If the wakeup call was made before release, there's a chance the scheduler will interrupt in between the two calls and allow the other process to start. This would cause the other process to reach the spinlock acquire and have to wait for the interrupted process to be rescheduled to release the spinlock. Simple efficiency.

Part 7: Finishing up with the Initialize Mutex System Call (~10 lines of code)

  • In this section you will:
    • Write the mutex initialization function

The initialize system call is very simple:

  • Acquire the mutex spinlock
  • Loop through each element from 0 to NMUTEX in the mutex state array looking for an unallocated mutex
  • If one cannot be found, release the spinlock and return an error condition
  • If one is found, set the mutex state to unlocked
  • Release the spinlock and return the index into the mutex state array
    • This index is the "mutex handle" that the process will use to call lock and unlock

Part 8: Run the assn6 test program

Now you can test your mutex code by executing the assn6 program in xv6.

xv6 kernel is booting

hart 1 starting
hart 2 starting
init: starting sh
$ assn6
assn6 Shared Memory Test Program by John Jolly
Total after loops: 0
Success! Increments match decrements!

Warning: When you use your working mutex locks, the code will slow down significantly. My test program runs nearly ten minutes before showing a working result. My suggestion to you is to change the MAX_LOOP macro at the top (line 4) of the source file at user/assn6.c to something less that 1000000 to verify everything is working. Try 100. If that works, go back up to 1000000 and wait to see if you are successful. Expect it to be slow.

Extra Credit:

There are several chances for extra credit in this assignment. Here are the extra credit options available:

  • +10% - Speed up the assn6 program by implementing course-grained locking (~10 lines of code)
  • +10% - Implement and use a system call to deallocate a mutex (~20 lines of code)
  • +20% - Implement a global mutex scheduling wait queue for process blocked on locked mutexes (~50 lines of code)
  • +20% - Implement per-mutex wait queues in the kernel and write code in the assn6 program that use five locks concurrently (~100 lines of code)
  • +20% - Implement in-kernel semaphores and change your assn6 test program to implement the producer-consumer model

Hints:

  • Build your stub system calls first and make sure everything compiles. No reason to fight compiler bugs and deadlock bugs at the same time.
  • Keep your critical sections small. If you need to wrap an entire function in a critical section, fine. You should seek to reduce it if possible, though.
  • You should really understand what the first parameter of the sleep and wakeup function represents. Why is it a void *? What are potential uses for that parameter?
  • You can use the printf function in the kernel code for debugging. Don't hesitate to print out the current state of a mutex for debugging purposes. Or print the value that argint puts into your variable.
  • Reduce your problem set for debugging. Modify the test program to reduce the number of loops. Reduce the number of total mutexes in the system. Smaller footprints are always easier to debug.
  • If you're frustrated with your changes not working, check in your changes and start over. Checkout your original assn5 branch, create a new branch, and try again with your new knowledge from the previous branch.

Submission:

When you're satisfied with your mutex system call and accompanying test program, stage the changes and commit them to your local git repository. Here is your pre-push checklist:

  • When you view git log, does it show HEAD -> assn6? If not, check out an assn6 branch with git checkout -b assn6 student/assn5 where student is the name for your remote repository
  • Do you see any uncommitted files in git status? Then stage them and commit them now
  • Your git status is clean? Try your assignment one last time by starting the xv6 OS and running your test program
  • Your assn6 test program runs great? Excellent, you're ready to push your assn6 branch to your remote repository!
  • Go to Canvas and submit your assignment with a note that you've pushed assn6 to Bitbucket. Note in your Canvas submission any extra credit you completed.

Grading:

The assignment is worth a total of 50 points. The grading for this assignment is as follows:

Points Description
3 Source code is pushed to your private Bitbucket repository as branch assn6
2 The source builds successfully with no errors or warnings
5 The call to allocate a mutex is made in the correct place in the assn6 source
5 The increment and decrement instruction in assn6 are properly locked
5 The allocate, lock, and unlock mutex system calls are created correctly
5 A mutex spinlock and state array are defined and properly initialized
5 Allocate mutex system call is implemented correctly and returns a unique handle
10 Lock mutex system call is implemented correctly
10 Unlock mutex system call is implemented correctly
5 Extra Credit - Implement course-grained locking
5 Extra Credit - Free mutex system call implemented
10 Extra Credit - Scheduler wait queue implemented for blocked mutexes
10 Extra Credit - Per-mutex wait queues and a five-lock test program implemented
10 Extra Credit - Semaphores implemented and test program written with semaphores

assignment_name: Assignment 7 - Add and Use the Execute Permission
description:
Objectives

The xv6 operating system lacks any form of file permissions such as read, write, or execute. For this assignment you will add the execute permission to the xv6 file system and check this permission when executing a program. You will make the following changes:

  • Create a test program named assn7 that will check the execute permission bit on files and attempt to execute files with and without the bit set
  • Add the permission value to the on-disk inode, in-memory inode, and the stat structure
  • Change the mkfs utility to create the xv6 filesystem with the appropriate permissions per file
  • Properly initialize and handle the permission value in the kernel
  • Properly set directory permissions when created
  • Check the correct setting of the permission when the exec system call is made

Details

Part 1: Creating your test program

  • In this part you will create the assn7 test program and add it to the Makefile

Create a new branch from the riscv branch named assn7. Create the source code for your test program in a file named user/assn7.c. Make sure to add assn7 to the Makefile. Your assn7 test program should do the following:

  • Open README and using stat check that the execute permission is not set
  • Open assn7 and using stat check that the execute permission is set
  • Create a child process and attempt to exec the README file. Report the wrong exec exit status
  • Create a child process and attempt to exec the echo command with an empty string. Report the wrong exec exit status
  • Show success when all tests pass

You can obtain information about a file using the stat library call. This function takes two parameters: a path to the file and a reference to a variable of type struct stat. Here is an example on how to call the library function (your test program will use it slightly differently):

struct stat st;
int ret;

ret = stat("README", &st);
if(ret < 0) {
  printf("stat for README returned an error: %d\n", ret);
  exit(1);
}
printf("The inode number of the file is %d\n", st.ino);

There are currently several values available in struct stat including:

struct stat {
  int dev;     // File system's disk device
  uint ino;    // Inode number
  short type;  // Type of file
  short nlink; // Number of links to file
  uint64 size; // Size of file in bytes
};

For this assignment you will be adding a new value to struct stat called perm. Just like type and nlink it should be type short. Your test program will check this perm variable two times: once when you check stat for the file README and a second time when you check stat for the file assn7. The README file is a simple text file and should not be set to executable, whereas your test program should be set as an executable file.

After checking the executable permission on the files using stat you will then attempt to execute each file using the exec system call. Here is an example on how to execute a program such as ls README assn7 (your program will use the system call slightly differently):

int pid;
int ret;

pid = fork();
if(pid == 0) { // Child process
  char *newargv[] = {
    "ls",
    "README",
    "assn7",
    0 };
  ret = exec(newargv[0], newargv);
  exit(ret);
}
wait(&ret);
printf("Executing 'ls' gave a exit code of %d\n", ret);

The exec system call takes two parameters: A string for the path to the program to execute and an array of strings for the parameters. The array is the tricky bit, as there are two requirements. First, the array must contain the name of the program as the first array element. Second, the array must contain a zero (0) as the last array element. The exec system call returns only if an error occurs, otherwise the child process is exclusively given over to the loaded program.

Your test program needs to check if an error occurred when attempting to run a program. Currently exec in xv6 only reports one error: -1. This is the same error when you try to load a program that does not exist, as well as the error if the program file is corrupted. Your assignment needs to detect an error specifically when the permissions are wrong. For this assignment the error reported by exec when the permissions are wrong will be -2. Your test program should check for this specific error value from exec.

Notice that if exec returns an error, it is good practice to exit the child process with an error value as well. Exiting the child process with the error code returned by exec is fine for our purposes.

Part 2: Adding the perm variable to struct stat, struct inode, and struct dinode (6 lines of code)

  • In this part you will add the perm variable to three structures, and a filler variable to the on-disk inode structure

There are three structures you need to add the new permission variable:

  • struct stat: This is how file metadata gets from the kernel to the user program.
    • Only the information the user program needs is provided by struct stat.
      • This does not include things such as the block pointers.
    • You can find this structure in the file kernel/stat.h
  • struct inode: This is the in-memory structure where file metadata resides.
    • This resembles the on-disk inode structure with a few extra details such as a reference count.
    • You can find this structure in the file kernel/file.h
  • struct dinode: This is the on-disk structure where file metadata is stored
    • This structure is loaded into the struct inode when the file is opened
    • This structure has a very important limitation. It must be a size that evenly divides the xv6 storage blocksize of 1024
    • You can find this structure in the file kernel/fs.h

Let's start with the struct dinode size requirement. Currently the structure looks like this:

// On-disk inode structure
struct dinode {
  short type;           // File type
  short major;          // Major device number (T_DEVICE only)
  short minor;          // Minor device number (T_DEVICE only)
  short nlink;          // Number of links to inode in file system
  uint size;            // Size of file (bytes)
  uint addrs[NDIRECT+1];   // Data block addresses
};

If you add up the size of each element, you get a total structure size of:

  • short type: 2 bytes
  • short major: 2 bytes
  • short minor: 2 bytes
  • short nlink: 2 bytes
  • uint size: 4 bytes
  • uint addrs[NDIRECT+1]: The value of NDIRECT is 12, so this array declaration is 4 * 13 = 52 bytes
  • Total: 2 + 2 + 2 + 2 + 4 + 52 = 64

This allows for 1024 / 64 = 16 on-disk inodes per block. This even division is necessary for a kernel memory allocation scheme called the SLAB allocation. One page of memory or one block of disk is allocated for a number of similar structures. In order to maintain this even division requirement, any changes to the inode structure must allow the structure to evenly divide the block size of 1024.

If you add a short perm variable to this structure, it will increase the structure size from 64 bytes to 66 bytes, which does not evenly divide the block size. In order to fix this the structure needs to have a variable removed (perhaps decrease NDIRECT by one) or one or more variables need to be added to bring the structure up to the next evenly divisible size (in our case, 128 bytes).

You will add the short perm variable to the structure, but you will also add a filler variable char filler[62]. Now the structure will be 64 bytes of the original data, 2 bytes for the new perm variable, and 62 bytes for the new filler variable, making a total of 128 bytes. This will only allow 8 on-disk inodes per block, but xv6 will allocate more on-disk blocks as necessary, so it shouldn't be a problem.

As there are no size restrictions on the struct inode and struct stat data structures, just add a short perm variable to each structure.

Also, add two lines to kernel/stat.h (be careful not to put a semicolon after each line):

  • #define FPERM_NOX 0: This sets the permission of the file or directory to "not executable"
  • #define FPERM_EXE 1: This sets the permission of the file or directory to "is executable"

Part 3: Adding the perm value to the filesystem through mkfs (8 lines of code)

  • In this part you will change the mkfs/mkfs.c source to create file and directory inodes with the correct permission (execute permission for directories and program files with filenames starting with an underscore)

When you run the command make qemu you are actually creating two things. First, the kernel is compiled and linked into a file name kernel/kernel. Next, the user-space programs are compiled and linked and combined into the file system image named fs.img. This image is created using the mkfs/mkfs program which is also compiled as part of the build process. In order to have the execute permission set for the executable programs, you must modify the mkfs/mkfs.c source code to set this permission for each executable.

A problem that you will need to work around is that the mkfs/mkfs.c file is marked to be ignored by git commands. This may have been by accident or by design, but for your purposes you will need to circumvent this. There are two ways to do this, and it is up to you which method you use:

  • Stage your changes using the command git add -f mkfs/mkfs.c: The -f option will cause git to ignore the .gitignore file for this one command. You will see this suggestion if you try to add your changes without the option. This is probably the least invasive option
  • Change mkfs to mkfs/mkfs in the .gitignore file: Instead of ignoring the whole directory, this change will ignore a specific file in the directory. Specifically the compiled binary mkfs that is created during the build process will be ignored, but not the source code itself. If you make this change, you will want to stage and commit .gitignore along with your changes to mkfs/mkfs.c

The mkfs/mkfs.c source has a function called ialloc. It's purpose is to properly set the values within the on-disk inode structure then write that on-disk inode structure onto the actual storage media. Currently it takes one parameters, ushort type. This value will be added to the on-disk inode structure and identifies if the inode is a file or a directory. You will add a second parameter called ushort perm and copy that value into the din.perm structure variable. Make sure you use the xshort() function the same way used by the type parameter.

You will also need to change the forward declaration for the ialloc function near the top of the mkfs/mkfs.c source file. Remember, the function declaration is at the top, the function definition is much further into the file.

There are two places in the mkfs/mkfs.c file where the ialloc function is called:

  • Creating the root directory inode: You will find a call to ialloc(T_DIR). You need to set the directory to "executable" as you want the user program to be able to make this directory the current working directory. Change the function call to ialloc(T_DIR, FPERM_EXE)
  • Creating the files: You will find a call to ialloc(T_FILE). You want to change this call, but you don't want to set every file as executable, only the files with filenames that start with an underscore (_).
    • Just above this function call you'll see an if(shortname[0] == '_') condition. This would be a good place to set the FPERM_EXE permission. Otherwise, for files with filenames that do not start with an underscore you should set the FPERM_NOX permission

Part 4: Handle the perm structure variable in kernel/fs.c (4 lines of code)

  • In this part you will add four lines initializing or copying the permission value into the correct structure variable

Most inode operations in the kernel happen within the kernel/fs.c file. There are four changes that need to be made to this file:

  • The ialloc function: Initialize the dip->perm variable to FPERM_NOX
    • This is the default inode setting and should only be changed as necessary, such as for creating directories in part 5
  • The iupdate function: Copy the ip->perm value into the dip->perm variable
  • The ilock function: Copy the dip->perm value into  the ip->perm variable
  • The stati function: Copy the ip->perm value into the st->perm variable

Part 5: Fix the create system call helper function to set the correct directory permission (2 lines of code)

  • In this part you will set the FPERM_EXE permission for directories created by the create function in kernel/sysfile.c

Inside the kernel there is only one location where a new inode is created. This is in the create function found in kernel/sysfile.c. This function is called when a new file, directory, or device node is created, so it is central to creating a new inode. The ialloc function initializes the perm variable in the inode to FPERM_NOX by default, but you want to change this for new directories. Any time an inode needs to be changed, three functions must be called:

  • ilock: This function is exactly what you think. It provides a mutually exclusive lock for the changes made to the inode. This should make sense when you consider concurrent inode access in the kernel
    • Make sure any change you make to the inode (such as set the FPERM_EXE permission on directories) happens after the call to ilock
  • iupdate: This function prepares the inode changes to be written to the on-disk inode.
    • This may not happen immediately as xv6 caches block writes, but as far as you're concerned, you've made the change permanent
  • iunlockput: This function releases the mutual exclusion to the inode lock and releases it's reference to the inode

Notice the if statement that checks if the type of the file created is T_DIR. This would be a good place to change the directory permission to FPERM_EXE. Remember to change the permission value for the ip structure. Do not change it for the dp structure as this represents the inode for the parent directory, and you should assume the parent directory was created with the proper permissions.

Make sure you call iupdate(ip) after changing the permission of the inode.

Part 6: Change exec to report an error if the program file does not have the FPERM_EXE permission (10 lines of code)

  • In this part you will create a function that will check the execution flag of an inode, and return a unique error value of -2 when the program inode is not executable

The exec function can be found in the file kernel/exec.c. This function does all the work of loading a program file into memory, and setting up the process structure and memory for the new program. It is in the exec function that the inode for the program file is opened. This happens when the namei function is called. You want to check the inode permissions for FPERM_EXE just after the inode is locked.

But the kernel/exec.c file doesn't know anything about the content of the struct inode.

You will create a helper function in kernel/fs.c that will take a struct inode* as a parameter and return 1 if the inode permission is set to FPERM_EXE, or 0 if the inode permission is not set to FPERM_EXE. I suggest sticking with the naming conventions used in kernel/fs.c and name the function is_execi. Make sure you add your new function declaration to kernel/defs.h

Now in the exec function of kernel/exec.c, call your new is_execi function to test if the inode is executable. If it is not executable then goto bad.

One problem with the exec function is it returns an error value -1 for all the events that can go wrong. This includes not finding the program file, corrupted program file data, memory allocation for the program or data, even the copying of the arguments to the new program stack. This is unusable to our test program as you will need to know specifically when a program cannot be executed. This means an error value other than -1. To do this you need to make three changes:

  • Create a new integer variable named err that is initialized to the error -1
  • Return the value in the err variable after the bad label at the bottom of the exec function
    • It's currently return -1;, just replace -1 with err
  • Set err to -2 if the inode does not have the FPERM_EXE permission set, before going to bad

Conclusion

You have added a new permission value to an inode structure, and are using it to verify that a program can be executed. You should make sure everything builds and your test program does what you expect it to before pushing your final changes. You should make sure your work area is clean and pushed to your student repository under the assn7 branch. Go to Canvas and submit a message indicating your assignment is complete and ready to be graded.

Extra credit:

There are many things that can be done with the new file permission, here are a few suggestions:

  • 5 points (2 lines of code): Add to the user/ls.c program to indicate when a file is executable (X) or not executable (_)
  • 5 points (20 lines of code): Create a stat user program that reports all the stats of a file, including file permissions
  • 10 points (40 lines of code): Create a chmod system call that allows changing a files permission, and a test program demonstrating the system call

Rubric:

Points Description
5 points Changes committed to Bitbucket and project builds successfully
5 points The perm variable is added to the dinode, inode, and stat structures
5 points The assn7 program successfully calls stat and checks the perm value for the executable setting on the README and assn7 files
5 points The assn7 program successfully creates two child processes and reports the correct error when executing README and report success when executing echo ""
5 points The mkfs program correctly sets the FPERM_EXE permission on directories and program files
5 points In kernel/fs.c: ialloc sets the FPERM_NOX, iupdate, ilock, and stati correctly copy the right permission into the right variable
10 points In kernel/exec.c the exec function returns the unique error value -2 when the file permission is not FPERM_EXE
5 points The ls program is modified to show if a file has execution permissions
5 points The stat program is created and shows the name of the file and all the information found in struct stat for that file
10 points A chmod system call is created, it changes the permission of the file specified, and a test program demonstrates success and failure of the system call

Discuss

Please respond to one of the following discussion questions:
  • Look up one of these commands and try it out: grep, find, diff. Tell which command you tried out, what you learned about it, and when the command might be useful.
  • Three commonly-used editors in Linux systems are Nano, Vim, and Emacs. Comment on the advantages and disadvantages of at least two of the three. If you have decided which editor you are going to use, tell which one you are going to use and why.
  • If you have experience with Git, summarize you experience with it and tell what you like and/or dislike about it. Also give any suggestions you might have about how to learn Git and how to avoid common mistakes.
  • If you have experience with Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) describe your experience. Tell whether you've found it to be useful. Also give any sources of information about WSL that you've found useful.

assignment_name: M2 - Discuss: Examples of C programming bugs
description:
Discuss

Look through the examples of C programming bugs on this page: Examples of C programming bugs.

See if you can figure out what the bugs are in two or three of the examples. Then post the example number and description of the problem for each of the examples you choose. See if your discussion group can explain all of the bugs.

Please remember to be courteous, respectful, and constructive in your comments.

Discuss

Please read the textbook and search the Internet and respond the following questions. 

(1) What is the CPU scheduling algorithm used in Windows?

(2) What is the CPU scheduling algorithm used in Linux?

Discuss

Please respond to the following discussion question:  

  • What do you look for in terms of memory when you are buying or building a new computer? How much memory is adequate for main memory and for graphics memory? What do you look at other than the amount of memory?

Discuss

Now that you have learned about memory paging and swapping, you will create a new feature that will allow shared memory between processes in the xv6 operating system. I want you to discuss the best implementation of the feature. The feature has the following design requirements:

  • Must be compatible with the paged memory system of RISCV and the xv6 operating system
  • Must have a system call that allocates shared memory to a process
  • Must have some method to identify a shared memory region
  • Must allow shared memory to persist in both parent and child after a call to `fork()`
  • Must persist data in shared memory after a process has terminated

What I want each of you to propose is the following:

  • System call API: Include things like the name, parameters, and return value
  • In-kernel storage: Include data structures and methods needed to identify and persist shared memory regions
  • Modifications: Identify functions and data structures that already exist in the xv6 kernel that must be modified to implement this feature

This discussion is open for two weeks. During this time I will monitor the discussion and provide guidance. Hopefully this will prevent poor design decisions early in the process. When the discussion is complete I will take your design ideas and create Assignment 5. You will be responsible for implementing this shared memory feature. This is your chance to guide the creation of an assignment, so choose your API wisely - you will have to implement it no matter how bizarre. Now, tell us how it should work!

I expect everyone to follow these rules:

  • Be respectful: Every idea is a good idea, even if you don't agree or understand.
    • If you disagree, politely suggest a better alternative. I will be the final arbiter of unresolved issues.
    • If you don't understand, ask politely and specifically about what you do not understand.
      • If you are replying to help someone understand, be patient and thorough in your explanation
  • Be professional: We are dealing with a technical feature design. You should never make personal attacks
    • You are encouraged to argue the technical merits of ideas, but please be respectful (see above).
    • You are welcome to disparage the existing xv6 design. The xv6 kernel is not perfect, and sometimes it's fun to identify bad design decision. But be prepared to explain how you would do things differently.
    • Follow the UVU CS Code of Ethics found here: Code of Ethics.

A student that is found in violation of these rules will be warned once privately. Any further violation will be reported to Academic Affairs.

Discuss

Please respond to one of the following discussion questions:

  • Do you have experience from a job or another class working with multithreaded programs? What do you like or dislike about writing multithreaded programs? If you didn't use Pthreads, how did the thread library you used compare to Pthreads?
  • What aspects of using Pthreads do you find to be the most challenging? What has helped you to better understand how to use Pthreads?
  • How is testing multithreaded programs different than testing single-threaded programs?

Discuss

Please respond to one of the following discussion questions:  

  • Getting synchronization right in a multi-process or multi-threaded program can be difficult. Running the same program with the same inputs can have different results if there is a race condition in the program, so testing is much more challenging. Likewise, debugging programs is tricky because it can sometimes to reproduce a problem. Can you find or think of any strategies that make it easier to get synchronization right?  
  • What race conditions occur outside of computer systems? In those situations, what is analogous to a critical section, and what is analogous to synchronization mechanisms?

Discuss

Please respond to one of the following discussion questions:

  • What factors determine which deadlock strategy to use in a given system? In other words, if you were implementing a system, how would you decide which deadlock strategy to use?
  • Is ignoring deadlock (sometimes called the "ostrich algorithm") a reasonable deadlock strategy? Why or why not?

Discuss

Please respond to one of the following discussion questions:

  • Are hard-disk drives going the way of magnetic tape storage systems? In other words, do you think that hard-disk drives will be completely (or almost completely) replaced by solid-state (nonvolatile memory) drives in the next five or ten years? Why or why not?
  • In the early days of personal computers could easily be backed up to CDs, and later to DVDs. However, those days are long gone. What devices and strategies do you use to back-up the storage on the computers and mobile devices that you use? What issues do you think are important to consider when deciding how to back up your data?

Discuss

Please respond to one of the following discussion questions:  

  • What file systems do you commonly use? Your answer should not be "Windows" or "Mac" or "Linux", because each of those systems does or can work with more than one file system. What aspects of those file systems do you like or dislike? Have you ever purchased a storage device that used one file system and then reformatted it to be used with a different file system?
  • Do you use symbolic links? You might have used them without realizing it because different operating systems use different terms for symbolic links. If you have used symbolic links, briefly explain how and when you use them. If you haven't used them, look them up for an operating system and briefly explain how they work and whether you think they will be useful.

This quiz covers xv6 operating system build environment and Git version control topics. It also covers chapters 4-9 in the Operating System: Three Easy Pieces book.

You have 60 minutes to complete the 15 questions in this quiz. There are thirteen multiple choice questions and two short answer questions.

Complete

This quiz covers memory (Chapters 13-17) and virtual memory (18-22)

Complete

This quiz covers Chapters 26-32 of the Operating Systems: Three Easy Pieces book.

You have two attempts for this quiz, the highest score will be taken from both attempts. You can use your textbook and web resources on the quiz.

This quiz will have four short answer questions that relate to the subject of Storage and File Systems. These relate to the chapters 36-45 in the textbook in general, and more specifically the three videos found at the top of the M10 - Watch: File Systems module page. Watch those videos to be able to answer the questions in this quiz

Please submit your info using the below link and upload the snapshot of the confirmation page to get your Bonus credit.

Get to Know You

assignment_name: Introduce Yourself to Your Peers via Flip
description: Introduce Yourself

assignment_name: Wellness Checkup Tool (Please upload a snapshot of submission to get Credit)

description:
Submit | Final Project Topic Selection

Introduction and Rationale

  You will submit your choice for your Final Project topic.

Instructions 

You need to choose a topic where you can implement meeting the below project goals.

Project Goals: 

  1. Design Cryptographic Algorithms/ Functional Programs

    • Develop robust cryptographic algorithms/functional programs to enhance the security of data and communications.
    • Consider factors such as confidentiality, integrity, and authenticity in the design process.
    • Document the design rationale, mathematical foundations, and potential vulnerabilities.

  2. Implement Cryptographic Algorithms/ Functional Programs

    • Translate the designed cryptographic algorithms into the functional code of your choice
    • Ensure the implementation adheres to the specified design criteria and standards.
    • Evaluate the performance and efficiency of the implemented algorithms.

  3. Identify Insecure Code:

    • Conduct a thorough analysis of code written in the chosen programming language.
    • Utilize static code analysis tools, manual code review, and other techniques to identify potential security vulnerabilities.
    • Categorize and prioritize identified insecure code based on severity and impact.

  4. Fix Insecure Code:

    • Develop a systematic approach to addressing and fixing the identified insecure code.
    • Prioritize fixing based on the severity of vulnerabilities and potential impact.
    • Implement secure coding practices to prevent future vulnerabilities.

 

 

Addressing the below factors requires a holistic approach to security, including continuous education, robust development practices, regular security assessments, and a commitment to staying updated on emerging threats and best practices.

  1. Lack of Secure Coding Practices:

    • Inadequate attention to secure coding principles and practices.

  2. Inadequate Authentication and Authorization:

    • Weak authentication mechanisms or improper authorization controls.

  3. Insufficient Encryption:

    • Failure to implement proper encryption for data in transit and at rest.

  4. Poor Input Validation:

    • Insufficient validation of user inputs leads to injection attacks.

  5. Outdated Software and Libraries:

    • Use of outdated software components or libraries with known vulnerabilities.

  6. Insecure Configuration:

    • Incorrect or insecure configuration settings, such as default passwords.

  7. Lack of Security Testing:

    • Inadequate security testing, including penetration testing and code reviews.

  8. Inadequate Error Handling:

    • Poorly managed error handling revealing sensitive information.

  9. Insufficient Logging and Monitoring:

    • Lack of proper logging and monitoring mechanisms.

  10. Third-Party Dependencies:

    • Use of third-party components without thorough security assessments.

  11. Ignoring Security Updates:

    • Neglecting to apply security updates and patches promptly.

  12. Social Engineering Attacks:

    • Falling victim to phishing attacks or other forms of social engineering.

  13. Insufficient User Education:

    • Lack of user awareness and education about security best practices.

  14. Rapid Development Practices:

    • Pressures to release software quickly, leading to skipped security measures.

  15. Mobile and Web App-specific Issues:

    • Insecure data storage, insufficient session management, and client-side vulnerabilities.

  16. Inadequate Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Protection:

    • Failing to protect against XSS attacks, allowing attackers to inject malicious scripts.

  17. Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) Vulnerabilities:

    • Lack of protection against CSRF attacks, enabling unauthorized actions on behalf of a user.

  18. Insecure Direct Object References (IDOR):

    • Allowing unauthorized access to resources by manipulating object references.

  19. Insecure File Uploads:

    • Allowing users to upload files without proper validation and security checks.

  20. Data Leaks and Exposure:

    • Accidental exposure of sensitive information due to poor data handling practices.

  21. Insecure APIs:

    • Lack of proper authentication and authorization mechanisms in APIs.

  22. Insufficient Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) Controls:

    • Inadequate restrictions on cross-origin requests, lead to security issues.

  23. Insufficient Network Security:

    • Poorly configured firewalls, lack of intrusion detection, and other network security issues.

  24. Inadequate Session Management:

    • Weak session handling leads to session hijacking or session fixation attacks.

  25. Insufficient Data Validation:

    • Failure to validate and sanitize data leads to security vulnerabilities.

 

You will be submitting your choice (at least two factors) using this Final Project Topic Selection Survey.  You need to implement the program meeting the project goals addressing to mitigate your chosen factors.

Final Project Topic Selection Survey

 

Please upload a snapshot to prove your survey completion.

Grading

Your completed survey will receive full credit.

Submit | Tentative Project Milestone and Abstract

Introduction and Rationale

  You will submit your initial project milestone and Abstract

Instructions 

You will need to evaluate your project and break it into the below five Milestones.  These milestones need to demonstrate a significant step toward completing your project.  You will be asked to demonstrate the completion of each of these Milestones at various points throughout the semester.

Take some time now to make a plan. 

  1. Research and Design

    • Review existing cryptographic algorithms and security standards.
    • Develop new cryptographic algorithms considering project requirements.
    • Document the design principles, potential threats, and countermeasures.

  2. Implementation

    • Translate the designed cryptographic algorithms into code.
    • Implement code following best practices and design criteria.
    • Conduct testing to ensure correctness, efficiency, and resistance against common attacks.

  3. Code Security Analysis

    • Employ static analysis tools and manual reviews to identify insecure code.
    • Prioritize vulnerabilities based on severity and potential impact.
    • Generate detailed reports highlighting insecure code segments.

  4. Remediation

    • Develop and document a remediation plan for addressing identified vulnerabilities.
    • Apply fixes to insecure code, ensuring compatibility with the overall system.
    • Conduct thorough testing to validate the effectiveness of the fixes.

  5. Documentation and Reporting

    • Document the entire process, including design decisions, implementation details, and security analysis results.
    • Prepare comprehensive reports for stakeholders, including recommendations for future code security practices.

 

Please submit the below deliverables:

1. The project title (it should be a catchy and meaningful title)

2. Tentative abstract of your project.

3. Tentative 5 milestones specific to your project

Please upload one document having all the deliverables.

  4. In what ways do encryption and hashing contribute to enhancing the confidentiality and integrity of data stored in databases?

  5. How can organizations balance the need for providing database access to authorized users while minimizing the risk of insider threats?

  6. What role does audit logging play in database security, and how can organizations leverage it for monitoring and incident response?

  7. Can you share examples of best practices for securing database backups and preventing data loss in the event of a security incident?

  8. How do regulatory requirements and compliance standards impact the design and implementation of database security measures?

  9. What considerations should organizations take into account when implementing database security measures in cloud environments?

  10. Can you discuss the challenges and strategies associated with ensuring database security in a rapidly evolving technological landscape?

assignment_name: Module 8: Discuss | SQL Injection and Data Center Security
description:
Discuss

Introduction and Rationale

Participants in the SQL injection and data center security discussion gained valuable insights into the specific threats posed by SQL injection attacks and the broader implications for data center security. Exploring the consequences of successful SQL injection attacks heightened participants' awareness of the potential risks and damages. The discussion on the mechanisms behind SQL injection attacks provided a foundational understanding of how vulnerabilities in web applications can be exploited. Preventive measures and best practices discussed equipped participants with actionable strategies to defend against SQL injection, highlighting the collaborative effort required from developers and security teams. In the context of data center security, participants learned about the unique challenges posed by SQL injection attacks and the additional measures needed to protect databases within a data center environment. Real-world examples illustrated the practical impact of SQL injection on data center security, offering valuable lessons for participants. Insights into input validation, prepared statements, and parameterized queries provided practical guidance for implementing secure coding practices. Lastly, discussions on emerging technologies emphasized the evolving nature of security measures, prompting participants to consider innovative approaches in their security strategies. Overall, the discussion fostered a well-rounded understanding of SQL injection, its implications for data center security, and proactive measures to mitigate these risks in contemporary cybersecurity environments.

Discussion Prompt

Choose one of the following questions to craft a response to.  Write a minimum of a paragraph in your response.  Be sure to address all of the parts of the question.

  1. Why is SQL injection a significant threat to database security, and what are the potential consequences of successful SQL injection attacks?

  2. Can you explain the basic mechanisms behind SQL injection and how attackers exploit vulnerabilities in web applications to gain unauthorized access to databases?

  3. What preventive measures can organizations implement to defend against SQL injection attacks, and how can developers contribute to minimizing this threat?

  4. In the context of data center security, how do SQL injection attacks pose unique challenges, and what additional measures should be considered to protect databases in a data center environment?

  5. How can organizations balance the need for maintaining user-friendly web applications with the imperative of implementing robust security measures against SQL injection?

  6. What role does input validation play in preventing SQL injection, and what best practices should be followed in designing secure input validation processes?

  7. Can you share examples of real-world incidents where SQL injection compromised data center security, and discuss the lessons learned from these incidents?

  8. How does the implementation of prepared statements and parameterized queries contribute to mitigating the risks associated with SQL injection?

  9. What considerations should organizations keep in mind when securing databases in a multi-tenant data center environment where multiple clients share the same infrastructure?

  10. How do evolving technologies, such as machine learning and behavioral analysis, impact the detection and prevention of SQL injection attacks, and what challenges may arise in implementing these technologies?

How to Post and Respond

Introduction and Rationale

Participants in the social engineering discussion gained a comprehensive understanding of the multifaceted nature of this cybersecurity threat. Exploring the psychological aspects of social engineering heightened participants' awareness of how human behavior can be exploited. Discussions on common techniques provided practical insights into recognizing and mitigating social engineering threats, empowering participants to be more vigilant. The conversation on employee training underscored the importance of awareness programs in preventing successful social engineering attacks within organizations. Insights into the use of social media for intelligence gathering highlighted the need for individuals to be mindful of the information they share online. Real-world examples of successful social engineering attacks provided concrete lessons, emphasizing the need for continuous learning and adaptation. The discussion on trust and skepticism prompted participants to reflect on the delicate balance required for effective security. Conversations around establishing a security culture within organizations provided practical strategies for fostering a resilient workforce. Ethical considerations in training discussions encouraged participants to think critically about responsible education practices. Lastly, exploring the evolving nature of social engineering tactics prompted forward-thinking, empowering participants to stay ahead of emerging threats. Overall, the discussion provided a holistic view of social engineering, ensuring participants left with both theoretical knowledge and practical strategies to enhance their cybersecurity resilience.

Discussion Prompt

Choose one of the following questions to craft a response to.  Write a minimum of a paragraph in your response.  Be sure to address all of the parts of the question.

  2. Can you provide examples of common social engineering techniques, and discuss how individuals and organizations can recognize and mitigate these threats?

  4. How do social engineers leverage information from social media and other online platforms to gather intelligence for targeted attacks?

  5. What role does trust play in social engineering, and how can individuals and organizations balance trust with a healthy skepticism to enhance security?

  6. Can you share real-world instances where social engineering attacks were successful, and discuss the lessons learned from these incidents?

  8. What are the ethical considerations involved in conducting social engineering awareness training, and how can organizations strike the right balance in educating without causing fear or paranoia?

assignment_name: Module 10: Discuss | Pre-text Development and Vishing
description:
Discuss

Introduction and Rationale

Participants in the pre-text development and vishing discussion gained valuable insights into the intricacies of social engineering tactics. Exploring the potency of combining pre-text development with vishing deepened participants' understanding of how attackers manipulate human psychology. Discussions on the process of pre-text development provided a practical view of how convincing scenarios are crafted to deceive targets during vishing attacks. Identifying red flags and recognizing vishing attempts became tangible skills for participants, empowering them to be more vigilant in their personal and professional interactions. The conversation on education and training highlighted the importance of building resilience against these tactics. Real-world examples brought the theoretical concepts to life, illustrating the impact of successful pre-text and vishing attacks. The discussion on technology emphasized the need for a multifaceted approach to detection and prevention, recognizing both the strengths and limitations of technological solutions. Insights into verifying the legitimacy of calls and requests provided practical strategies for individuals to protect themselves. Ethical considerations in training discussions encouraged participants to think critically about responsible education practices. Lastly, exploring the adaptive nature of pre-text and vishing tactics prompted forward-thinking, ensuring participants were left with not only a deeper understanding of the subject matter but also practical strategies to bolster their defenses against evolving social engineering threats.

Discussion Prompt

Choose one of the following questions to craft a response to.  Write a minimum of a paragraph in your response.  Be sure to address all of the parts of the question.

  1. Why is pre-text development and vishing a potent combination in social engineering, and how do attackers use these techniques to manipulate targets?

  2. Can you describe the process of pre-text development and how it involves creating a convincing scenario to deceive individuals during vishing attacks?

  3. What are the key red flags that individuals and organizations should be aware of to recognize pre-texts and vishing attempts?

  4. In what ways can education and training programs help individuals build resilience against pre-text development and vishing attacks?

  5. How can organizations enhance their security measures to protect employees from falling victim to pre-text and vishing tactics?

  6. Can you share examples of real-world incidents where pre-text development and vishing were successfully employed, and discuss the impact on individuals and organizations?

  7. What role does technology play in detecting and preventing vishing attacks, and what are the limitations of relying solely on technological solutions?

  8. How can individuals verify the legitimacy of calls and requests, especially in situations where pre-texts may seem plausible?

  9. What ethical considerations should be taken into account when conducting security awareness training on pre-text development and vishing?

  10. Considering the evolving nature of communication channels, how might pre-text and vishing tactics adapt, and what strategies can individuals and organizations employ to stay resilient?
