Introduction and Rationale

Participants in the data privacy discussion gain a comprehensive understanding of the complexities surrounding the protection of personal information. Exploring the concerns and impacts of data privacy in the digital age heightens participants' awareness of the significance of this issue. Clarifying the differences between data privacy and security equips participants with a foundational understanding of the multifaceted nature of safeguarding information. Discussions on data breaches and unauthorized access provide practical insights into the risks individuals and organizations face and strategies to mitigate these threats. Delving into the ethical considerations surrounding data collection emphasizes the responsibility organizations bear in preserving user privacy. Understanding the regulatory landscape, including GDPR and CCPA, enhances participants' awareness of the legal frameworks shaping data privacy practices. Practical tips for individuals to protect their data privacy foster a sense of personal agency in the digital realm. Exploring the impact of emerging technologies prompts forward-thinking discussions on adapting privacy practices to technological advancements. Insights into transparency and trust-building contribute to discussions on ethical and responsible data handling. Real-world examples of best practices and the role of international collaboration add a practical dimension to the conversation, providing participants with a well-rounded view of data privacy principles and practices. Overall, the discussion empowers participants to navigate the complexities of data privacy, contributing to a more informed and proactive approach to safeguarding personal information.

Discussion Prompt

Choose one of the following questions to craft a response to.  Write a minimum of a paragraph in your response.  Be sure to address all of the parts of the question.

  1. Why is data privacy a growing concern in the digital age, and how does it impact individuals and organizations alike?

  2. Can you explain the key differences between data privacy and data security, and why both are essential components of a robust cybersecurity strategy?

  3. In what ways do data breaches and unauthorized access compromise individuals' privacy, and what measures can organizations take to mitigate these risks?

  4. How does the collection and use of personal data by companies and service providers raise ethical considerations, and what responsibilities do organizations have in safeguarding user privacy?

  5. Can you discuss the role of regulations, such as GDPR and CCPA, in shaping the landscape of data privacy, and what challenges do organizations face in compliance?

  6. What measures can individuals take to protect their own data privacy in an increasingly interconnected digital world?

  7. How do emerging technologies, such as artificial intelligence and the Internet of Things, impact data privacy, and what safeguards should be in place to prevent misuse?

  8. What role does transparency play in building trust between organizations and individuals concerning the handling of personal data?

  9. Can you share examples of best practices for creating and implementing privacy policies that effectively protect user data?

  10. Considering the global nature of data flows, how can international collaboration and standards contribute to ensuring consistent and robust data privacy practices?

Introduction and Rationale

Participants in the malware (virus and worm) discussion gain a comprehensive understanding of these pervasive threats and how they impact cybersecurity. Clarifying the distinctions between viruses and worms allows participants to appreciate the nuances in their behaviors and spread mechanisms. Exploring common vectors of infiltration and preventive measures equips participants with practical strategies to mitigate risks. The discussion on the persistence of viruses and worms provides insights into the potential long-term effects of malware infections. Balancing antivirus solutions and system performance considerations prompts thoughtful discussions on optimizing security measures. Real-world examples of historical attacks illustrate the tangible impact of malware, offering lessons learned for participants. Understanding the role of user behaviors in propagation emphasizes the importance of education and awareness. Delving into the evolution of malware challenges and detection methods equips participants to stay ahead of advanced threats. Discussions on incident response planning provide practical guidance for organizations to handle outbreaks effectively. Examining the financial impact of malware attacks and preparing for recovery fosters a proactive approach to cybersecurity. Lastly, exploring the evolving landscape of malware attacks on connected devices prompts forward-thinking discussions on securing IoT environments. Overall, the discussion empowers participants with a well-rounded view of malware threats, enabling them to adopt informed practices to protect systems and networks.

Discussion Prompt

Choose one of the following questions to craft a response to.  Write a minimum of a paragraph in your response.  Be sure to address all of the parts of the question.

  1. What distinguishes viruses and worms in the realm of malware, and how do their characteristics influence the methods they use to spread and damage systems?

  2. Can you discuss the common vectors through which viruses and worms infiltrate systems, and what preventive measures can individuals and organizations take to mitigate these risks?

  3. In what ways do viruses and worms differ in terms of their persistence on infected systems, and how does this impact the severity of their effects?

  4. How can organizations balance the need for robust antivirus solutions with the imperative of minimizing system resource utilization and performance impact?

  5. Can you share examples of notable virus and worm attacks throughout history, and discuss the lessons learned from these incidents?

  6. What role do user behaviors, such as downloading attachments or clicking on links, play in the propagation of viruses and worms, and how can user education mitigate these risks?

  7. How does the evolution of malware, including polymorphic and metamorphic variants, challenge traditional antivirus detection methods, and what strategies can be employed to counter these advanced threats?

  8. What considerations should organizations take into account when developing incident response plans to effectively handle virus and worm outbreaks?

  9. How do malware attacks, particularly ransomware, impact individuals and organizations financially, and what measures can be taken to prepare for and recover from such incidents?

  10. With the increasing prevalence of connected devices, how has the landscape of malware attacks evolved, and what steps can be taken to secure IoT devices from virus and worm infections?

As far as I can tell, SRIs are open until December 22nd, but if you want extra credit points you will need to complete the survey and turn in your receipt before Canvas closes for student submissions.

In the file gas_prices.txt (linked below) you will find weekly U.S. gas prices for 1994 through 2012. The format is <date>:<price>, as follows:

01-03-1994:0.992
01-10-1994:0.995
01-17-1994:1.001
01-24-1994:0.999
01-31-1994:1.005
02-07-1994:1.007
02-14-1994:1.016
02-21-1994:1.009
02-28-1994:1.004
03-07-1994:1.007
…

Write a program that reads this file and outputs a report containing the low price, average price, and high prices for each year, as well as the average prices for each month of each year, sorted by year and month, as follows:

    1994:
        Low: $0.99, Avg: $1.08, High: $1.17
        January    $1.00
        February   $1.01
        March      $1.01
        April      $1.03
        May        $1.05
        June       $1.08
        July       $1.11
        August     $1.15
        September  $1.14
        October    $1.11
        November   $1.12
        December   $1.13

  
    1995:
	Low: $1.11, Avg: $1.16, High: $1.25
	January   $1.13
	February  $1.12
	March     $1.12
	April     $1.16
	May       $1.23
	June      $1.24
	July      $1.20
	August    $1.17
	September $1.16
	October   $1.13
	November  $1.11
	December  $1.12
    …

Redirect your report to a file named gas_report.txt. Submit that file along with your code in a file named gasprices.py

To redirect output from a program to a file, use > in the command line when you run your program, as shown in this example:

python3 gasprices.py > gas_report.txt

Turn in

Submit the following files on Canvas:

■ gasprices.py - Your program
■ gas_report.txt - Output from your program

Do not submit anything else.

Data file

◆ gas_prices.txt

Data

For this assignment you will use four text data files named parts.txt, projects.txt, spj.txt, and suppliers.txt (linked at the bottom of this page). These files contain comma-separated data for four database tables: parts, projects, spj, and suppliers. The “data dictionary” (slot descriptions) for this database is:
• suppliers: (sno,sname,status,city)
• parts: (pno,pname,color,weight,city)
• projects: (jno,jname,city)
• spj: (sno,pno,jno,qty)

The first slot in each tuple (sno, pno, and jno) in the first 3 tables is the unique record id (a string). You may let all of your slot data types be strings for simplicity in this assignment.

Each text file has the name of the relation/table and the slot/column names on the first two lines, respectively. Use these to properly define your named tuples.

For this project, read the data from each file into an associated set of namedtuples, so you can process the queries below using set and dictionary comprehensions (a dictionary comprehension for query number six).

Data files

You can download the data files individually or download the zip file which has all four .txt data files inside it.
◆ suppliers.txt
◆ parts.txt
◆ projects.txt
◆ spj.txt

◆ compData.zip

Queries

Process these queries using comprehensions:
1. Get names of all suppliers that supply bolts.
2. Get names of all suppliers that supply blue parts.
3. Get names of all suppliers not used in Athens projects
4. Get names and colors of all parts not used in Oslo
5. Get pairs of names of all suppliers that are located in the same city.
6. Print all suppliers out by city

Processing queries with comprehensions

To illustrate, you can find suppliers for projects in London as shown below in the file london_named.py in the Code folder:

{s.sname for s in suppliers for r in spj for j in projects 
 if r.sno == s.sno if j.jno == r.jno if j.city == 'London'}

which gives the response:

{'Jones', 'Adams', 'Clark'}

We use sets so that any duplicate tuples are removed, as is typical in database queries. For readability, you could separate the queries into multiple steps, as found in london_named.py, shown below:

london_projs = {j.jno for j in projects if j.city == 'London'}
london_supp_ids = {r.sno for r in spj if r.jno in london_projs}
london_supps = {s.sname for s in suppliers if s.sno in london_supp_ids}
print(london_supps)

You can decide which form looks best to you for each problem individually.

Each text file has the name of the relation/table and the slot/column names on the first two lines, respectively. Use these to properly define your named tuples. To illustrate, here is parts.txt:

parts
pno,pname,color,weight,city
p1,Nut,Red,12,London
p2,Bolt,Green,17,Paris
p3,Screw,Blue,17,Rome
p4,Screw,Red,14,London
p5,Cam,Blue,12,Paris
p6,Cog,Red,19,London

The code that reads such data should be application independent/generic. I would write a function that returns the named tuple object. (Hint: Consider using the unary * sequence-flattening operator for arguments in a function call.)

Print no duplicates. There should be no top-level loops in this script (they are inside the comprehensions) except for when you read the data in. The queries should use comprehensions only.

Here is the expected output (order within a set or dictionary is immaterial, for this project, and also within the pairs of suppliers in the same city):

{'Adams'}
{'Jones', 'Adams', 'Blake'}
{'Blake'}
{('Cam', 'Blue'), ('Cog', 'Red'), ('Nut', 'Red'), ('Bolt', 'Green'), ('Screw', 'Red')}
{('Jones', 'Blake'), ('Smith', 'Clark')}
{'Paris': {'Jones', 'Blake'}, 'Athens': {'Adams'}, 'London': {'Clark', 'Smith'}}

Turn in

Turn in the following:

■ comp.py - Your Python code

In this assignment you will create two decorators. I suggest you follow 2 steps.

Step 1

Refer to the trace decorator from Professor Allison's Chapter 9 slide set. It counts the number of times a decorated function is executed. Modify trace (and rename it as track) so that it 1) caches the result of all function calls, so that the decorated function is never called twice with the same arguments, and 2) counts the total number of function calls. Tracking the count of calls is accomplished by using a function attribute. To illustrate how this works, consider the recursive function that computes the nth Fibonacci number.
def fib(n):
    return n if n in (0,1) else fib(n-1) + fib(n-2)
This implementation makes many repeated function calls on the same argument. If we decorate it as follows:
@track
def fib(n):
    return n if n in (0,1) else fib(n-1) + fib(n-2)
then calling print(fib(10), 'count =' ,fib.count) yields the following:
55, calls = 177
Very wasteful! Your modified track decorator should print the following:
(1,){} found in cache
(2,){} found in cache
(3,){} found in cache
(4,){} found in cache
(5,){} found in cache
(6,){} found in cache
(7,){} found in cache
(8,){} found in cache
The eight trace statements are printed whenever a repeated call is attempted on the arguments shown. Note that both positional and keyword arguments function as the cache dictionary key. This is done with the following statement:
key = str(args) + str(kwargs)

using the customary parameter names for decorators.

Step 2

Write a separate logging decorator that saves all function calls and their results in the file "log.txt". This requires opening the file for appending:
logfile = open('log.txt','a')
You will need the wrapper function to open the file for each function call, write the information, and close the file.
When you decorate fib with only the log decorator, log.txt should contain the output below:
@log
def fib(n):
 return n if n in (0,1) else fib(n-1) + fib(n-2)
print(fib(10))   # Prints 55

The file log.txt contains:

fib((1,){}) = 1
fib((0,){}) = 0
fib((2,){}) = 1
fib((1,){}) = 1
fib((3,){}) = 2
fib((1,){}) = 1
fib((0,){}) = 0
fib((2,){}) = 1
fib((4,){}) = 3
fib((1,){}) = 1
fib((0,){}) = 0
fib((2,){}) = 1
fib((1,){}) = 1
fib((3,){}) = 2
fib((5,){}) = 5
fib((1,){}) = 1
fib((0,){}) = 0
fib((2,){}) = 1
fib((1,){}) = 1
fib((3,){}) = 2
fib((1,){}) = 1
fib((0,){}) = 0
fib((2,){}) = 1
fib((4,){}) = 3
fib((6,){}) = 8
fib((1,){}) = 1
fib((0,){}) = 0
fib((2,){}) = 1

Background

Many stores now offer options for ordering groceries online, for pickup or home delivery. This project will print a report of online orders from a fictional grocery chain. There are 3 input files to process:
• customers.txt
• items.txt
• orders.txt

The first file holds customer data in a single text line like the following:

810003,Kai Antonikov,31 Prairie Rose Street,Philadelphia,PA,19196,215-975-7421,kantonikov0@4shared.com

The data fields are the customer id, name, street, city, state, zip, phone, and email.

The file items.txt has fields item_id, description, and price:

57464,Almonds Ground Blanched,2.99

Orders.txt holds 2 lines per order. The first line contains the customer id, order number, order date, and then a variable-length sequence of item_id–quantity pairs:

762212,1,2020-03-15,10951-3,64612-2,57544-1,80145-1,27515-2,16736-1,79758-2,29286-2,51822-3,39096-1,32641-3, …

In the line above, 3 items of product #10951 were ordered, 2 of product #64612, etc. Note that all fields in all files are comma-separated, and that the item_id–quantity pairs in orders.txt are separated by a dash.

The second line contains payment information in the form of payment code, and payment information. There are 3 types of payments:

• 1 = Credit card (card number and expiration date)
• 2 = PayPal (paypal_id only)
• 3 = Wire transfer (bank_id and account_id)

Here are respective examples:

1,373975319551257,12-2023
2,cfeeham3s
3,72-2201515,68196-140

Requirements

The following UML class diagram suggests a design for this project.

PDF version of the UML diagram: groceriesUML.pdf

Note that Payment should be an abstract class with abstract method __str__, which its derived classes must override to return a string which becomes part of printing an order, as illustrated in the sample output below. Order.print_order implicitly uses Customer.__str__ and Payment.__str__ to do its work.

Here is the main logic:

if __name__ == '__main__':
    Customer.read_customers("customers.txt")
    Item.read_items("items.txt")
    Order.read_orders("orders.txt")
    
    # Now print orders to the file order_report.txt:
    …

The static methods Customer.read_customers and Item.read_items create respectively global dictionaries of Customer and Item objects obtained from file input. Order.read_orders populates a global list or dictionary with Order objects obtained from file input.

Implementation Notes

• Use @dataclass for Customer, Item, LineItem, and Order.
• Customers and Item objects are found as needed by their respective IDs; don’t duplicate data.
• Make Order.total a read property; it returns payment.amount. Set the payment amount in read_orders.
• Note the formatting of the report, including 2 decimals for the order total. Match this output format exactly.
• You may have seen this project in CS 2370. The Python version is over 100 lines shorter. Make your solution Pythonic. Don’t just “translate” your C++ code.

The file words.txt (linked here and at the bottom of the page) contains about 81,000 words, one per line. You will use it for this assignment as a lexicon of English words.

Write a Python program that chooses a word of a specified length at random from the lexicon and displays it to the user in a random, scrambled order. Then let the user guess words of varying lengths that can be formed using the letters of the word and the same number of occurrences or less as they appear in the word. After every guess, respond to the user whether the guess was correct, and add it to the list of words that have been guessed so far. Print results grouped by length of words and alphabetized within each group.

Here is a sample execution:

$ python3 wordgame.py
Enter the range of word lengths (low,high):3,6
renbur:

['---', '---', '---', '---', '---', '---', '---', '---', '---']
['----', '----', '----', '----']
['-----']
['------']

Enter a guess: bur
Correct!

urnrbe:

['---', '---', 'bur', '---', '---', '---', '---', '---', '---']
['----', '----', '----', '----']
['-----']
['------']

Enter a guess: burr
Correct!

ubenrr:

['---', '---', 'bur', '---', '---', '---', '---', '---', '---']
['----', 'burr', '----', '----']
['-----']
['------']

Enter a guess: run
Correct!

rebnur:

['---', '---', 'bur', '---', '---', '---', '---', 'run', '---']
['----', 'burr', '----', '----']
['-----']
['------']

Enter a guess: rune
Correct!

brurne:

['---', '---', 'bur', '---', '---', '---', '---', 'run', '---']
['----', 'burr', '----', 'rune']
['-----']
['------']

Enter a guess: foo
Sorry. Try again

renrub:

['---', '---', 'bur', '---', '---', '---', '---', 'run', '---']
['----', 'burr', '----', 'rune']
['-----']
['------']

Enter a guess: burner
Correct!

nrrebu:

['---', '---', 'bur', '---', '---', '---', '---', 'run', '---']
['----', 'burr', '----', 'rune']
['-----']
['burner']

Enter a guess: burn
Correct!

enurrb:

['---', '---', 'bur', '---', '---', '---', '---', 'run', '---']
['burn', 'burr', '----', 'rune']
['-----']
['burner']

Enter a guess: urn
Correct!

nebrur:

['---', '---', 'bur', '---', '---', '---', '---', 'run', 'urn']
['burn', 'burr', '----', 'rune']
['-----']
['burner']

Enter a guess: q

['brr', 'bun', 'bur', 'err', 'nub', 'rub', 'rue', 'run', 'urn', 'burn', 'burr', 'rube', 'rune', 'rerun', 'burner']

Note that you first prompt the user for the range of word lengths to consider. The largest length requested (6 in this case) determines the length of the word that you will choose randomly from the lexicon (“burner” here). Note also that you shuffle the word on each iteration. Entering the string “q” quits the program. Display each list of same-length words guessed in alphabetical order.

Print all words at the end of the game, as shown above.

If there are no words of a particular length, just ignore them altogether (note no words of length 5 below in “seaway” with a length range of 4 through 6):

esaywa:

['away', '----', 'ayes', 'easy', 'sway', 'ways', 'yaws', 'yeas', 'yews']
['------']

You may find itertools.groupby, random.choice, and random.shuffle helpful.

Submit your code and a text file containing the transcript of a sample game session.

Hint: It is too time-consuming to check every permutation of subsets of letters for being a word for the game to be efficient. It is better to instead look at every possible word of the appropriate lengths in the dictionary and check to see if the letters are subsets of the sets of letters in the original, full-length word. Using collections.Counter makes easy work of this. (Counter is Python’s version of a “bag” data structure. You can use <, <=,>, >= as needed for checking containment. This functionality is new in Python 3.10.)

If a command-line argument is passed to the program, that argument should be used as the base word. For example, with the command below, the base word would be “stormy”:

$ python3 wordgame.py stormy

Name your Python file wordgame.py

Word file: words.txt

Write a Python program that will make an HTML index for a directory that is specified as a command-line parameter. The program should recursively traverse the directory tree of the specified directory and make an HTML index for each of the subdirectories.

The HTML index for each directory should display the name of the directory as a heading at the top of the page. It should include links to the index of each subdirectory. Each of the images in the directory should be displayed in the HTML index page below the links to subdirectories.

Each small image on an index page should be a link to the full-size image.

The file name should be displayed below each image. If the image has EXIF data (explained below) that includes a time stamp (date and time), then display the date and time below the file name. If it has EXIF data that includes GPS coordinates, use reverse geocoding (also explained below) to find the location where the image was taken and display the location under the time stamp.

Your program should recognize files with any of the following extensions (upper or lower case) as image files: JPG, JPEG, PNG, GIF

If a subdirectory does not include any image files, and none of its subdirectories contains image files, then a link for that subdirectory should not be displayed in the index. For example, in the sample index included in this assignment, there is a directory named Three. It contains images, so there is a link to Three on the index page for the Pictures directory. The Three directory has a subdirectory named ThreeA, and ThreeA has a subdirectory named ThreeA1. Neither ThreeA nor ThreeA1 has any images in it, so there is no link to ThreeA on the index page for Three.

Images and subdirectories should be sorted alphabetically. It's okay if they are sorted with capital letters coming before lower-case letters, as they are in the sample output shown below.

HTML

I don't expect you to have prior knowledge of HTML, but you will need to learn the basics of HTML to do this assignment. There is a good introduction to HTML on the Mozilla developer web site at https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/HTML/Introduction_to_HTML

Most or all of the HTML that you need for this assignment is in the templates that I provide below.

The Mozilla developer web site also has an introduction to CSS at https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/CSS

All of the CSS you need for this assignment is in the templates that I provide, but you will do better if you understand the basics of CSS.

This file has some templates that you can use for generating HTML: htmlTemplates.py

Traversing directory trees

In order to make an index page for a directory you will need to find out what files and subdirectories are in the directory. The os module provides several ways to do that, including os.scandir and os.listdir. listdir is easier to use, but scandir is probably better for this assignment because it returns a directory entry for each file or subdirectory in the directory. You can use the directory entry to tell if an entry is a subdirectory or a regular file.

Another function in the os module that is useful for this assignment is os.chdir, which you can use to change directories. You can use chdir('..') to change directories to the parent directory.

Since directory trees are trees, which are defined recursively, I recommend that you use a recursive function to travers the directory tree.

Exif data

Exif data is information about an image that digital cameras store with the image. It includes the type of camera, camera settings, the date and time that the photo was taken, and GPS coordinates of the location where it was taken. You can read about Exif information on this web site: https://photographylife.com/what-is-exif-data

For this assignment you will read the time stamp (which includes the date) and the GPS information from the Exif data. You can read Exif information using the ExifRead module. Since ExifRead is not a built-in module, you will need to install it with pip. This page tells how to install and use the module: https://pypi.org/project/ExifRead/

The exifread.process_file function takes an open file as a parameter and returns a dictionary that has tag names as the dictionary keys. If there is no Exif information for a file then an empty dictionary will be returned.

You will need to use the following tags to get the time stamp and GPS location information:
■ Image DateTime

■ GPS GPSLatitudeRef
■ GPS GPSLatitude
■ GPS GPSLongitudeRef
■ GPS GPSLongitude

I recommend that you write a small test program to experiment with exifread and see how it works before incorporating it into your main program.

Location

You can use the reverse_geocoder module to get a location name for an image that has GPS data. You can read about the reverse_geocoder on these pages:
■ https://pypi.org/project/reverse_geocoder/
■ https://github.com/thampiman/reverse-geocoder

The Exif GPS values will be in the format of a string with degrees, minutes, and seconds (DMS) in a list. The seconds will often be in the form of a fraction, with a numerator, a slash, and then a denominator. Here's an example:
"[43, 28, 1407/500]"

For reverse geocoding you will need to parse that string and get numeric values for the degrees, minutes, and seconds. Then you'll need to convert the coordinate to a decimal degrees (DD) format, where each coordinate (latitude and longitude) is a single floating-point value. for example the DD format for the DMS coordinate above would be 43.46744833333334

The formula for converting from DMS to DD is:
DD = D + M/60 + S/3600
where D is degrees, M is minutes, and S is seconds.

If the GPSLatitudeRef value is "N" (for "North") then the latitude should be positive, but if it is "S" (South) then the latitude should be negative. Similarly, if the GPSLongitudeRef value is "E" (East) the longitude should be positive and if it is "W" (West) the longitude should be negative.

The reverse_geocoder.search function will return a list of dictionaries. Use the first dictionary in the list and display the name, admin1, and cc values as location information for the image. The name will be the name of the nearest city with a population of more than 1000. For the US, admin1 will be the name of a state and for other countries it will be the name of a province or something similar. The cc value is a two-letter country code.

NOTE: The only top-level code (not inside a function or class) in a file that uses reverse_geocoder should be in a block like this:

if __name__ == '__main__':
    # Call functions to do reverse geocoding here

Otherwise you will get errors and strange behavior. I recommend that you put the reverse geocoding code in its own file rather than putting it in the same file as your main program.

Sample output

Here is a zip file that includes some directories with HTML index files generated for them: Pictures.zip

Here's a picture of the index page for the top-level directory in the zip file, show links to three subdirectories and two images. One of the images has Exif information displayed and the other one doesn't because the image doesn't have Exif data.

Turn in

Turn in these files in Canvas:

■ indexer.py - This is your main indexing program

■ geo.py - This is your code that does reverse geocoding (uses the EXIF GPS coordinates to find a location name)

Background

The Internet is a complex client-server system with millions of computers connected via IP (Internet Protocol). The World-Wide Web is an abstract layer on top of the Internet where computers communicate via HTTP (Hyper-Text Transfer Protocol). Web pages are text files requested and received through HTTP commands. All computers connected to the web have a URL (Uniform Resource Locator) that allows requests from browsers to find the destination server.

In this exercise you will write a simplistic web search engine that reads web pages and “ranks” them by how many links to them exist from other web pages. You will “crawl” the web starting with a given URL and follow its links to some level of search depth and report all URLs reached in rank order (explained below).

Requirements

Write a class named HayStack whose constructor receives a URL and an optional search depth (defaulted to 3 levels). The constructor crawls starting from the given web page, finding and following all embedded webpage links until it reaches the maximum search depth and computes the following data items:

1. An index that maps every word encountered on each crawled page to a list of URLs of all the pages that contain that word. Only keep words consisting of runs of alphabetic characters and apostrophes. Convert all words to lower case. Only consider text that is found outside of HTML tags.

2.A graph that maps every URL encountered to a list of the web pages it links to directly. (This will be used subsequently for ranking web pages by “popularity”.)

Make sure you do not crawl a page twice! That could lead to an infinite loop.

Include also the following method in your HayStack class:

   def compute_ranks(self, graph):
        d = 0.85     # probability that surfer will bail
        numloops = 10

        ranks = {}
        npages = len(graph)
        for page in graph:
            ranks[page] = 1.0 / npages

        for _ in range(0, numloops):
            newranks = {}
            for page in graph:
                newrank = (1 - d) / npages
                for url in graph:   
                    if page in graph[url]:  # this url links to page
                        newrank += d*ranks[url]/len(graph[url])
                newranks[page] = newrank
            ranks = newranks
        self.ranks = ranks

This function takes the graph mentioned above and “ranks” the web pages in graph, placing the result in a dictionary, self.ranks, where the key is the url and the value is the page’s rank. This is a simplified version of Google’s page ranking algorithm that made that search engine so famous decades ago.

Finally, write a lookup method that takes a word as a search key and outputs the webpages that contain that word in rank order, highest to lowest. See the sample output below.

Implementation Notes

■ Name your file search.py

■ You will test your code on a handful of web pages found at roversgame.net/cs3270. Make sure that your code runs with this test driver:

if __name__ == '__main__':
    engine = HayStack('http://roversgame.net/cs3270/page1.html',4)
    for w in ['pages','links','you','have','I']:
        print(w)
        pprint.pprint(engine.lookup(w))
    print()
    print('index:')
    pprint.pprint(engine.index)
    print()
    print('graph:')
    pprint.pprint(engine.graph)
    print()
    print('ranks:')
    pprint.pprint({page:round(rank,4) for page,rank in engine.ranks.items()})

The test driver code above must be included in your program and work properly to get credit for this assignment.

■ You will need to include a User-Agent header in the request that your program sends to the server. Here's an example of doing that with urllib.request:

req = urllib.request.Request(url, headers={'User-Agent' : 'XY'})

Here's an example of including a User-Agent header with the requests module:

content = requests.get(url, headers={"User-Agent": "XY"}).text

Here's a simple program that uses urllib.request and requests to download a file: urlopen.py 

■ You only have to write about 30 lines of code. Redirect this output to a text file named results.txt and submit it along with your source code.

■ Do not use Beautiful Soup, Scrapy, or anything like them. Use regular expressions and urllib.request or requests.

■ Note that you will need to import Python’s pprint module (“pretty print”). The output is below.

Background

You are aware that air pollution is a major problem in today’s world, causing respiratory issues for many individuals as well as contributing to global warming. One indicator of pollution is high ozone levels, caused in part by automobile hydrocarbon emissions.

The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) maintains ozone detection stations in various locations throughout the country. A key measure is the Air Quality Index (AQI). In the Canvas folder for this assignment is an 80mb (250,000+ lines) file named daily_44201_2021.csv, a CSV file containing all AQI data for 2021. (This is raw data downloaded directly from EPA’s website.) The first line of the file is a header row naming each column. The fields in each column of each data row are described below.

daily_44201_2021.csv

Field Position 

Field Name 

Description

1

State Code

The FIPS code of the state in which the monitor resides.

2

County Code

The FIPS code of the county in which the monitor resides.

3

Site Num

A unique number within the county identifying the site.

4

Parameter Code

The AQS code corresponding to the parameter measured by the monitor.

 

 

(many fields omitted)

20

AQI

The Air Quality Index for the day for the pollutant, if applicable.

21

Method Code

An internal system code indicating the method (processes, equipment, and protocols) used in gathering and measuring the sample. The method name is in the next column.

22

Method Name

A short description of the processes, equipment, and protocols used in gathering and measuring the sample.

23

Local Site Name

The name of the site (if any) given by the State, local, or tribal air pollution control agency that operates it.

24

Address

The approximate street address of the monitoring site.

25

State Name

The name of the state where the monitoring site is located.

26

County Name

The name of the county where the monitoring site is located.

27

City Name

The name of the city where the monitoring site is located. This represents the legal incorporated boundaries of cities and not urban areas.

28

CBSA Name

The name of the core bases statistical area (metropolitan area) where the monitoring site is located.

29

Date of Last Change

The date the last time any numeric values in this record were updated in the AQS data system.

 

You will retrieve data by the names of the state and county (columns 25 and 26).

Requirements

In this project you will plot on demand all AQI data for a given county. The number of AQI entries varies for each county and are ordered chronologically. You just need to retrieve the AQI data (column 20) in the order it appears in the file and plot it. Annotate the plot with the state and county names, as well as the average AQI, as shown below.

Once the state and county have been selected, offer a choice of two destinations for the plot:

  1. Display (the plot is shown on the screen)
  2. Save to File (the plot is saved to a file)

Submit your source code along with plot files for

  • Utah County, Utah
  • Santa Clara County, California
  • Wayne County, Michigan
  • Pima County, Arizona

Also, I have included a file, state_codes.txt, that associates the two-letter code for each state with their names as they appear in the data file.

This is a graded in-class programming exercise to give you some practice with decorators. I recommend that you work in groups of two or three students.

a) Write a decorator that prints the time that it takes for a function to execute. You can use the timeit module to get the start time and end time of the function:

from timeit import default_timer as timer
start = timer()
# ...
end = timer()
print(end - start) # Time in seconds

You might want to use time.sleep() to test your decorator. It takes a number of seconds (int or float) as its only parameter.

Sample driver code

from timeit import default_timer as timer
import time as _time

# DECORATOR DEFINITION GOES HERE

if __name__ == "__main__":
    @timedec
    def fun1(seconds):
        _time.sleep(seconds)

    fun1(2.5)

Output

Code$ ./timedec1.py
2.50
Code$

b) Modify the decorator so that it uses a function attribute to make a list of times for the function. Write code that is not part of the decorator to call the function ten times and print the list of times.

Sample driver code

from timeit import default_timer as timer
import time as _time

if __name__ == "__main__":
    @timedec
    def fun1(seconds):
        _time.sleep(seconds)

    for t in [.1, .2, .3, .4, .5, .6, .7, .8, .9]:
        fun1(t)

    print(fun1.times)
    print(", ".join(['{:.2f}'.format(t) for t in fun1.times]))

Output

Code$ ./timedec2.py 
[0.10104170300110127, 0.20013756700063823, 0.30031348600095953, 0.4001610410014109, 0.5001705899994704, 0.6006298969987256, 0.7004569050004648, 0.8007079519993567, 0.9011211779979931]
0.10, 0.20, 0.30, 0.40, 0.50, 0.60, 0.70, 0.80, 0.90 
Code$

NOTES
--Although a decorator like this might be useful, it isn't necessarily the best way to get timing information about code. Other options are to use Python profiling tools (https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/profile.html) or other functions in the timeit module (https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/timeit.html).
--It's fine to look up information about decorators in general, but for this exercise don't look up a decorator to time a function. The purpose of this exercise is to get practice with decorators, not practice looking things up on the Internet.

TURN IN
Put your decorator code (both versions) and drivers and sample output from Parts a and b into a text, Word, or PDF file and turn it in the file in Canvas.

If you work in a group only one person needs to submit a file, but make sure that the file contains the names of all group members.

Make a Tkinter demo program that does the following:

  • Has at least one other button
  • Gets user input from a text input field

Tkinter doesn't provide a way to play sounds so you will need to use the playsound module to play a sound.

Some possibilities are a unit conversion program, a dice roller, a simple RPG character generator, or a simple photo viewer.

Post a short description of your program, at least one screenshot of your program in action, and at least one code snippet.

I encourage you to work in groups of two or three students but you can work alone if you'd like. If you work in a group, make sure that the names of all the students in the group are at the beginning of the post and are easy to see.

All tasks below are executed against the database you created in Project 1.

Please submit the commands used and proof that they succeeded (results)

Please revisit your data model and ensure that the data model is normalized to 3 normal forms.

The results can be cut and pasted from the result returned or captured as screenprints. 

1. Partition One of the Tables

  • Run 'explain' on a select query before and after partitioning the table
  • Please copy the results and include them in you project 2 submission
  • Please note the partition value must include the keys. You may need to create a composite key.

2. Create a Stored Procedure / Function

  • Create a stored procedure / function to query a table and have it accept a parameter.

3. Database Views and User Access to Views

  • Create a view on every table
  • Create the role ViewAll and add select permission on all tables to this role
  • Create a user and grant them the ViewAll role

4. Create an Application Admin Role

  • Create a role called AppAdmin
  • The role should have references, select, insert, update and delete on all tables
  • Create a user and grant that user the role AppAdmin

5. Alter Tables

  • Alter one of the tables by adding a new column
  • Alter a table and rename the table

6. Primary Key (PK) and Foreign Key (FK) Constraints

  • Create PK and FK constraints on all tables in your database

7. Table Auditing using Triggers

  • Create a "history" version for one of your tables
  • Create an update trigger that populates the "history" table
  • The "history" table should contain three extra columns
    • The user who made the change
    • A timestamp column containing a default of the current time
    • A column that indicates what is the new row and which is the old row
  • An additional PK (I suggest a sequence number) is probably required on the "history" table because the trigger should contain before and after values for all columns of the source table. There are other choices for the PK

8. Check Constraints

  • Create a check constraint on at least two of your columns.

9. Schema Creation and User Access

  • Create a schema 
  • Create a copy of one of your tables in that schema
  • Populate the new table in the schema with the data from the original table
  • Create a user and give that user select, references, update, delete and update to the new table created in the schema

10. Application Report

  • Create and describe in detail a query that functions as a report in your database.
  • This report should resemble a report a real user of your system would execute on a regular basis
  • Please create the query as a view
  • Take the MySQL or Postgres Python scripts I uploaded to Canvas
  • Modify the script to connect to your database
  • Create a query from your database and display the results

Please use the tables from the database we created in class.

Please write the SQL that answers the questions below. Remember to include the "explain" output as a comment.

There are 10 queries and each is worth 3 points.

Your submission should include the commented question below with the SQL (DML / DQL) underneath.

The purpose of this assignment is to understand the relationship between joins and subqueries. 

A query can be written with either a join or subqueries depending on the use case.

Each can be used to retrieve the same desired results. It should be noted that an "EXPLAIN" should be run to choose the best SQL solution

Query:

select firstname, lastname, departmentdesc from faculty
inner join departments on faculty.departmentId = departments.departmentId
where departmentdesc = 'CSC';

Questions:

    1. Convert this query to use a SELECT subquery
    2. Convert this query to use a FROM subquery
    3. Convert this query to use a WHERE subquery

Query

select classnumber, room, buildingdesc, dayoftheweekdesc from classes
inner join buildings on buildings.buildingid = classes.buildingid
inner join dayoftheweek on dayoftheweek.dayoftheweekid = classes.dayoftheweekid
where dayoftheweekdesc = 'Friday';

Questions:

    1. Convert this query to use a SELECT subquery
    2. Convert this query to use a FROM subquery
    3. Convert this query to use a WHERE subquery

To learn how open and submit this assignment, follow this tutorial:

How do I submit a Google Cloud assignment?

Submit

Your Water Footprint

For this activity I would like you to think about water consumption. Utah is the second driest state in the nation. The more information we have on water consumption, the more we can help conserve water. Let's find out how much water you and your family use.

This is a question that you might not think about too much, so now if your chance!  

For this assignment, you will first take the Water Footprint Calculator quiz here:  https://www.watercalculator.org/ (Links to an external site.) After you answer a series of questions, you will get a result with your water use compared to the national average.   

After you have your results, read about water use in Utah here:  https://geology.utah.gov/map-pub/survey-notes/glad-you-asked/does-utah-use-more-water/ (Links to an external site.)  

Answer the following questions about water use.  

1.  What was your average water use and how did it compare to the national average? 

2.  List and describe 3 aspects of your water use that are high.  

3.  Do you think water use should be a concern to citizens and policy makers in Utah?  Why or why not?  

4.  How likely are you to make changes to your water consumption habits?  Why or why not?  What would compel you to change?  

 

Feel free to make a video for this assignment rather than an essay if you'd like!

  • A little about yourself
  • Why you are taking this class 
  • What is your major or career goal

In this discussion you are going to discover how we use the minerals within our own state in our everyday lives. For this assignment, you need to complete the following:

  1. Research two of the following minerals listed below (pick 2 that have not been chosen by other group members), discuss a few interesting facts about the minerals, where in Utah you could find the minerals, and then describe (describe not list) 2 uses for each mineral. 
  2. Respond to ONE other student's post and share what you have learned from that student's post.

Please do not discuss the spiritual, healing or mystical traits of minerals as potential uses or interesting facts regarding the mineral you research.  Even though some individuals swear by the healing potential of crystals there is not much scientific backing in this phenomenon and most scientists treat the potential healing as a placebo effect in the healing process. 

AragoniteCalciteFluoriteGypsumPyrite
AzuriteCarnotiteGalenaHaliteQuartz
BerylChalcopyriteGarnetHematiteSilver
BiotiteFeldsparGold MalachiteTopaz

The goal of this assignment is to give you the opportunity to examine volcanoes from around the globe, and to interpret the tectonic settings in which they form. To learn more about volcanoes, check out the following websites: the Smithsonian Institution Global Volcanism Program: http://volcano.si.edu/ (Links to an external site.), Volcano World: http://volcano.oregonstate.edu/ (Links to an external site.); USGS Volcanic Hazards Program http://volcanoes.usgs.gov/ (Links to an external site.).

In this discussion, you are tasked to share 2 volcanoes you would like to visit.  In your initial post, you need to include the following information

  1. An image of the volcano, (a link to the image will work as well)
  2. A description of the type of volcano (based on size, shape, and composition) and the major geologic hazards associated with the volcano
  3. Describe the likely tectonic setting of the chosen volcano. (Hint: think back to your plate tectonics lecture ). Support your answer with observations on the major tectonic landforms of the region.
  4. Why you want to visit.

After posting your initial response  respond to two of your group members’ postings. In your response explain which volcano description was most helpful for you in developing an understanding of the volcano formation and its related hazards  and which one you would most like to see in real life and why.

Tips: Google Earth will come in handy for this assignment.  Google Earth is a free software by Google you can download to your computer (https://support.google.com/earth/answer/21955?hl=en), or download the app to your smart phone. You can virtually fly to the volcano, and zoom out to observe its shape and examine the region for tectonic settings. Here are some examples you can check out in Google Earth. you can go directly there by typing in the coordinates in the search bar at the upper left side of the screen. Of course, these can be your favorite volcanoes too!

1. Descabezado Grande, Chile (-35.58, -70.75)

2. Mt. St. Helens (46.1958, - 122.1821) in southern Washington, USA. 

3. Mauna Loa on the BIG island of Hawaii (central Pacific Ocean) (19.4715, -155.59039)

4. Mt. Fujiyama, Japan (35.364, 138.731)

5. Mt. Alayta, Ethiopia (12.887, 40.573)

6. Aniakchack,  Alaska (56.901, -158.142)

The objective of this discussion is to discover how we classify igneous rocks and to interpret the history of the rock.  Once again observations and clues in the rock can aid us in our forensic GSI (Geologic Scene Investigation)!  

Each individual in your group will research one of the following igneous rocks listed below.  Each rock has a link that goes to a 3D model of the rock.  In your initial post, you are asked to come up with as many observations as you can regarding the rock (i.e. texture, color....). Based on these observations you will try to identify the rock and explain why you made that identification.  You will explain how you know its composition (Mafic, Intermediate, Felsic) and explain how you know its geological (cooling) history (i.e. is it extrusive or intrusive).  If it is intrusive you should give me an example of the igneous feature it could originate from (i.e. batholith, dike, sill, stock); whereas, if it is extrusive you should give me an example of what type of volcano it would have originated from (i.e. shield cone, cinder cone, or composite / stratocone). Here is a basic chart  to help you identify the rocks.

Description

In this activity, you will collect information about the potential earthquake hazards and vulnerability of where you live.  If you do not live along the Wasatch Front, you can use UVU's location, or some other place.  

Factors that affect seismic risk include:

  • Hazard: The chance that the building will experience strong shaking, soil liquefaction, or a landslide.
  • Vulnerability: The likelihood that the building will collapse due to those geological hazards.

Procedure

Follow these directions to collect your numbers for each index, and then input your information into the Google Sheet provided in the Module.  

First we will examine the physical geographic contexts of your location, then you will examine the dwelling itself. 

  • Examine the Strong Shaking Potential map on Page 16 of the Scenario for a Magnitude 7.0 Earthquake on the Wasatch Fault–Salt Lake City Segment report (found on Canvas). 
    • This is a map of the shaking intensity that is 10% likely to occur. Use the following categories to score the seismic hazard due to strong shaking. Score your location location using the numbers in parentheses, based on the ground acceleration. Put the score in the column labeled A on the seismic risk spreadsheet.
      • Purple to blue to green areas of the map: Low hazard (1)
      • Yellow to Orange areas of the map: Moderate hazard (2)
      • Red areas of the map: Significant hazard (3)
  • Examine the Liquefaction Potential map from the Utah Geologic Survey. This is a map of the likelihood of liquefaction due to earthquake shaking . Score your location using the numbers in parentheses, based on the liquefaction potential map. Put the score in the column labeled B on the seismic risk spreadsheet.
    • Low / Very Low hazard (1)
    • Moderate hazard (2)
    • High (3)
  • Examine the Landslide potential map of Page 21 of the Scenario for a Magnitude 7.0 Earthquake on the Wasatch Fault–Salt Lake City Segment. In this report you will find 2 maps—one of landslide potential in wet conditions and one in dry conditions. You will try to take the average between these two maps.  Estimate the landslide hazard using the categories below. Score your location using the numbers in parentheses, based on the landslide hazard. Put the score in the column labeled C on the seismic risk spreadsheet.
    • Low hazard: grey areas on map, on flat land (1)
    • Moderate hazard: green to yellow areas on the map, at foot of slope or on gradual slope (2)
    • High hazard: orange to red areas on the map, building is on a steep slope (3)

Building construction plays a large role in determining risk.  

  • Examine your house or dwelling and see if there are any “soft stories,” floors of the building with few supporting walls, such as parking garages or large auditoriums, that are underneath other floors of the building.
    • If there are Soft Stories, enter 1; if no soft stories, enter 0
  • Buildings made of unreinforced masonry (brick or concrete without reinforcement) are particularly susceptible to earthquake damage. If there is clear evidence that a building is made of unreinforced masonry, that building gets a 2 in column C. If the building is made of masonry and it was built before 1970, give it a score of 1.5.
  • Buildings with a vertical irregularity (different parts at different heights) or plan irregularity (deviations from a box-shape) tend to fare poorly in earthquakes. Give each building with either type of irregularity a score of 0.5.
  • Number of people in the house/dwelling: The “value” we are using when calculating risk in this exercise is the number of lives at risk. If you live in a house, count the number of people that are regularly present.  If you live in an apartment building or multi-dwelling unit, estimate the number of people in your particular building.  

 

After you have completed the tasks above, open the Google Sheet and add a new row with your information.  The Google Sheet can be found here (Earthquake risk assessment sheet (Links to an external site.)) and also on the Modules tab for this unit.  Your risk will be automatically calculated once you enter in the information in the columns.  The lower the number is the risk column, the better.  

In your discussion, share your results.  What was your risk score?  What were some of the biggest contributing factors to your risk score?  What surprised you about earthquake risk in Utah?  How could you reduce your earthquake risk? 

You will also comment on two group members.  Give a general reaction to their score and ask one question about their risk score that they did not discuss.  For example, you might ask why their risk of landslides was high, or liquefaction low.  Finally, help them think about ways to be prepared for an earthquake.  

You should post your initial discussion post by Friday night so that people will have time to make comments to your post,  and you have time to comment on  other's posts. The due date for this assignment is Sunday midnight.

Geological structures are also connected to plate tectonics and form many of the features / landforms that we see around us. In the discussion this week we will first try to identify some geological features and then you will try to connect the theory of plate tectonics with the structure.  

Original Post Instructions:  Pick one of the field photos listed below.  As before you should check if someone else has already researched that photo in your group.  You need to research a photo that someone else has not discussed.  As always some are easier than others.

Field Photo 01

Ketobe Knob, Utah

Field Photo 02

Moab, Utah

Field Photo 03

Sideling, Maryland

Field Photo 04

Cedar Mountain, Utah

Field Photo 05 

New Zealand

Field Photo 06

Mauritania, Africa

Field Photo 07

Bighorn, Wyoming

Field Photo 08

Provo, Utah

Field Photo 09

Walnut Bottom, West Virginia

The hope is that we will all help each other to make these connections.  It is important to help students make these connections but how the concepts connect may be difficult for students to grasp. 

The assignment is to identify the geological structure or structures in your field photo, discuss the related stress that formed the feature, and then how it is related to plate tectonics. Remember to cite your resources and put things in your own words.

  1. Identify the geological structure in the field photo.
    • Make sure you describe the observations you made when identifying the feature.
  2. Describe the type of deformation that would have caused the feature (i.e. Brittle deformation, Plastic Deformation) and stress/strain relationship (i.e. compression, extensional, shear, etc...)
  3. Many of the field photos are not technically at a plate boundary but are still caused by processes involved with plate tectonics.  Describe what kind of plate boundary the feature could be associated with and why. 

Commenting Post Instructions: When you comment on other individuals posts I would ask that you let us know where else in the world you may find these kind of structures.

assignment_name: Unit 11: Utah Lake Water Quality Issues
description:
Discuss

As many of you know, every summer Utah Lake experienced severe problems with algal blooms, which results in localized closures and impacts water supply in the region.  For this assignment, you will discuss what causes algal blooms on the lake, and think about ways to solve these problems. 

Read these recent articles on Utah Lake for some background information on Utah Lake: 

  • State officials seek to avoid repeat of summertime algal blooms: https://www.ksl.com/?sid=44721370&nid=148 (Links to an external site.),
  • First Utah Lake Summit seeks to answer questions, provide solutions for future: http://www.heraldextra.com/news/local/first-utah-lake-summit-seeks-to-answer-questions-provide-solutions/article_84d86b47-b967-56cc-9247-3af82848cef4.html (Links to an external site.)
  • Will algal blooms return to Utah waters? If so, state officials say they’re better prepared: http://www.sltrib.com/home/5423688-155/will-algal-blooms-return-to-utah (Links to an external site.)
  • Utah Lake’s poop-driven algal bloom is a crappy situation: https://www.wired.com/2016/07/pretty-algae-bloom-lake-utah-blame-pooping/ (Links to an external site.) 

This chapter in your textbook discusses nutrient cycles that shape ecosystems, like Utah Lake.  These nutrient cycles are key to understanding the problems facing Utah Lake. 

In your original post (at least a couple of paragraphs) , you need address the following questions: 

  1. How are humans implicated in the algal bloom problems on Utah Lake?
  2. How could algal blooms on Utah Lake effect other waterways in the state?
  3. Describe in detail three possible solutions for solving the algal bloom problem.

After posting your post by midnight Friday, you need respond to 2 of your team members' post by midnight on Sunday.

I hope you enjoyed the documentary and have learned something from it. Now it is time to reflect on the documentary. 

In your initial post, I'd like you to answer the following questions:

1. If you had some knowledge on climate change before the film, has your perception shifted or been reinforced in any way?
2. Has your local city or neighborhood experienced any effects of climate change? Do you know anyone who has experienced the consequences of climate change?
3. What skills do you posses, like James who used his photography, to make a difference for this issue?
4. What is one change you want to create in your community to combat the effects of climate change?
5. What would you like to tell an elected official in your town, country or world about climate change?

In your comment posts, you need reply to two other posts and comment on what you learned from their posts. (Important: everyone has their right to express their opinions, we should all have an open mind to accept each other's views even if they are totally different. We always learn from other people, big or small!)

Greetings!

It was nice to have you in my class this semester and thanks for completing the SRI for this class. I look forward to seeing your feedback. Please upload a picture of your SRI receipt here for extra credits. Let me know if you have any questions. 

Best wishes and enjoy the rest of your summer!

Weihong

After reviewing the vocabulary page complete the following questions-

There will be several sketches that you will need to make as well as images you will need to modify and then upload. Below are links to the images you will need to modify-

Antelope Island Paleoshorelines.JPG

Groyne-direction of longshore drift.JPG

Do not do this lab until you have watched both instruction videos.

 

You will need to upload two files, The first is a rough sketch of a hill that formed as a sub-glacial deposit. The second is completing a graph showing how a glacier receded over time. A copy of the graph and the aerial photo you will use for that question is below. 

updated Graph for Receding glacier in Greenland.JPG

Greenland receding glacier.jpg

After view the instruction videos on the vocabulary page- Complete the questions below for the online version of the Earthquake lab. 

There are 4 files that you will need to upload.

1) The location of an earthquake epicenter that you will find on https://www.sciencecourseware.org/VirtualEarthquake/ (any of the first three examples)

2) The certificate at the end of the exercise

3) Draw contour lines for a shaking intensity map

4) Marking liquefaction risk for San Francisco

This is the online lab for groundwater. There will be three drawings that you will submit for part of the lab. 

1) Showing changes in water flow due to over pumping of a well

2) An elevation profile of part of central Florida riddled with sinkholes.

3) Showing the height the water would rise to when a well is drilled into a confined water table.

You may either draw your sketches on paper and scan them in or snap a photo to submit it, or draw it on your computer and upload your saved diagram for the question.

How to draw using PowerPoint

Online Streams Lab-Google Earth Files.kmz

The final can only raise your grade. If it does not raise your grade, then your pre-final grade will be used.

Look up Industrial/Commercial Uses for any of the following minerals. (Note: Uses like crystal healing are not what we're looking for)

  • Diamond (non- jewelry)

Since the discussions are meant for preparation for the lab they will be due before class each week. The discussion for the first week will has a later due date since we are just starting the class. 

Please introduce yourself. Tell us where you are from, your major and anything else you think may be of interest (favorite food, pets, etc.) Then write a couple of sentences about the rest of the discussion- plate tectonics.

Plate Tectonics is the unifying theory of Geology. Everything relates to Plate Tectonics. Pick something that is related to Plate Tectonics and describe it below. It can be a place on the Earth that is located at a plate boundary. It can be landforms/physical geography caused by Plate Tectonics. It could be resources, hazards, or other features related to the landforms caused by Plate Tectonics.

Types of Igneous Rocks

There are several places where igneous rocks can be found in and around Utah. Two that many in the public are aware of are the Granites and Granodiorites in Little Cottonwood Canyon near Salt Lake City, and Basaltic cinder cones and lava flows west of Fillmore in Central Utah.

For your first post note differences in the rocks at these two sites. Include such things as grain size, texture, types of minerals, color, weight and any other ways that these rocks formed. Brownie points for those who note differences in the age of these particular rocks and the particular tectonic settings that led to their formation at that particular time and location in Utah. 

For replies you may also include other locations where similar rocks have formed, and how they might be different than the two sites noted above.

Sedimentary Rocks

Sedimentary Rocks are responsible for the scenery in many of the National Parks and Monuments in Utah as well as the Grand Canyon in Arizona. Pick one of the sedimentary layers in the Grand Canyon (link) and find similarities and differences with a Sedimentary unit in one of the National Parks in Southern Utah, or layer found in the Wasatch Front, or other place of your choosing. You can focus on such things as grain size, texture, composition, thickness of layers, color, age, environment of deposition or any other similarities or differences that are noteworthy.

Discuss

What is your favorite metamorphic rock? Have you ever seen this rock outside? What are some of the things you like about your favorite metamorphic rock?  If you can include a picture feel free to do so.

Hints to get you started-

A large portion of the rock sold as "Granite" countertops is actually metamorphic. Any time you see any bands or swirls, it's a good indication that it is a foliated metamorphic rock, like Gneiss.

Marble has been used throughout history for statues and other decorative stone work.

You can find metamorphic rocks at the bottom of the Grand Canyon (the inner gorge), in the Uintas, in the lower portion of Rock Canyon in Provo, and in few other spots along the Wasatch Front.

Make sure and comment on at least 1 other persons paragraph.

There are dozens in not thousands of different coordinate systems that can be used for maps. Some are set up to work world wide, while others are set up to only work for specific areas. Two coordinate systems that are widely used in the US are-

1) Latitude and Longitude

2) The Public Land Survey System (aka Township and Range)

The diagram above shows how Latitude and Latitude works.

 

 

 

 

The diagram above shows how the Public Land Survey System works.

 

Compare these, or other coordinate systems of your choosing, and note any advantages or disadvantages you can find. These may include ease of use, familiarity, and which areas/uses the coordinate system is set up/optimized for.

Geological structures are one of the important features that are shown on Geologic Maps. They include different kinds of any change in the form or position of the rocks. Geologic Structures include faults, such as normal (aka dip-slip), reverse, thrust and strike-slip faults. Other structures include rock folds, such as anticlines, synclines, monoclines, domes and basins.

Geologic Structures are connected to plate tectonics and form many of the features / landforms that we see around us. In the discussion this week we will first try to identify some geological features and then you will try to connect the theory of plate tectonics with the structure.  

Original Post Instructions:  

1. Pick one of the geologic cross-sections shown below.  Try to find a two different geologic structures on at least two different cross sections. 

2. Describe the type of deformation that would have caused the feature (i.e. Brittle deformation, Plastic Deformation) and stress/strain relationship (i.e. compression, extensional, shear, etc...)

3. Many of the cross-sections are not technically at a plate boundary but are still caused by processes involved with plate tectonics.  Describe what kind of plate boundary the feature could be associated with and why.

For 5 points extra credit for participation, complete the course evaluation and attach a copy of your SRI receipt here.

Homework Instructions:

  • Work through the assigned problems from the section.  These are listed on the Homework Problem List.
  • Open the homework solutions (below the assignment on Canvas) and "grade" your homework using a pen/pencil of a different color than you used for the homework.
  • Re-work any problems that you missed.  If you got all problems correct on the first attempt, simply write "100%" on the top of the first page.
  • Submit your homework (either online or in person).  Assignments are due at midnight on the date listed on Canvas.
    • If you choose to turn in the assignment online, scan or photograph both the original homework and the re-worked problems.  Upload either a PDF or JPG image on Canvas for your submission.
    • If you choose to turn in a paper assignment, it can be dropped off either in class or to my office (LA109k).  Make sure to place your homework in the proper folder!

Be aware that simply doing the required problems may not be enough to achieve mastery of the material!  Additional recommended problems are provided, but not required.
